Depressive disorder.name: Depression
Depressive disorder.summary: <p>Depression is a serious medical <span class="qt2">illness</span>. It's more than just a feeling of being sad or "blue" for a few days. If you are one of the more than 19 million teens and adults in the United States who have depression, the feelings do not go away. They persist and interfere with your everyday life. Symptoms can include:</p><ul><li>Feeling sad or "empty"</li><li>Loss of interest in favorite activities</li><li>Overeating, or not wanting to eat at all</li><li>Not being able to sleep, or sleeping too much</li><li>Feeling very tired</li><li>Feeling hopeless, irritable, anxious, or guilty</li><li>Aches or pains, headaches, cramps, or digestive problems</li><li>Thoughts of death or suicide</li></ul><p>Depression is a <span class="qt1">disorder</span> of the brain. There are a variety of causes, including genetic, biological, environmental, and psychological factors. Depression can happen at any age, but it often begins in teens and young adults. It is much more common in women. Women can also get  postpartum depression after the birth of a baby. Some people get seasonal affective <span class="qt1">disorder</span> in the winter. Depression is one part of bipolar <span class="qt1">disorder</span>.</p><p>There are effective treatments for depression, including antidepressants, talk therapy, or both.</p><p>NIH: National Institute of Mental Health</p>

Hypertensive disease.name: Pulmonary <span class="qt2">Hypertension</span>
Hypertensive disease.summary: <p>Pulmonary <span class="qt2">hypertension</span> (PH) is <span class="qt2">high blood pressure</span> in the arteries to your lungs. It is a serious condition. If you have it, the blood vessels that carry blood from your heart to your lungs become hard and narrow. Your heart has to work harder to pump the blood through. Over time, your heart weakens and cannot do its job and you can develop heart failure. </p><p>Symptoms of PH  include:</p><ul><li>Shortness of breath during routine activity, such as climbing two flights of stairs</li><li>Tiredness</li><li>Chest pain</li><li>A racing heartbeat</li><li>Pain on the upper right side of the abdomen</li><li>Decreased appetite</li></ul><p>As PH worsens, you may find it hard to do any physical activities.</p><p>There are two main kinds of PH. One runs in families or appears for no known reason. The other kind is related to another condition, usually heart or lung <span class="qt1">disease</span>. </p><p>There is no cure for PH. Treatments can control symptoms.  They involve treating the heart or lung <span class="qt1">disease</span>, medicines, oxygen, and sometimes lung transplantation.</p><p>NIH: National Heart, Lung, and Blood Institute</p>

Coronary arteriosclerosis.name: <span class="qt0"><span class="qt2">Coronary</span></span><span class="qt2"> Artery Disease</span>
Coronary arteriosclerosis.summary: <p><span class="qt0"><span class="qt2">Coronary</span></span><span class="qt2"> artery disease</span> (CAD) is the most common type of <span class="qt0">heart</span> disease. It is the leading cause of death in the United States in both men and women.</p><p>CAD happens when the arteries that supply blood to <span class="qt0">heart</span> muscle become hardened and narrowed. This is due to the buildup of cholesterol and other material, called plaque, on their inner walls. This buildup is called atherosclerosis. As it grows, less blood can flow through the arteries. As a result, the <span class="qt0">heart</span> muscle can't get the blood or oxygen it needs. This can lead to chest pain (angina) or a <span class="qt0">heart</span> attack.  Most <span class="qt0">heart</span> attacks happen when a blood clot suddenly cuts off the <span class="qt0">hearts</span>' blood supply, causing permanent <span class="qt0">heart</span> damage.  </p><p>Over time, CAD can also weaken the <span class="qt0">heart</span> muscle and contribute to <span class="qt0">heart</span> failure and arrhythmias. <span class="qt0">Heart</span> failure means the <span class="qt0">heart</span> can't pump blood well to the rest of the body. Arrhythmias are changes in the normal beating rhythm of the <span class="qt0">heart</span>.  </p><p>NIH: National <span class="qt0">Heart</span>, Lung, and Blood Institute</p>

Coronavirus disease 2019.name: <span class="qt1">COVID-19 (</span><span class="qt0"><span class="qt1">Coronavirus</span></span><span class="qt1"> <span class="qt2">Disease</span> <span class="qt3">2019</span></span>)
Coronavirus disease 2019.summary: <p><span class="qt1">COVID-19 (</span><span class="qt0"><span class="qt1">coronavirus</span></span><span class="qt1"> <span class="qt2">disease</span> <span class="qt3">2019</span></span>) is an <span class="qt2">illness</span> caused by a virus. This virus is a <span class="qt0">coronavirus</span> called SARS-CoV-2. It spreads when a person who has the infection breathes out droplets and very small particles that contain the virus. On this page, you'll find links to resources on important issues such as symptoms, risks, and how you can protect yourself and your family.</p><p>We also have pages on:</p><ul><li>COVID-19 testing</li><li>COVID-19 vaccines</li><li>Post-COVID conditions (long COVID)</li></ul>

Accident cerebrovascular.name: Ischemic <span class="qt1">Stroke</span>
Accident cerebrovascular.summary: <p>A <span class="qt1">stroke</span> is a medical emergency. There are two types - ischemic and hemorrhagic. Ischemic <span class="qt1">stroke</span> is the more common type. It is usually caused by a blood clot that blocks or plugs a blood vessel in the brain. This keeps blood from flowing to the brain. Within minutes, brain cells begin to die.  Another cause is stenosis, or narrowing of the artery. This can happen because of atherosclerosis, a disease in which plaque builds up inside your arteries. Transient ischemic attacks (TIAs) occur when the blood supply to the brain is interrupted briefly. Having a TIA can mean you are at risk for having a more serious <span class="qt1">stroke</span>.</p><p>Symptoms of <span class="qt1">stroke</span> are:</p><ul><li>Sudden numbness or weakness of the face, arm or leg (especially on one side of the body)</li><li>Sudden confusion, trouble speaking or understanding speech</li><li>Sudden trouble seeing in one or both eyes</li><li>Sudden trouble walking, dizziness, loss of balance or coordination</li><li>Sudden severe headache with no known cause</li></ul><p>It is important to treat <span class="qt1">strokes</span> as quickly as possible. Blood thinners may be used to stop a <span class="qt1">stroke</span> while it is happening by quickly dissolving the blood clot. Post-<span class="qt1">stroke</span> rehabilitation can help people overcome disabilities caused by <span class="qt1">stroke</span> damage.</p><p>NIH: National Institute of Neurological Disorders and <span class="qt1">Stroke</span></p>

Arrhythmias are changes in the normal beating rhythm of the <span class="qt0"><span class="qt1">heart</span></span>.  </p><p>NIH: National <span class="qt0"><span class="qt1">Heart</span></span>, Lung, and Blood Institute</p>

Diabetes.name: <span class="qt0">Diabetes</span>
Diabetes.summary:
<p><span class="qt0">Diabetes</span> is a disease in which your blood glucose, or blood sugar, levels are too high.  Glucose comes from the foods you eat. Insulin is a hormone that helps the glucose get into your cells to give them energy.  With type 1 <span class="qt0">diabetes</span>, your body does not make insulin.  With type 2 <span class="qt0">diabetes</span>, the more common type, your body does not make or use insulin well. Without enough insulin, the glucose stays in your blood. You can also have prediabetes.  This means that your blood sugar is higher than normal but not high enough to be called <span class="qt0">diabetes</span>.  Having prediabetes puts you at a higher risk of getting type 2 <span class="qt0">diabetes</span>.</p><p>Over time, having too much glucose in your blood can cause serious problems.    It can damage your eyes, kidneys, and nerves. <span class="qt0">Diabetes</span> can also cause heart disease, stroke and even the need to remove a limb. Pregnant women can also get <span class="qt0">diabetes</span>, called gestational <span class="qt0">diabetes</span>.</p><p>Blood tests can show if you have <span class="qt0">diabetes</span>. One type of test, the A1C, can also check on how you are managing your <span class="qt0">diabetes</span>. Exercise, weight control and sticking to your meal plan can help control your <span class="qt0">diabetes</span>. You should also monitor your blood glucose level and take medicine if prescribed. 
</p><p>NIH: National Institute of <span class="qt0">Diabetes</span> and Digestive and Kidney Diseases</p>

Hypercholesterolemia.name: <span class="qt1">Cholesterol</span>
Hypercholesterolemia.summary: What is <span class="qt1">cholesterol</span>?<p><span class="qt1">Cholesterol</span> is a waxy, fat-like substance that's found in all the cells in your body. Your body needs some <span class="qt1">cholesterol</span> to make hormones, vitamin D, and substances that help you digest foods. Your body makes all the <span class="qt1">cholesterol</span> it needs. <span class="qt1">Cholesterol</span> is also found in foods from animal sources, such as egg yolks, meat, and cheese.</p><p>If you have too much <span class="qt1">cholesterol</span> in your blood, it can combine with other substances in the blood to form plaque. Plaque sticks to the walls of your arteries. This buildup of plaque is known as atherosclerosis. It can lead to coronary artery disease, where your coronary arteries become narrow or even blocked.</p>What are HDL, LDL, and VLDL?<p>HDL, LDL, and VLDL are lipoproteins. They are a combination of fat (lipid) and protein. The lipids need to be attached to the proteins so they can move through the blood. Different types of lipoproteins have different purposes:</p><ul><li>HDL stands for high-density lipoprotein. It is sometimes called "good" <span class="qt1">cholesterol</span> because it carries <span class="qt1">cholesterol</span> from other parts of your body back to your liver. Your liver then removes the <span class="qt1">cholesterol</span> from your body.</li><li>LDL stands for low-density lipoprotein. It is sometimes called "bad" <span class="qt1">cholesterol</span> because a high LDL level leads to the buildup of plaque in your arteries.</li><li>VLDL stands for very low-density lipoprotein. Some people also call VLDL a "bad" <span class="qt1">cholesterol</span> because it too contributes to the buildup of plaque in your arteries. But VLDL and LDL are different; VLDL mainly carries triglycerides and LDL mainly carries <span class="qt1">cholesterol</span>.</li></ul>What causes high <span class="qt1">cholesterol</span>?<p>The most common cause of high <span class="qt1">cholesterol</span> is an unhealthy lifestyle. This can include:</p><ul><li>Unhealthy eating habits, such as eating lots of bad fats. One type, saturated fat, is found in some meats, dairy products, chocolate, baked goods, and deep-fried and processed foods. Another type, trans fat, is in some fried and processed foods. Eating these fats can raise your LDL (bad) <span class="qt1">cholesterol</span>.</li><li>Lack of physical activity, with lots of sitting and little exercise. This lowers your HDL (good) <span class="qt1">cholesterol</span>.</li><li>Smoking, which lowers HDL <span class="qt1">cholesterol</span>, especially in women. It also raises your LDL <span class="qt1">cholesterol</span>.</li></ul><p>Genetics may also cause people to have high <span class="qt1">cholesterol</span>. For example, familial <span class="qt0">hypercholesterolemia</span> (FH) is an inherited form of high <span class="qt1">cholesterol</span>. Other medical conditions and certain medicines may also cause high <span class="qt1">cholesterol</span>.</p>What can raise my risk of high <span class="qt1">cholesterol</span>?<p>A variety of things can raise your risk for high <span class="qt1">cholesterol</span>:</p><ul><li>Age. Your <span class="qt1">cholesterol</span> levels tend to rise as you get older. Even though it is less common, younger people, including children and teens, can also have high <span class="qt1">cholesterol</span>.</li><li>Heredity. High blood <span class="qt1">cholesterol</span> can run in families.</li><li>Weight. Being overweight or having obesity raises your <span class="qt1">cholesterol</span> level.</li><li>Race. Certain races may have an increased risk of high <span class="qt1">cholesterol</span>. For example, African Americans typically have higher HDL and LDL <span class="qt1">cholesterol</span> levels than whites.</li></ul>What health problems can high <span class="qt1">cholesterol</span> cause?<p>If you have large deposits of plaque in your arteries, an area of plaque can rupture (break open). This can cause a blood clot to form on the surface of the plaque. If the clot becomes large enough, it can mostly or completely block blood flow in a coronary artery.</p><p>If the flow of oxygen-rich blood to your heart muscle is reduced or blocked, it can cause angina (chest pain) or a heart attack.</p><p>Plaque also can build up in other arteries in your body, including the arteries that bring oxygen-rich blood to your brain and limbs. This can lead to problems such as carotid artery disease, stroke, and peripheral arterial disease.</p>How is high <span class="qt1">cholesterol</span> diagnosed?<p>There are usually no signs or symptoms that you have high <span class="qt1">cholesterol</span>. There is a blood test to measure your <span class="qt1">cholesterol</span> level. When and how often you should get this test depends on your age, risk factors, and family history.  The general recommendations are:</p><p>For people who are age 19 or younger::</p><ul><li>The first test should be between ages 9 to 11</li><li>Children should have the test again every 5 years</li><li>Some children may have this test starting at age 2 if there is a family history of high blood <span class="qt1">cholesterol</span>, heart attack, or stroke</li></ul><p>For people who are age 20 or older::</p><ul><li>Younger adults should have the test every 5 years</li><li>Men ages 45 to 65 and women ages 55 to 65 should have it every 1 to 2 years</li></ul>How can I lower my <span class="qt1">cholesterol</span>?<p>You can lower your <span class="qt1">cholesterol</span> through heart-healthy lifestyle changes. They include a heart-healthy eating plan, weight management, and regular physical activity.</p><p>If the lifestyle changes alone do not lower your <span class="qt1">cholesterol</span> enough, you may also need to take medicines. There are several types of <span class="qt1">cholesterol</span>-lowering drugs available, including statins. If you take medicines to lower your <span class="qt1">cholesterol</span>, you still should continue with the lifestyle changes.</p><p>Some people with familial <span class="qt0">hypercholesterolemia</span> (FH) may receive a treatment called lipoprotein apheresis. This treatment uses a filtering machine to remove LDL <span class="qt1">cholesterol</span> from the blood. Then the machine returns the rest of the blood back to the person.</p><p>NIH: National Heart, Lung, and Blood Institute</p>

Chronic obstructive airway disease.name: <span class="qt0"><span class="qt1"><span class="qt3">COPD</span></span></span>
Chronic obstructive airway disease.summary:
What is <span class="qt0"><span class="qt1"><span class="qt3">COPD</span></span> (chronic</span> <span class="qt1">obstructive</span> pulmonary <span class="qt3">disease</span>)?<p><span class="qt0"><span class="qt1"><span class="qt3">COPD</span></span> (chronic</span> <span class="qt1">obstructive</span> pulmonary <span class="qt3">disease</span>) is a group of lung <span class="qt3">diseases</span> that make it hard to breathe and get worse over time.</p><p>Normally, the <span class="qt2">airways</span> and air sacs in your lungs are elastic or stretchy. When you breathe in, the <span class="qt2">airways</span> bring air to the air sacs. The air sacs fill up with air, like a small balloon. When you breathe out, the air sacs deflate, and the air goes out. If you have <span class="qt0"><span class="qt1"><span class="qt3">COPD</span></span></span>, less air flows in and out of your <span class="qt2">airways</span> because of one or more problems:</p><ul><li>The <span class="qt2">airways</span> and air sacs in your lungs become less elastic</li><li>The walls between many of the air sacs are destroyed</li><li>The walls of the <span class="qt2">airways</span> become thick and inflamed</li><li>The <span class="qt2">airways</span> make more mucus than usual and can become clogged</li></ul>What are the types of <span class="qt0"><span class="qt1"><span class="qt3">COPD</span></span> (chronic</span> <span class="qt1">obstructive</span> pulmonary <span class="qt3">disease</span>)?<p><span class="qt0"><span class="qt1"><span class="qt3">COPD</span></span></span> includes two main types:</p><ul><li>Emphysema affects the air sacs in your lungs, as well as the walls between them. They become damaged and are less elastic.</li><li><span class="qt0">Chronic</span> bronchitis, in which the lining of your <span class="qt2">airways</span> is constantly irritated and inflamed. This causes the lining to swell and make mucus.</li></ul><p>Most people with <span class="qt0"><span class="qt1"><span class="qt3">COPD</span></span></span> have both emphysema and <span class="qt0">chronic</span> bronchitis, but how severe each type is can be different from person to person.</p>What causes <span class="qt0"><span class="qt1"><span class="qt3">COPD</span></span> (chronic</span> <span class="qt1">obstructive</span> pulmonary <span class="qt3">disease</span>)?<p>The cause of <span class="qt0"><span class="qt1"><span class="qt3">COPD</span></span></span> is usually long-term exposure to irritants that damage your lungs and <span class="qt2">airways</span>. In the United States, cigarette smoke is the main cause. Pipe, cigar, and other types of tobacco smoke can also cause <span class="qt0"><span class="qt1"><span class="qt3">COPD</span></span></span>, especially if you inhale them.</p><p>Exposure to other inhaled irritants can contribute to <span class="qt0"><span class="qt1"><span class="qt3">COPD</span></span></span>. These include secondhand smoke, air pollution, and chemical fumes or dusts from the environment or workplace.</p><p>Rarely, a genetic condition called alpha-1 antitrypsin deficiency can play a role in causing <span class="qt0"><span class="qt1"><span class="qt3">COPD</span></span></span>.</p>Who is at risk for <span class="qt0"><span class="qt1"><span class="qt3">COPD</span></span> (chronic</span> <span class="qt1">obstructive</span> pulmonary <span class="qt3">disease</span>)?<p>The risk factors for <span class="qt0"><span class="qt1"><span class="qt3">COPD</span></span></span> include:</p><ul><li>Smoking. This the main risk factor. Up to 75% of people who have <span class="qt0"><span class="qt1"><span class="qt3">COPD</span></span></span> smoke or used to smoke.</li><li>Long-term exposure to other lung irritants, such as secondhand smoke, air pollution, and chemical fumes and dusts from the environment or workplace</li><li>Age. Most people who have <span class="qt0"><span class="qt1"><span class="qt3">COPD</span></span></span> are at least 40 years old when their symptoms begin.</li><li>Genetics. This includes alpha-1 antitrypsin deficiency, which is a genetic condition. Also, smokers who get <span class="qt0"><span class="qt1"><span class="qt3">COPD</span></span></span> are more likely to get it if they have a family history of <span class="qt0"><span class="qt1"><span class="qt3">COPD</span></span></span>.</li><li>Asthma. People who have asthma have more risk of developing <span class="qt0"><span class="qt1"><span class="qt3">COPD</span></span></span> than people who don't have asthma. But most people with asthma will not get <span class="qt0"><span class="qt1"><span class="qt3">COPD</span></span></span>.</li></ul>What are the symptoms of <span class="qt0"><span class="qt1"><span class="qt3">COPD</span></span> (chronic</span> <span class="qt1">obstructive</span> pulmonary <span class="qt3">disease</span>)?<p>At first, you may have no symptoms or only mild symptoms. As the <span class="qt3">disease</span> gets worse, your symptoms usually become more severe. They can include:</p><ul><li>Frequent coughing or a cough that produces a lot mucus</li><li>Wheezing</li><li>A whistling or squeaky sound when you breathe</li><li>Shortness of breath, especially with physical activity</li><li>Tightness in your chest</li></ul><p>Some people with <span class="qt0"><span class="qt1"><span class="qt3">COPD</span></span></span> get frequent respiratory infections such as colds and the flu. In severe cases, <span class="qt0"><span class="qt1"><span class="qt3">COPD</span></span></span> can cause weight loss, weakness in your lower muscles, and swelling in your ankles, feet, or legs.</p>How is <span class="qt0"><span class="qt1"><span class="qt3">COPD</span></span> (chronic</span> <span class="qt1">obstructive</span> pulmonary <span class="qt3">disease</span>) diagnosed?<p>Your health care provider may use many tools to make a diagnosis:</p><ul><li>A medical history, which includes asking about your symptoms</li><li>A family history</li><li>Various tests, such as lung function tests, a chest x-ray or CT scan, and blood tests</li></ul><p>Your doctor will diagnose <span class="qt0"><span class="qt1"><span class="qt3">COPD</span></span></span> based on your signs and symptoms, your medical and family histories, and test results.</p>What are the treatments for <span class="qt0"><span class="qt1"><span class="qt3">COPD</span></span> (chronic</span> <span class="qt1">obstructive</span> pulmonary <span class="qt3">disease</span>)?<p>There is no cure for <span class="qt0"><span class="qt1"><span class="qt3">COPD</span></span></span>. However, treatments can help with symptoms, slow the progress of the <span class="qt3">disease</span>, and improve your ability to stay active. There are also treatments to prevent or treat complications of the <span class="qt3">disease</span>. Treatments include:</p><ul><li>Lifestyle changes, such as
	<ul><li>Quitting smoking if you are a smoker. This is the most important step you can take to treat <span class="qt0"><span class="qt1"><span class="qt3">COPD</span></span></span>.</li><li>Avoiding secondhand smoke and places where you might breathe in other lung irritants</li><li>Ask your health care provider for an eating plan that will meet your nutritional needs. Also ask about how much physical activity you can do. Physical activity can strengthen the muscles that help you breathe and improve your overall wellness.</li></ul></li><li>Medicines, such as
	<ul><li>Bronchodilators, which relax the muscles around your <span class="qt2">airways</span>. This helps open your <span class="qt2">airways</span> and makes breathing easier. Most bronchodilators are taken through an inhaler. In more severe cases, the inhaler may also contain steroids to reduce inflammation.</li><li>Vaccines for the flu and pneumococcal pneumonia, since people with <span class="qt0"><span class="qt1"><span class="qt3">COPD</span></span></span> are at higher risk for serious problems from these <span class="qt3">diseases</span></li><li>Antibiotics if you get a bacterial or viral lung infection</li></ul></li><li>Oxygen therapy, if you have severe <span class="qt0"><span class="qt1"><span class="qt3">COPD</span></span></span> and low levels of oxygen in your blood. Oxygen therapy can help you breathe better. You may need extra oxygen all the time or only at certain times.</li><li>Pulmonary rehabilitation, which is a program that helps improve the well-being of people who have <span class="qt0">chronic</span> breathing problems. It may include
	<ul><li>An exercise program</li><li><span class="qt3">Disease</span> management training</li><li>Nutritional counseling</li><li>Psychological counseling</li></ul></li><li>Surgery, usually as a last resort for people who have severe symptoms that have not gotten better with medicines:
	<ul><li>For <span class="qt0"><span class="qt1"><span class="qt3">COPD</span></span></span> that is mainly related to emphysema, there are surgeries that 
			<ul><li>Remove damaged lung tissue</li><li>Remove large air spaces (bullae) that can form when air sacs are destroyed. The bullae can interfere with breathing.</li></ul>
		</li><li>For severe <span class="qt0"><span class="qt1"><span class="qt3">COPD</span></span></span>, some people may need lung transplant</li></ul></li></ul><p>If you have <span class="qt0"><span class="qt1"><span class="qt3">COPD</span></span></span>, it's important to know when and where to get help for your symptoms. You should get emergency care if you have severe symptoms, such as trouble catching your breath or talking. Call your health care provider if your symptoms are getting worse or if you have signs of an infection, such as a fever.</p>Can <span class="qt0"><span class="qt1"><span class="qt3">COPD</span></span> (chronic</span> <span class="qt1">obstructive</span> pulmonary <span class="qt3">disease</span>) be prevented?<p>Since smoking causes most cases of <span class="qt0"><span class="qt1"><span class="qt3">COPD</span></span></span>, the best way to prevent it is to not smoke. It's also important to try to avoid lung irritants such as secondhand smoke, air pollution, chemical fumes, and dusts.</p><p>NIH: National Heart, Lung, and Blood Institute</p>

Anemia.name: <span class="qt0">Anemia</span>
Anemia.summary: <p>If you have <span class="qt0">anemia</span>, your blood does not carry enough oxygen to the rest of your body.  The most common cause of <span class="qt0">anemia</span> is not having enough iron. Your body needs iron to make hemoglobin. Hemoglobin is an iron-rich protein that gives the red color to blood. It carries oxygen from the lungs to the rest of the body.</p><p><span class="qt0">Anemia</span> has three main causes: blood loss, lack of red blood cell production, and high rates of red blood cell destruction.</p><p>Conditions that may lead to <span class="qt0">anemia</span> include:</p><ul><li>Heavy periods</li><li>Pregnancy</li><li>Ulcers</li><li>Colon polyps or colon cancer</li><li>Inherited disorders</li><li>A diet that does not have enough iron, folic acid or vitamin B12</li><li>Blood disorders such as sickle cell <span class="qt0">anemia</span> and thalassemia, or cancer</li><li>Aplastic <span class="qt0">anemia</span>, a condition that can be inherited or acquired</li><li>G6PD deficiency, a metabolic disorder</li></ul><p><span class="qt0">Anemia</span> can make you feel tired, cold, dizzy, and irritable. You may be short of breath or have a headache.</p><p>Your doctor will diagnose <span class="qt0">anemia</span> with a physical exam and blood tests. Treatment depends on the kind of <span class="qt0">anemia</span> you have.</p><p>NIH: National Heart, Lung, and Blood Institute</p>

Infection.name: HIV and <span class="qt0">Infections</span>
Infection.summary: <p>Having HIV/AIDS weakens your body's immune system. It destroys the white blood cells that fight <span class="qt0">infection</span>. This puts you at risk for opportunistic <span class="qt0">infections</span> (OIs). OIs are serious <span class="qt0">infections</span> that take advantage of your weak immune system. These <span class="qt0">infections</span> are less common and less severe in healthy people.</p><p>There are many types of OIs:</p><ul><li>Bacterial <span class="qt0">infections</span>, including tuberculosis and a serious related disease, Mycobacterium avium complex (MAC)</li><li>Viral <span class="qt0">infections</span>, such as cytomegalovirus (CMV) and hepatitis C</li><li>Fungal <span class="qt0">infections</span>, like yeast <span class="qt0">infections</span>, cryptococcal meningitis, pneumocystis carinii pneumonia (PCP) and histoplasmosis</li><li>Parasitic <span class="qt0">infections</span>, such as crypto (cryptosporidiosis) and toxo (toxoplasmosis)</li></ul><p>Having HIV/AIDS can make <span class="qt0">infections</span> harder to treat. People with HIV/AIDS are also more likely to have complications from common illnesses such as the flu.</p><p>You can help prevent <span class="qt0">infections</span> by taking your HIV/AIDS medicines. Other things that can help include practicing safe sex, washing your hands well and often, and cooking your food thoroughly.</p>

Myocardial infarction.name: <span class="qt2">Heart Attack</span>
Myocardial infarction.summary: <p>Each year almost 800,000 Americans have a <span class="qt2">heart attack. A heart attack</span> happens when blood flow to the heart suddenly becomes blocked. Without the blood coming in, the heart can't get oxygen. If not treated quickly, the heart muscle begins to die. But if you do get quick treatment, you may be able to prevent or limit damage to the heart muscle. That's why it's important to know the symptoms of a <span class="qt2">heart attack</span> and call 911 if you or someone else is having them. You should call, even if you are not sure that it is a <span class="qt2">heart attack</span>.</p><p>The most common symptoms in men and women are:</p><ul><li>Chest discomfort. It is often in center or left side of the chest. It usually lasts more than a few minutes. It may go away and come back. It can feel like pressure, squeezing, fullness, or pain. It also can feel like heartburn or indigestion.</li><li>Shortness of breath. Sometimes this is your only symptom. You may get it before or during the chest discomfort. It can happen when you are resting or doing a little bit of physical activity.</li><li>Discomfort in the upper body. You may feel pain or discomfort in one or both arms, the back, shoulders, neck, jaw, or upper part of the stomach.</li></ul><p>You may also have other symptoms, such as nausea, vomiting, dizziness, and lightheadedness. You may break out in a cold sweat. Sometimes women will have different symptoms then men. For example, they are more likely to feel tired for no reason.</p><p>The most common cause of <span class="qt2">heart attacks is coronary</span> artery disease (CAD). With CAD, there is a buildup of cholesterol and other material, called plaque, on their inner walls or the arteries. This is atherosclerosis. It can build up for years. Eventually an area of plaque can rupture (break open). A blood clot can form around the plaque and block the artery.</p><p>A less common cause of <span class="qt2">heart attack</span> is a severe spasm (tightening) of a coronary artery. The spasm cuts off blood flow through the artery.</p><p>At the hospital, health care providers make a diagnosis based on your symptoms, blood tests, and different heart health tests. Treatments may include medicines and medical procedures such as coronary angioplasty. After a <span class="qt2">heart attack, cardiac</span> rehabilitation and lifestyle changes can help you recover.</p><p>NIH: National Heart, Lung, and Blood Institute</p>

Infection urinary tract.summary: <p>The <span class="qt1">urinary</span> system is the body's drainage system for removing wastes and extra water. It includes two kidneys, two ureters, a bladder, and a urethra. <span class="qt1"><span class="qt3">Urinary</span></span><span class="qt3"> </span><span class="qt2"><span class="qt3">tract</span></span><span class="qt3"> </span><span class="qt0"><span class="qt3">infections</span></span> (UTIs) are the second most common type of <span class="qt0">infection</span> in the body.</p><p>You may have a UTI if you notice:</p><ul><li>Pain or burning when you urinate</li><li>Fever, tiredness, or shakiness</li><li>An urge to urinate often</li><li>Pressure in your lower belly </li><li><span class="qt1">Urine</span> that smells bad or looks cloudy or reddish</li><li>Pain in your back or side below the ribs</li></ul><p>People of any age or sex can get UTIs. But about four times as many women get UTIs as men. You're also at higher risk if you have diabetes, need a tube to drain your bladder, or have a spinal cord injury.</p><p>If you think you have a UTI it is important to see your doctor. Your doctor can tell if you have a UTI with a <span class="qt1">urine</span> test.  Treatment is with antibiotics. </p><p>NIH: National Institute of Diabetes and Digestive and Kidney Diseases</p>

Insufficiency renal.name: Chronic <span class="qt1">Kidney</span> Disease
Insufficiency renal.summary: <p>You have two <span class="qt1">kidneys</span>, each about the size of your fist.  Their main job is to filter your blood. They remove wastes and extra water, which become urine. They also keep the body's chemicals balanced, help control blood pressure, and make hormones.</p><p>Chronic <span class="qt1">kidney</span> disease (CKD) means that your <span class="qt1">kidneys</span> are damaged and can't filter blood as they should. This damage can cause wastes to build up in your body. It can also cause other problems that can harm your health. Diabetes and high blood pressure are the most common causes of CKD.</p><p>The <span class="qt1">kidney</span> damage occurs slowly over many years. Many people don't have any symptoms until their <span class="qt1">kidney</span> disease is very advanced. Blood and urine tests are the only way to know if you have <span class="qt1">kidney</span> disease.</p><p>Treatments cannot cure <span class="qt1">kidney</span> disease, but they may slow <span class="qt1">kidney</span> disease. They include medicines to lower blood pressure, control blood sugar, and lower cholesterol. CKD may still get worse over time. Sometimes it can lead to <span class="qt1">kidney</span> failure. If your <span class="qt1">kidneys</span> fail, you will need  dialysis or a <span class="qt1">kidney</span> transplantation.</p><p>You can take steps to keep your <span class="qt1">kidneys</span> healthier longer:</p><ul><li>Choose foods with less  salt (sodium)</li><li>Control your blood pressure; your health care provider can tell you what your blood pressure should be</li><li>Keep your blood sugar in the target range, if you have diabetes</li><li>Limit the amount of alcohol you drink</li><li>Choose foods that are healthy for your heart: fruits, vegetables, whole grains, and low-fat dairy foods</li><li>Lose weight if you are overweight</li><li>Be physically active</li><li>Don't smoke</li></ul><p>NIH: National Institute of Diabetes and Digestive and <span class="qt1">Kidney</span> Diseases</p>

Degenerative polyarthritis.name: <span class="qt1">Osteoarthritis</span>
Degenerative polyarthritis.summary: What is <span class="qt1">osteoarthritis</span>?<p><span class="qt1">Osteoarthritis</span>, sometimes called OA, is a type of arthritis that only affects the joints, usually in the hands, knees, hips, neck, and lower back. It's the most common type of arthritis.</p><p>In a healthy joint, the ends of the bones are covered with a smooth, slippery tissue called cartilage. The cartilage pads the bones and helps them glide easily when you move the joint. With <span class="qt1">osteoarthritis</span>, the cartilage breaks down and becomes rough. Sometimes, all the cartilage wears away and the bones rub together. Bumps of extra bone called bone spurs may grow in the joint area.</p><p>There is no cure for <span class="qt1">osteoarthritis</span>. It usually gets worse slowly. But there's a lot you can do to manage the symptoms.</p>What are the symptoms of <span class="qt1">osteoarthritis</span>?<p><span class="qt1">Osteoarthritis</span> affects people in different ways, and not everyone has pain. The most common symptoms are:</p><ul><li>Pain when you move, which often gets better with rest</li><li>Stiffness, especially for the first 30 minutes after you get up from resting</li><li>Swollen joints, especially after using the joint a lot</li><li>Less movement in the joint than normal</li><li>A joint that feels loose or unstable</li></ul>What causes <span class="qt1">osteoarthritis</span>?<p>Researchers aren't sure what causes <span class="qt1">osteoarthritis</span>. They think that it could be caused by a combination of factors in the body and the environment. Your chance of developing <span class="qt1">osteoarthritis</span> increases with age. They also know that some people are more likely to develop it than others.</p>Who is more likely to develop <span class="qt1">osteoarthritis</span>?<p>Things that make you more likely to develop <span class="qt1">osteoarthritis</span> include:</p><ul><li>Aging. <span class="qt1">Osteoarthritis</span> can happen at any age, but the chance of getting it increases in middle-aged adults and older. After age 50, it is more common in women than in men.</li><li>Being overweight. Extra weight puts more stress on your joints.</li><li>Having a past injury or surgery on a joint. This is often the cause of <span class="qt1">osteoarthritis</span> in younger adults.</li><li>Doing a lot of activities that overuse the joint. This includes sports with a lot of jumping, twisting, running, or throwing.</li><li>Having a joint that doesn't line up correctly.</li><li>A family history of <span class="qt1">osteoarthritis</span>. Some people inherit genetic changes that increase their chance of developing <span class="qt1">osteoarthritis</span>.</li></ul>How is <span class="qt1">osteoarthritis</span> diagnosed?<p>There is no specific test for <span class="qt1">osteoarthritis</span>. To find out if you have <span class="qt1">osteoarthritis</span>, your provider:</p><ul><li>Will ask about your symptoms and medical history</li><li>Will do a physical exam</li><li>May use x-rays or other imaging tests to look at your joints</li><li>May order lab tests to make sure that a different problem isn't causing your symptoms</li></ul>What are the treatments for <span class="qt1">osteoarthritis</span>?<p>The goal of treating <span class="qt1">osteoarthritis</span> is to ease your pain, help you move better, and stop it from getting worse.</p><p>Treatment usually begins with:</p><ul><li>Exercises to improve strength, flexibility and balance</li><li>Weight loss, if needed, to improve pain, especially in your hips or knees</li><li>Braces or shoe inserts (orthotics) that a health care provider fits for you</li></ul><p>You can buy some pain relievers and arthritis creams without a prescription. They can be helpful, but it's best to talk to your provider about using them. If they don't help enough, your provider may prescribe injections (shots) into the joint or prescription pain relievers.</p><p>Complementary therapies may help some people. Massage can increase blood flow and bring warmth to the area. Some research shows that acupuncture may help relieve <span class="qt1">osteoarthritis</span> pain. Simple things like heat and ice can help, too.</p><p>If none of these treatments help enough, surgery may be an option. You and your provider can decide if it's right for you.</p><p>NIH: National Institute of Arthritis and Musculoskeletal and Skin Diseases</p>

Anxiety state.name: <span class="qt0">Anxiety</span>
Anxiety state.summary: What is <span class="qt0">anxiety</span>?<p><span class="qt0">Anxiety</span> is a feeling of fear, dread, and uneasiness. It might cause you to sweat, feel restless and <span class="qt0">tense</span>, and have a rapid heartbeat.   It can be a normal reaction to <span class="qt0">stress</span>. For example, you might feel <span class="qt0">anxious</span> when faced with a difficult problem at work, before taking a test, or before making an important decision. It can help you to cope. The <span class="qt0">anxiety</span> may give you a boost of energy or help you focus. But for people with <span class="qt0"><span class="qt2">anxiety</span></span><span class="qt2"> disorders</span>, the fear is not temporary and can be overwhelming.</p>What are <span class="qt0"><span class="qt2">anxiety</span></span><span class="qt2"> disorders</span>?<p><span class="qt0"><span class="qt2">Anxiety</span></span><span class="qt2"> disorders</span> are conditions in which you have <span class="qt0">anxiety</span> that does not go away and can get worse over time. The symptoms can interfere with daily activities such as job performance, schoolwork, and relationships.</p>What are the types of <span class="qt0"><span class="qt2">anxiety</span></span><span class="qt2"> disorders</span>?<p>There are several types of <span class="qt0"><span class="qt2">anxiety</span></span><span class="qt2"> disorders</span>, including:</p><ul><li>Generalized <span class="qt0"><span class="qt2">anxiety</span></span><span class="qt2"> disorder</span> (GAD).People with GAD worry about ordinary issues such as health, money, work, and family. But their worries are excessive, and they have them almost every day for at least 6 months.</li><li>Panic disorder. People with panic disorder have panic attacks. These are sudden, repeated periods of intense fear when there is no danger. The attacks come on quickly and can last several minutes or more.</li><li>Phobias. People with phobias have an intense fear of something that poses little or no actual danger. Their fear may be about spiders, flying, going to crowded places, or being in social situations (known as social <span class="qt0">anxiety</span>).</li></ul>What causes <span class="qt0"><span class="qt2">anxiety</span></span><span class="qt2"> disorders</span>?<p>The cause of <span class="qt0">anxiety</span> is unknown. Factors such as genetics, brain biology and chemistry, <span class="qt0">stress</span>, and your environment may play a role.</p>Who is at risk for <span class="qt0"><span class="qt2">anxiety</span></span><span class="qt2"> disorders</span>?<p>The risk factors for the different types of <span class="qt0"><span class="qt2">anxiety</span></span><span class="qt2"> disorders</span> can vary. For example, GAD and phobias are more common in women, but social <span class="qt0">anxiety</span> affects men and women equally. There are some general risk factors for all types of <span class="qt0"><span class="qt2">anxiety</span></span><span class="qt2"> disorders</span>, including:</p><ul><li>Certain personality traits, such as being shy or withdrawn when you are in new situations or meeting new people</li><li>Traumatic events in early childhood or adulthood</li><li>Family history of <span class="qt0">anxiety</span> or other mental disorders</li><li>Some physical health conditions, such as thyroid problems or arrhythmia</li></ul>What are the symptoms of <span class="qt0"><span class="qt2">anxiety</span></span><span class="qt2"> disorders</span>?<p>The different types of <span class="qt0"><span class="qt2">anxiety</span></span><span class="qt2"> disorders</span> can have different symptoms. But they all have a combination of:</p><ul><li><span class="qt0">Anxious</span> thoughts or beliefs that are hard to control. They make you feel restless and <span class="qt0">tense</span> and interfere with your daily life. They do not go away and can get worse over time.</li><li>Physical symptoms, such as a pounding or rapid heartbeat, unexplained aches and pains, dizziness, and shortness of breath</li><li>Changes in behavior, such as avoiding everyday activities you used to do</li></ul><p>Using caffeine, other substances, and certain medicines can make your symptoms worse.</p>How are <span class="qt0"><span class="qt2">anxiety</span></span><span class="qt2"> disorders</span> diagnosed?<p>To diagnose <span class="qt0"><span class="qt2">anxiety</span></span><span class="qt2"> disorders</span>, your health care provider will ask about your symptoms and medical history. You may also have a physical exam and lab tests to make sure that a different health problem is not the cause of your symptoms.</p><p>If you don't have another health problem, you will get a psychological evaluation. Your provider may do it, or you may be referred to a mental health professional to get one.</p>What are the treatments for <span class="qt0"><span class="qt2">anxiety</span></span><span class="qt2"> disorders</span>?<p>The main treatments for <span class="qt0"><span class="qt2">anxiety</span></span><span class="qt2"> disorders</span> are psychotherapy (talk therapy), medicines, or both:</p><ul><li>Cognitive behavioral therapy (CBT) is a type of psychotherapy that is often used to treat <span class="qt0"><span class="qt2">anxiety</span></span><span class="qt2"> disorders</span>. CBT teaches you different ways of thinking and behaving. It can help you change how you react to the things that cause you to feel fear and <span class="qt0">anxiety</span>. It may include exposure therapy. This focuses on having you confront your fears so that you will be able to do the things that you had been avoiding.</li><li>Medicines to treat <span class="qt0"><span class="qt2">anxiety</span></span><span class="qt2"> disorders</span> include anti-<span class="qt0">anxiety</span> medicines and certain antidepressants. Some types of medicines may work better for specific types of <span class="qt0"><span class="qt2">anxiety</span></span><span class="qt2"> disorders</span>. You should work closely with your health care provider to identify which medicine is best for you. You may need to try more than one medicine before you can find the right one.</li></ul><p>NIH: National Institute of Mental Health</p>

Hypothyroidism.name: <span class="qt0">Hypothyroidism</span>
Hypothyroidism.summary:
What is <span class="qt0">hypothyroidism</span>?<p><span class="qt0">Hypothyroidism</span>, or underactive thyroid, happens when your thyroid gland doesn't make enough thyroid hormones to meet your body's needs.</p><p>Your thyroid is a small, butterfly-shaped gland in the front of your neck. It makes hormones that control the way the body uses energy. These hormones affect nearly every organ in your body and control many of your body's most important functions. For example, they affect your breathing, heart rate, weight, digestion, and moods. Without enough thyroid hormones, many of your body's functions slow down. But there are treatments that can help.</p>What causes <span class="qt0">hypothyroidism</span>?<p><span class="qt0">Hypothyroidism</span> has several causes. They include:</p><ul><li>Hashimoto's disease, an autoimmune disorder where your immune system attacks your thyroid. This is the most common cause.</li><li>Thyroiditis, inflammation of the thyroid</li><li>Congenital <span class="qt0">hypothyroidism, hypothyroidism</span> that is present at birth</li><li>Surgical removal of part or all of the thyroid</li><li>Radiation treatment of the thyroid</li><li>Certain medicines</li><li>In rare cases, a pituitary disease or too much or too little iodine in your diet</li></ul>Who is at risk for <span class="qt0">hypothyroidism</span>?<p>You are at higher risk for <span class="qt0">hypothyroidism</span> if you:</p><ul><li>Are a woman</li><li>Are older than age 60</li><li>Have had a thyroid problem before, such as a goiter</li><li>Have had surgery to correct a thyroid problem</li><li>Have received radiation treatment to the thyroid, neck, or chest</li><li>Have a family history of thyroid disease</li><li>Were pregnant or had a baby in the past 6 months</li><li>Have Turner syndrome, a genetic disorder that affects females</li><li>Have pernicious anemia, in which the body cannot make enough healthy red blood cells because it does not have enough vitamin B12</li><li>Have Sjogren's syndrome, a disease that causes dry eyes and mouth</li><li>Have type 1 diabetes</li><li>Have rheumatoid arthritis, an autoimmune disease that affects the joints</li><li>Have lupus, a chronic autoimmune disease</li></ul>What are the symptoms of <span class="qt0">hypothyroidism</span>?<p>The symptoms of <span class="qt0">hypothyroidism</span> can vary from person to person and may include:</p><ul><li>Fatigue</li><li>Weight gain</li><li>A puffy face</li><li>Trouble tolerating cold</li><li>Joint and muscle pain</li><li>Constipation</li><li>Dry skin</li><li>Dry, thinning hair</li><li>Decreased sweating</li><li>Heavy or irregular menstrual periods</li><li>Fertility problems in women</li><li>Depression</li><li>Slowed heart rate</li><li>Goiter, an enlarged thyroid that may cause your neck to look swollen. Sometimes it can cause trouble with breathing or swallowing.</li></ul><p>Because <span class="qt0">hypothyroidism</span> develops slowly, many people don't notice symptoms of the disease for months or even years.</p>What other problems can <span class="qt0">hypothyroidism</span> cause?<p><span class="qt0">Hypothyroidism</span> can contribute to high cholesterol. In rare cases, untreated <span class="qt0">hypothyroidism</span> can cause myxedema coma. This is a condition in which your body's functions slow down to the point that it becomes life-threatening.</p><p>During pregnancy, <span class="qt0">hypothyroidism</span> can cause complications, such as premature birth, high blood pressure in pregnancy, and miscarriage. It can also slow the baby's growth and development.</p>How is <span class="qt0">hypothyroidism</span> diagnosed?<p>Your health care provider may use many tools to make a diagnosis:</p><ul><li>A medical history, including asking about your symptoms</li><li>A physical exam</li><li>Thyroid tests, such as
		<ul><li>TSH, T3, T4, and thyroid antibody  blood tests</li><li>Imaging tests, such as a thyroid scan, ultrasound, or radioactive iodine uptake test. A radioactive iodine uptake test measures how much radioactive iodine your thyroid takes up from your blood after you swallow a small amount of it.</li></ul></li></ul>What are the treatments for <span class="qt0">hypothyroidism</span>?<p>The treatment for <span class="qt0">hypothyroidism</span> is medicine to replace the hormone that your own thyroid can no longer make. About 6 to 8 weeks after you start taking the medicine, you will get a blood test to check your thyroid hormone level. Your health care provider will adjust your dose if needed. Each time your dose is adjusted, you'll have another blood test. Once you find the right dose, you will probably get a blood test in 6 months. After that, you will need the test once a year.</p><p>If you take your medicine according to the instructions, you usually should be able to control the <span class="qt0">hypothyroidism</span>. You should never stop taking your medicine without talking with your health care provider first.</p><p>If you have Hashimoto's disease or other types of autoimmune thyroid disorders, you may be sensitive to harmful side effects from iodine. Talk to your health care provider about which foods, supplements, and medicines you need to avoid.</p><p>Women need more iodine when they are pregnant because the baby gets iodine from the mother's diet. If you are pregnant, talk with your health care provider about how much iodine you need.</p><p>NIH: National Institute of Diabetes and Digestive and Kidney Diseases</p>

Confusion.name: Traumatic Brain Injury

Malignant neoplasms.name: <span class="qt1"><span class="qt2">Cancer</span></span>
Malignant neoplasms.summary: <p><span class="qt1"><span class="qt2">Cancer</span></span> begins in your cells, which are the building blocks of your body.   Normally, your body forms new cells as you need them, replacing old cells that die. Sometimes this process goes wrong. New cells grow even when you don't need them, and old cells don't die when they should. These extra cells can form a mass called a <span class="qt1"><span class="qt2">tumor. Tumors</span></span> can be benign or <span class="qt0">malignant</span>. Benign <span class="qt1"><span class="qt2">tumors</span></span> aren't <span class="qt1"><span class="qt2">cancer</span></span> while <span class="qt0">malignant</span> ones are. Cells from <span class="qt0">malignant</span> <span class="qt1"><span class="qt2">tumors</span></span> can invade nearby tissues. They can also break away and spread to other parts of the body. </p><p><span class="qt1"><span class="qt2">Cancer</span></span> is not just one disease but many diseases. There are more than 100 different types of <span class="qt1"><span class="qt2">cancer</span></span>. Most <span class="qt1"><span class="qt2">cancers</span></span> are named for where they start. For example, lung <span class="qt1"><span class="qt2">cancer</span></span> starts in the lung, and breast <span class="qt1"><span class="qt2">cancer</span></span> starts in the breast. The spread of <span class="qt1"><span class="qt2">cancer</span></span> from one part of the body to another is called metastasis. Symptoms and treatment depend on the <span class="qt1"><span class="qt2">cancer</span></span> type and how advanced it is. Most treatment plans may include surgery, radiation and/or chemotherapy. Some may involve hormone therapy, immunotherapy or other types of biologic therapy, or stem cell transplantation. </p><p>NIH: National <span class="qt1"><span class="qt2">Cancer</span></span> Institute</p>

Primary malignant neoplasm.name: Bone Marrow Diseases
Primary malignant neoplasm.summary: <p>Bone marrow is the spongy tissue inside some of your bones, such as your hip and thigh bones. It contains stem cells. The stem cells can develop into the red blood cells that carry oxygen through your body, the white blood cells that fight infections, and the platelets that help with blood clotting.</p><p>With bone marrow disease, there are problems with the stem cells or how they develop:</p><ul><li>In leukemia, a <span class="qt2"><span class="qt3">cancer</span></span> of the blood, the bone marrow makes abnormal white blood cells</li><li>In aplastic anemia, the bone marrow doesn't make red blood cells</li><li>In myeloproliferative disorders, the bone marrow makes too many white blood cells</li><li>Other diseases, such as <span class="qt2"><span class="qt3">lymphoma</span></span>, can spread into the bone marrow and affect the production of blood cells</li></ul><p>Causes of bone marrow diseases include genetics and environmental factors. Tests for bone marrow diseases include blood and bone marrow tests. Treatments depend on the disorder and how severe it is. They might involve medicines, blood transfusions or a bone marrow transplant.</p>

Hiv.name: <span class="qt0">HIV</span>

Acquired immuno-deficiency syndrome.name: HIV

Cellulitis.name: <span class="qt0">Cellulitis</span>
Cellulitis.summary: <p><span class="qt0">Cellulitis</span> is an infection of the skin and deep underlying tissues. Group A strep (streptococcal) bacteria are the most common cause.  The bacteria enter your body when you get an injury such as a bruise, burn, surgical cut, or wound.</p><p>Symptoms include:</p><ul><li>Fever and chills</li><li>Swollen glands or lymph nodes</li><li>A rash with painful, red, tender skin. The skin may blister and scab over.</li></ul><p>Your health care provider may take a sample or culture from your skin or do a blood test to identify the bacteria causing infection. Treatment is with antibiotics. They may be oral in mild cases, or intravenous (by IV) for more severe cases.</p>

Gastroesophageal reflux disease.name: <span class="qt4">GERD</span>
Gastroesophageal reflux disease.summary: <p>Your esophagus is the tube that carries food from your mouth to your stomach. <span class="qt0"><span class="qt3">Gastroesophageal</span></span><span class="qt3"> </span><span class="qt1"><span class="qt3">reflux</span></span> <span class="qt2">disease</span> (<span class="qt4">GERD</span>) happens when a muscle at the end of your esophagus does not close properly. This allows stomach contents to leak back, or <span class="qt1">reflux</span>, into the esophagus and irritate it. </p><p>You may feel a burning in the chest or throat called heartburn.  Sometimes, you can taste stomach fluid in the back of the mouth.  If you have these symptoms more than twice a week, you may have <span class="qt4">GERD</span>. You can also have <span class="qt4">GERD</span> without having heartburn. Your symptoms could include a dry cough, asthma symptoms, or trouble swallowing.</p><p>Anyone, including infants and children, can have <span class="qt4">GERD</span>.  If not treated, it can lead to more serious health problems. In some cases, you might need medicines or surgery.  However, many people can improve their symptoms by:</p><ul><li>Avoiding alcohol and spicy, fatty or acidic foods that trigger heartburn</li><li>Eating smaller meals</li><li>Not eating close to bedtime </li><li>Losing weight if needed </li><li>Wearing loose-fitting clothes</li></ul><p>NIH: National Institute of Diabetes and Digestive and Kidney <span class="qt2">Diseases</span></p>

Hiv infections.name: <span class="qt0">HIV</span>

Septicemia.name: <span class="qt1">Sepsis</span>
Septicemia.summary: What is <span class="qt1">sepsis</span>?<p><span class="qt1">Sepsis</span> is your body's overactive and extreme response to an infection. <span class="qt1">Sepsis</span> is a life-threatening medical emergency. Without quick treatment, it can lead to tissue damage, organ failure, and even death.</p>What causes <span class="qt1">sepsis</span>?<p><span class="qt1">Sepsis</span> happens when an infection you already have triggers a chain reaction throughout your body. Bacterial infections are the most common cause, but other types of infections can also cause it.</p><p>The infections are often in the lungs, stomach, kidneys, or bladder. It's possible for <span class="qt1">sepsis</span> to begin with a small cut that gets infected or with an infection that develops after surgery. Sometimes, <span class="qt1">sepsis</span> can occur in people who didn't even know that they had an infection.</p>Who is at risk for <span class="qt1">sepsis</span>?<p>Anyone with an infection could get <span class="qt1">sepsis</span>. But certain people are at higher risk:</p><ul><li>Adults 65 or older</li><li>People with chronic conditions, such as diabetes, lung disease, cancer, and kidney disease</li><li>People with weakened immune systems</li><li>Pregnant women</li><li>Children younger than one</li></ul>What are the symptoms of <span class="qt1">sepsis</span>?<p><span class="qt1">Sepsis</span> can cause one or more of these symptoms:</p><ul><li>Rapid breathing and heart rate</li><li>Shortness of breath</li><li>Confusion or disorientation</li><li>Extreme pain or discomfort</li><li>Fever, shivering, or feeling very cold</li><li>Clammy or sweaty skin</li></ul><p>It's important to get medical care right away if you think you might have <span class="qt1">sepsis</span> or if your infection is not getting better or is getting worse.</p>What other problems can <span class="qt1">sepsis</span> cause?<p>Severe cases of <span class="qt1">sepsis</span> can lead to septic shock, where your blood pressure drops to a dangerous level and multiple organs can fail.</p>How is <span class="qt1">sepsis</span> diagnosed?<p>Your health care provider may use many tools to make a diagnosis:</p><ul><li>A medical history, which includes asking about your symptoms </li><li>A physical exam, including checking vital signs (your temperature, blood pressure, heart rate, and breathing)</li><li>Lab tests that check for signs of infection or organ damage</li><li>Imaging tests such as an x-ray or a CT scan to find the location of the infection</li></ul><p>Many of the signs and symptoms of <span class="qt1">sepsis</span> can also be caused by other medical conditions. This may make <span class="qt1">sepsis</span> hard to diagnose in its early stages.</p>What are the treatments for <span class="qt1">sepsis</span>?<p>It is very important to get treatment right away. Treatment usually includes:</p><ul><li>Antibiotics</li><li>Maintaining blood flow to organs. This may involve getting oxygen and intravenous (IV) fluids.</li><li>Treating the source of the infection</li><li>If needed, medicines to increase blood pressure</li></ul><p>In serious cases, you might need kidney dialysis or a breathing tube. Some people need surgery to remove tissue damaged by the infection.</p>Can <span class="qt1">sepsis</span> be prevented?<p>To prevent <span class="qt1">sepsis</span>, you should try to prevent getting an infection:</p><ul><li>Take good care of any chronic health conditions that you have</li><li>Get recommended vaccines</li><li>Practice good hygiene, such as handwashing</li><li>Keep cuts clean and covered until healed</li></ul><p>NIH: National Institute of General Medical SciencesCenters for Disease Control and Prevention</p>

Deep vein thrombosis.name: <span class="qt0">Deep</span> <span class="qt1">Vein</span> <span class="qt2">Thrombosis</span>
Deep vein thrombosis.summary: <p><span class="qt0">Deep</span> <span class="qt1">vein</span> <span class="qt2">thrombosis</span>, or DVT, is a blood clot that forms in a <span class="qt1">vein</span> <span class="qt0">deep</span> in the body. Most <span class="qt0">deep</span> <span class="qt1">vein</span> clots occur in the lower leg or thigh. If the <span class="qt1">vein</span> swells, the condition is called thrombophlebitis. A <span class="qt0">deep</span> <span class="qt1">vein</span> <span class="qt2">thrombosis</span> can break loose and cause a serious problem in the lung,  called a pulmonary embolism.</p><p>Sitting still for a long time can make you more likely to get a DVT. Some medicines and disorders that increase your risk for blood clots can also lead to DVTs. Common symptoms are :</p><ul><li> Warmth and tenderness over the <span class="qt1">vein</span> </li><li> Pain or swelling in the part of the body affected </li><li> Skin redness </li></ul><p>Treatment includes medicines to ease pain and inflammation, break up clots and keep new clots from forming. Keeping the affected area raised and applying moist heat can also help. If you are taking a long car or plane trip, take a break, walk or stretch your legs and drink plenty of liquids.</p>

Dehydration.name: <span class="qt0">Dehydration</span>
Dehydration.summary: What is <span class="qt0">dehydration</span>?<p><span class="qt0">Dehydration</span> is a condition caused by the loss of too much fluid from the body.  It happens when you are losing more fluids than you are taking in, and your body does not have enough fluids to work properly.</p>What causes <span class="qt0">dehydration</span>?<p>You can become dehydrated because of:</p><ul><li>Diarrhea</li><li>Vomiting</li><li>Sweating too much</li><li>Urinating too much, which can happen because of certain medicines and illnesses</li><li>Fever</li><li>Not drinking enough</li></ul>Who is at risk for <span class="qt0">dehydration</span>?<p>Certain people have a higher risk of <span class="qt0">dehydration</span>:</p><ul><li>Older adults. Some people lose their sense of thirst as they age, so they don't drink enough fluids.</li><li>Infants and young children, who are more likely to have diarrhea or vomiting</li><li>People with chronic illnesses that cause them to urinate or sweat more often, such as diabetes, cystic fibrosis, or kidney problems</li><li>People who take medicines that cause them to urinate or sweat more</li><li>People who exercise or work outdoors during hot weather</li></ul>What are the symptoms of <span class="qt0">dehydration</span>?<p>In adults, the symptoms of <span class="qt0">dehydration</span> include:</p><ul><li>Feeling very thirsty</li><li>Dry mouth</li><li>Urinating and sweating less than usual</li><li>Dark-colored urine</li><li>Dry skin</li><li>Feeling tired</li><li>Dizziness</li></ul><p>In infants and young children, the symptoms of <span class="qt0">dehydration</span> include:</p><ul><li>Dry mouth and tongue</li><li>Crying without tears</li><li>No wet diapers for 3 hours or more</li><li>A high fever</li><li>Being unusually sleepy or drowsy</li><li>Irritability</li><li>Eyes that look sunken</li></ul><p><span class="qt0">Dehydration</span> can be mild, or it can be severe enough to be life-threatening. Get medical help right away if the symptoms also include:</p><ul><li>Confusion</li><li>Fainting</li><li>Lack of urination</li><li>Rapid heartbeat</li><li>Rapid breathing</li><li>Shock</li></ul>How is <span class="qt0">dehydration</span> diagnosed?<p>To make a diagnosis, your health care provider will:</p><ul><li>Do a physical exam</li><li>Check your vital signs</li><li>Ask about your symptoms</li></ul><p>You may also have:</p><ul><li>Blood tests to check your electrolyte levels, especially potassium and sodium. Electrolytes are minerals in your body that have an electric charge. They have many important jobs, including helping to keep a balance of fluids in your body.</li><li>Blood tests to check your kidney function</li><li>Urine tests to check for <span class="qt0">dehydration</span> and its cause</li></ul>What are the treatments for <span class="qt0">dehydration</span>?<p>The treatment for <span class="qt0">dehydration</span> is to replace the fluids and electrolytes that you have lost. For mild cases, you may just need to drink lots of water. If you lost electrolytes, sports drinks may help. There are also oral rehydration solutions for children. You can buy those without a prescription.</p><p>Severe cases may be treated with intravenous (IV) fluids with salt in a hospital.</p>Can <span class="qt0">dehydration</span> be prevented?<p>The key to preventing <span class="qt0">dehydration</span> is making sure that you get enough fluids:</p><ul><li>Drink enough water every day. Each person's needs can be different, so ask your health care provider how much you should be drinking each day.</li><li>If you are exercising in the heat and losing a lot of minerals in sweat, sports drinks can be helpful</li><li>Avoid drinks that have sugar and caffeine</li><li>Drink extra fluids when the weather is hot or when you are sick</li></ul>

Systemic infection.name: <span class="qt2">Sepsis</span>
Systemic infection.summary: What is <span class="qt2">sepsis</span>?<p><span class="qt2">Sepsis</span> is your body's overactive and extreme response to an <span class="qt1">infection</span>. <span class="qt2">Sepsis</span> is a life-threatening medical emergency. Without quick treatment, it can lead to tissue damage, organ failure, and even death.</p>What causes <span class="qt2">sepsis</span>?<p><span class="qt2">Sepsis</span> happens when an <span class="qt1">infection</span> you already have triggers a chain reaction throughout your body. It's possible for <span class="qt2">sepsis</span> to begin with a small cut that gets infected or with an <span class="qt1">infection</span> that develops after surgery. This may make <span class="qt2">sepsis</span> hard to diagnose in its early stages.</p>What are the treatments for <span class="qt2">sepsis</span>?<p>It is very important to get treatment right away. Treatment usually includes:</p><ul><li>Antibiotics</li><li>Maintaining blood flow to organs. This may involve getting oxygen and intravenous (IV) fluids.</li><li>Treating the source of the <span class="qt1">infection</span></li><li>If needed, medicines to increase blood pressure</li></ul><p>In serious cases, you might need kidney dialysis or a breathing tube. Some people need surgery to remove tissue damaged by the <span class="qt1">infection</span>.</p>Can <span class="qt2">sepsis</span> be prevented?<p>To prevent <span class="qt2">sepsis</span>, you should try to prevent getting an <span class="qt1">infection</span>:</p><ul><li>Take good care of any chronic health conditions that you have</li><li>Get recommended vaccines</li><li>Practice good hygiene, such as handwashing</li><li>Keep cuts clean and covered until healed</li></ul><p>NIH: National Institute of General Medical SciencesCenters for Disease Control and Prevention</p>

Cardiomyopathy.name: <span class="qt0"><span class="qt1">Cardiomyopathy</span></span>
Cardiomyopathy.summary: <p><span class="qt0"><span class="qt1">Cardiomyopathy</span></span> is the name for diseases of the heart muscle. These diseases enlarge your heart muscle or make it thicker and more rigid than normal. In rare cases, scar tissue replaces the muscle tissue.</p><p>Some people live long, healthy lives with <span class="qt0"><span class="qt1">cardiomyopathy</span></span>. Some people don't even realize they have it. In others, however, it can make the heart less able to pump blood through the body. This can cause serious complications, including:</p><ul><li>Heart failure </li><li>Abnormal heart rhythms </li><li>Heart valve problems</li><li>Sudden cardiac arrest (SCA)</li></ul><p>Heart attacks, high blood pressure, infections, and other diseases can all cause <span class="qt0"><span class="qt1">cardiomyopathy</span></span>. Some types of <span class="qt0"><span class="qt1">cardiomyopathy</span></span> run in families. In many people, however, the cause is unknown. Treatment might involve medicines, surgery, other medical procedures, and lifestyle changes. </p><p>NIH: National Heart, Lung, and Blood Institute</p>

Embolism pulmonary.name: <span class="qt1"><span class="qt2">Pulmonary</span></span> <span class="qt0">Embolism</span>
Embolism pulmonary.summary:
What is a <span class="qt1"><span class="qt2">pulmonary</span></span> <span class="qt0">embolism</span> (PE)?<p>A <span class="qt1"><span class="qt2">pulmonary</span></span> <span class="qt0">embolism</span> (PE) is a sudden blockage in a <span class="qt1"><span class="qt2">lung</span></span> artery. It usually happens when a blood clot breaks loose and travels through the bloodstream to the <span class="qt1"><span class="qt2">lungs</span></span>. PE is a serious condition that can cause:</p><ul><li>Permanent damage to the <span class="qt1"><span class="qt2">lungs</span></span></li><li>Low oxygen levels in your blood</li><li>Damage to other organs in your body from not getting enough oxygen</li></ul><p>PE can be life-threatening, especially if a clot is large, or if there are many clots.</p>What causes a <span class="qt1"><span class="qt2">pulmonary</span></span> <span class="qt0">embolism</span> (PE)?<p>The cause is usually a blood clot in the leg called a deep vein thrombosis that breaks loose and travels through the bloodstream to the <span class="qt1"><span class="qt2">lungs</span></span>.</p>Who is at risk for a <span class="qt1"><span class="qt2">pulmonary</span></span> <span class="qt0">embolism</span> (PE)?<p>Anyone can get a <span class="qt1"><span class="qt2">pulmonary</span></span> <span class="qt0">embolism</span> (PE), but certain things can raise your risk of PE:</p><ul><li>Having surgery, especially joint replacement surgery</li><li>Certain medical conditions, including</li><ul><li>Cancers</li><li>Heart diseases</li><li><span class="qt1"><span class="qt2">Lung</span></span> diseases</li><li>A broken hip or leg bone or other trauma</li></ul><li>Hormone-based medicines, such as birth control pills or hormone replacement therapy</li><li>Pregnancy and childbirth. The risk is highest for about six weeks after childbirth.</li><li>Not moving for long periods, such as being on bed rest, having a cast, or taking a long plane flight
</li><li>Age. Your risk increases as you get older, especially after age 40.
</li><li>Family history and genetics. Certain genetic changes that can increase your risk of blood clots and PE.
</li><li>Obesity</li></ul>What are the symptoms of a <span class="qt1"><span class="qt2">pulmonary</span></span> <span class="qt0">embolism</span> (PE)?<p>Half the people who have <span class="qt1"><span class="qt2">pulmonary</span></span> <span class="qt0">embolism</span> have no symptoms. If you do have symptoms, they can include shortness of breath, chest pain or coughing up blood. Symptoms of a blood clot include warmth, swelling, pain, tenderness and redness of the leg.</p>How is a <span class="qt1"><span class="qt2">pulmonary</span></span> <span class="qt0">embolism</span> (PE) diagnosed?<p>It can be difficult to diagnose PE. To make a diagnosis, your health care provider will:</p><ul><li>Take your medical history, including asking about your symptoms and risk factors for PE</li><li>Do a physical exam</li><li>Run some tests, including various imaging tests and possibly some blood tests</li></ul>What are the treatments for a <span class="qt1"><span class="qt2">pulmonary</span></span> <span class="qt0">embolism</span> (PE)?<p>If you have PE, you need medical treatment right away. The goal of treatment is to break up clots and help keep other clots from forming. Treatment options include medicines and procedures.</p><p>Medicines:</p><ul><li>Anticoagulants, or blood thinners, keep blood clots from getting larger and stop new clots from forming. You might get them as an injection, a pill, or through an I.V. (intravenous). They can cause bleeding, especially if you are taking other medicines that also thin your blood, such as aspirin.</li><li>Thrombolytics are medicines to dissolve blood clots. You may get them if you have large clots that cause severe symptoms or other serious complications. Thrombolytics can cause sudden bleeding, so they are used if your PE is serious and may be life-threatening.</li></ul><p>Procedures:</p><ul><li>Catheter-assisted thrombus removal uses a flexible tube to reach a blood clot in your <span class="qt1"><span class="qt2">lung</span></span>. Your health care provider can insert a tool in the tube to break up the clot or to deliver medicine through the tube. Usually you will get medicine to put you to sleep for this procedure.</li><li>A vena cava filter may be used in some people who cannot take blood thinners. Your health care provider inserts a filter inside a large vein called the vena cava. The filter catches blood clots before they travel to the <span class="qt1"><span class="qt2">lungs</span></span>, which prevents <span class="qt1"><span class="qt2">pulmonary</span></span> <span class="qt0">embolism</span>. But the filter does not stop new blood clots from forming.</li></ul>Can <span class="qt1"><span class="qt2">pulmonary</span></span> <span class="qt0">embolism</span> (PE) be prevented?<p>Preventing new blood clots can prevent PE. Prevention may include:</p><ul><li>Continuing to take blood thinners. It's also important to get regular checkups with your provider, to make sure that the dosage of your medicines is working to prevent blood clots but not causing bleeding.</li><li>Heart-healthy lifestyle changes, such as heart-healthy eating, exercise, and, if you smoke, quitting smoking
</li>Using compression stockings to prevent deep vein thrombosis (DVT)
<li>Moving your legs when sitting for long periods of time (such as on long trips)</li><li>Moving around as soon as possible after surgery or being confined to a bed</li></ul><p>NIH: National Heart, <span class="qt1"><span class="qt2">Lung</span></span>, and Blood Institute</p>

Chronic kidney failure.name: <span class="qt1">Kidney</span> <span class="qt2">Failure</span>
Chronic kidney failure.summary: <p>Healthy <span class="qt1">kidneys</span> clean your blood by removing excess fluid, minerals, and wastes. They also make hormones that keep your bones strong and your blood healthy. But if the <span class="qt1">kidneys</span> are damaged, they <span class="qt2">don't work</span> properly. Harmful wastes can build up in your body. Your blood pressure may rise. Your body may retain excess fluid and not make enough red blood cells. This is called <span class="qt1">kidney</span> <span class="qt2">failure</span>.</p><p>If your <span class="qt1">kidneys</span> <span class="qt2">fail</span>, you need treatment to replace the work they normally do. The treatment options are dialysis or a <span class="qt1">kidney</span> transplant. Each treatment has benefits and drawbacks. No matter which treatment you choose, you'll need to make some changes in your life, including how you eat and plan your activities. But with the help of health care providers, family, and friends, most people with <span class="qt1">kidney</span> <span class="qt2">failure</span> can lead full and active lives.</p><p>NIH: National Institute of Diabetes and Digestive and <span class="qt1">Kidney</span> Diseases</p>

Neoplasm.name: <span class="qt0"><span class="qt1">Cancer</span></span>
Neoplasm.summary: <p><span class="qt0"><span class="qt1">Cancer</span></span> begins in your cells, which are the building blocks of your body.   Normally, your body forms new cells as you need them, replacing old cells that die. Sometimes this process goes wrong. New cells grow even when you don't need them, and old cells don't die when they should. These extra cells can form a mass called a <span class="qt0"><span class="qt1">tumor. Tumors</span></span> can be benign or malignant. Benign <span class="qt0"><span class="qt1">tumors</span></span> aren't <span class="qt0"><span class="qt1">cancer</span></span> while malignant ones are. Cells from malignant <span class="qt0"><span class="qt1">tumors</span></span> can invade nearby tissues. They can also break away and spread to other parts of the body. </p><p><span class="qt0"><span class="qt1">Cancer</span></span> is not just one disease but many diseases. There are more than 100 different types of <span class="qt0"><span class="qt1">cancer</span></span>. Most <span class="qt0"><span class="qt1">cancers</span></span> are named for where they start. For example, lung <span class="qt0"><span class="qt1">cancer</span></span> starts in the lung, and breast <span class="qt0"><span class="qt1">cancer</span></span> starts in the breast. The spread of <span class="qt0"><span class="qt1">cancer</span></span> from one part of the body to another is called metastasis. Symptoms and treatment depend on the <span class="qt0"><span class="qt1">cancer</span></span> type and how advanced it is. Most treatment plans may include surgery, radiation and/or chemotherapy. Some may involve hormone therapy, immunotherapy or other types of biologic therapy, or stem cell transplantation. </p><p>NIH: National <span class="qt0"><span class="qt1">Cancer</span></span> Institute</p>

Epilepsy.name: <span class="qt0">Epilepsy</span>
Epilepsy.summary: <p><span class="qt0">Epilepsy</span> is a brain disorder that causes people to have recurring seizures.  The seizures happen when clusters of nerve cells, or neurons, in the brain send out the wrong signals. People may have strange sensations and emotions or behave strangely. They may have violent muscle spasms or lose consciousness.</p><p><span class="qt0">Epilepsy</span> has many possible causes, including illness, brain injury, and abnormal brain development. In many cases, the cause is unknown.</p><p>Doctors use brain scans and other tests to diagnose <span class="qt0">epilepsy</span>. It is important to start treatment right away. There is no cure for <span class="qt0">epilepsy</span>, but medicines can control seizures for most people. When medicines are not working well, surgery or implanted devices such as vagus nerve stimulators may help. Special diets can help some children with <span class="qt0">epilepsy</span>.</p><p>NIH: National Institute of Neurological Disorders and Stroke</p>

Peripheral vascular disease.name: <span class="qt0">Peripheral</span> Arterial <span class="qt2">Disease</span>
Peripheral vascular disease.summary: <p><span class="qt0">Peripheral</span> arterial <span class="qt2">disease</span> (PAD) happens when there is a narrowing of the <span class="qt1">blood vessels</span> outside of your heart. The cause of PAD is atherosclerosis. This happens when plaque builds up on the walls of the arteries that supply blood to the arms and legs. Plaque is a substance made up of fat and cholesterol.
