It causes the arteries to narrow or become blocked. This can reduce or stop blood flow, usually to the legs. If severe enough, blocked blood flow can cause tissue death and can sometimes lead to amputation of the foot or leg.</p><p>The main risk factor for PAD is smoking. Other risk factors include older age and <span class="qt2">diseases</span> like diabetes, high blood cholesterol, high blood pressure, heart <span class="qt2">disease</span>, and stroke.</p><p>Many people who have PAD don't have any symptoms. If you have symptoms, they may include:</p><ul><li>Pain, numbness, achiness, or heaviness in the leg muscles. This happens when walking or climbing stairs.</li><li>Weak or absent pulses in the legs or feet</li><li>Sores or wounds on the toes, feet, or legs that heal slowly, poorly, or not at all</li><li>A pale or bluish color to the skin</li><li>A lower temperature in one leg than the other leg</li><li>Poor nail growth on the toes and decreased hair growth on the legs</li><li>Erectile dysfunction, especially among men who have diabetes</li></ul><p>PAD can increase your risk of heart attack, stroke, and transient ischemic attack.</p><p>Doctors diagnose PAD with a physical exam and heart and imaging tests. Treatments include lifestyle changes, medicines, and sometimes surgery. Lifestyle changes include dietary changes, exercise, and efforts to lower high cholesterol levels and high blood pressure.</p><p>NIH: National Heart, Lung, and Blood Institute</p>

Carcinoma.name: <span class="qt0"><span class="qt1">Cancer</span></span>
Carcinoma.summary: <p><span class="qt0"><span class="qt1">Cancer</span></span> begins in your cells, which are the building blocks of your body.   Normally, your body forms new cells as you need them, replacing old cells that die. Sometimes this process goes wrong. New cells grow even when you don't need them, and old cells don't die when they should. These extra cells can form a mass called a <span class="qt0"><span class="qt1">tumor. Tumors</span></span> can be benign or malignant. Benign <span class="qt0"><span class="qt1">tumors</span></span> aren't <span class="qt0"><span class="qt1">cancer</span></span> while malignant ones are. Cells from malignant <span class="qt0"><span class="qt1">tumors</span></span> can invade nearby tissues. They can also break away and spread to other parts of the body. </p><p><span class="qt0"><span class="qt1">Cancer</span></span> is not just one disease but many diseases. There are more than 100 different types of <span class="qt0"><span class="qt1">cancer</span></span>. Most <span class="qt0"><span class="qt1">cancers</span></span> are named for where they start. For example, lung <span class="qt0"><span class="qt1">cancer</span></span> starts in the lung, and breast <span class="qt0"><span class="qt1">cancer</span></span> starts in the breast. The spread of <span class="qt0"><span class="qt1">cancer</span></span> from one part of the body to another is called metastasis. Symptoms and treatment depend on the <span class="qt0"><span class="qt1">cancer</span></span> type and how advanced it is. Most treatment plans may include surgery, radiation and/or chemotherapy. Some may involve hormone therapy, immunotherapy or other types of biologic therapy, or stem cell transplantation. </p><p>NIH: National <span class="qt0"><span class="qt1">Cancer</span></span> Institute</p>

Hepatitis c.name: <span class="qt0">Hepatitis</span> <span class="qt1">C</span>
Hepatitis c.summary: What is <span class="qt0">hepatitis</span> <span class="qt1">C</span>?<p><span class="qt0">Hepatitis is inflammation of the liver. Inflammation</span> is swelling that happens when tissues of the body are injured or infected. Inflammation can damage organs.</p><p>There are different types of <span class="qt0">hepatitis</span>. One type, <span class="qt0">hepatitis</span> <span class="qt1">C</span>, is caused by the <span class="qt0">hepatitis</span> <span class="qt1">C</span> virus (HCV). <span class="qt0">Hepatitis</span> <span class="qt1">C</span> can range from a mild illness lasting a few weeks to a serious, lifelong illness.</p><p><span class="qt0">Hepatitis</span> <span class="qt1">C</span> can be acute or chronic:</p><ul><li>Acute <span class="qt0">hepatitis</span> <span class="qt1">C</span> is a short-term infection. The symptoms can last up to 6 months. Sometimes your body is able to fight off the infection and the virus goes away. But for most people, an acute infection leads to chronic infection.</li><li>Chronic <span class="qt0">hepatitis</span> <span class="qt1">C</span> is a long-lasting infection. If it is not treated, it can last for a lifetime and cause serious health problems, including liver damage, cirrhosis (scarring of the liver), liver cancer, and even death.</li></ul>How is <span class="qt0">hepatitis</span> <span class="qt1">C</span> spread?<p><span class="qt0">Hepatitis</span> <span class="qt1">C</span> spreads through contact with the blood of someone who has HCV. This contact may be through:</p><ul><li>Sharing drug needles or other drug materials with someone who has HCV. In the United States, this is the most common way that people get <span class="qt0">hepatitis</span> <span class="qt1">C</span>.</li><li>Getting an accidental stick with a needle that was used on someone who has HCV. This can happen in health care settings.</li><li>Being tattooed or pierced with tools or inks that were not sterilized after being used on someone who has HCV</li><li>Having contact with the blood or open sores of someone who has HCV</li><li>Sharing personal care items that may have come in contact with another person's blood, such as razors or toothbrushes</li><li>Being born to a mother with HCV</li><li>Having unprotected sex with someone who has HCV</li></ul><p>Before 1992, <span class="qt0">hepatitis</span> <span class="qt1">C</span> was also commonly spread through blood transfusions and organ transplants. Since then, there has been routine testing of the U.S. blood supply for HCV. It is now very rare for someone to get HCV this way.</p>Who is more likely to get <span class="qt0">hepatitis</span> <span class="qt1">C</span>?<p>You are more likely to get <span class="qt0">hepatitis</span> <span class="qt1">C</span> if you:</p><ul><li>Have injected drugs</li><li>Had a blood transfusion or organ transplant before July 1992</li><li>Have hemophilia and received clotting factor before 1987</li><li>Have been on kidney dialysis</li><li>Have been in contact with blood or infected needles at work</li><li>Have had tattoos or body piercings</li><li>Have worked or lived in a prison</li><li>Were born to a mother with <span class="qt0">hepatitis</span> <span class="qt1">C</span></li><li>Have HIV</li><li>Have had more than one sex partner in the last 6 months</li><li>Have had a sexually transmitted disease</li><li>Are a man who has had sex with men (MSM)</li></ul><p>If you are at high risk for <span class="qt0">hepatitis</span> <span class="qt1">C</span>, your health care provider will likely recommend that you get tested for it.</p>What are the symptoms of <span class="qt0">hepatitis</span> <span class="qt1">C</span>?<p>Most people with <span class="qt0">hepatitis</span> <span class="qt1">C</span> have no symptoms. Some people with acute <span class="qt0">hepatitis</span> <span class="qt1">C</span> do have symptoms within 1 to 3 months after they are exposed to the virus. These symptoms may include:</p><ul><li>Dark yellow urine</li><li>Fatigue</li><li>Fever</li><li>Gray- or clay-colored stools</li><li>Joint pain</li><li>Loss of appetite</li><li>Nausea and/or vomiting</li><li>Pain in your abdomen (belly)</li><li>Jaundice (yellowish eyes and skin)</li></ul><p>If you have chronic <span class="qt0">hepatitis</span> <span class="qt1">C</span>, you probably will not have symptoms until it causes complications. This can happen decades after you were infected. For this reason, <span class="qt0">hepatitis</span> <span class="qt1">C</span> screening is important, even if you have no symptoms.</p>What other problems can <span class="qt0">hepatitis</span> <span class="qt1">C</span> cause?<p>Without treatment, <span class="qt0">hepatitis</span> <span class="qt1">C</span> may lead to cirrhosis, liver failure, and liver cancer. Early diagnosis and treatment of <span class="qt0">hepatitis</span> <span class="qt1">C</span> can prevent these complications.</p>How is <span class="qt0">hepatitis</span> <span class="qt1">C</span> diagnosed?<p>Providers diagnose <span class="qt0">hepatitis</span> <span class="qt1">C</span> based on your medical history, a physical exam, and blood tests.</p><p>If you do have <span class="qt0">hepatitis</span> <span class="qt1">C</span>, you may need additional tests to check for liver damage. These tests may include other blood tests, an ultrasound of the liver, and a liver biopsy.</p>What are the treatments for <span class="qt0">hepatitis</span> <span class="qt1">C</span>?<p>Treatment for <span class="qt0">hepatitis</span> <span class="qt1">C</span> is with antiviral medicines. They can cure the disease in most cases.</p><p>If you have acute <span class="qt0">hepatitis</span> <span class="qt1">C</span>, your provider may wait to see if your infection becomes chronic before starting treatment.</p><p>If your <span class="qt0">hepatitis</span> <span class="qt1">C</span> causes cirrhosis, you should see a doctor who specializes in liver diseases. Treatments for health problems related to cirrhosis include medicines, surgery, and other medical procedures. If your <span class="qt0">hepatitis</span> <span class="qt1">C</span> leads to liver failure or liver cancer, you may need a liver transplant.</p>Can <span class="qt0">hepatitis</span> <span class="qt1">C</span> be prevented?<p>There is no vaccine for <span class="qt0">hepatitis</span> <span class="qt1">C</span>. But you can help protect yourself from <span class="qt0">hepatitis</span> <span class="qt1">C</span> infection by:</p><ul><li>Not sharing drug needles or other drug materials.</li><li>Wearing gloves if you have to touch another person's blood or open sores.</li><li>Making sure your tattoo artist or body piercer uses sterile tools and unopened ink.</li><li>Not sharing personal items such toothbrushes, razors, or nail clippers.</li><li>Using a latex condom during sex. If your or your partner is allergic to latex, you can use polyurethane condoms.</li></ul><p>NIH: National Institute of Diabetes and Digestive and Kidney Diseases</p>

Bipolar disorder.name: <span class="qt0">Bipolar</span> <span class="qt1">Disorder</span>

Psychotic disorder.name: <span class="qt0"><span class="qt2">Psychotic</span></span><span class="qt2"> </span><span class="qt1"><span class="qt2">Disorders</span></span>
Psychotic disorder.summary: <p><span class="qt0"><span class="qt2">Psychotic</span></span><span class="qt2"> </span><span class="qt1"><span class="qt2">disorders</span></span> are severe mental <span class="qt1">disorders</span> that cause abnormal thinking and perceptions. People with psychoses lose touch with reality. Two of the main symptoms are delusions and hallucinations. Delusions are false beliefs, such as thinking that someone is plotting against you or that the TV is sending you secret messages. Hallucinations are false perceptions, such as hearing, seeing, or feeling something that is not there.</p><p>Schizophrenia is one type of <span class="qt0"><span class="qt2">psychotic</span></span><span class="qt2"> </span><span class="qt1"><span class="qt2">disorder</span></span>. People with bipolar <span class="qt1">disorder</span> may also have <span class="qt0">psychotic</span> symptoms. Other problems that can cause <span class="qt0">psychosis</span> include alcohol and some drugs, brain tumors, brain infections, and stroke.</p><p>Treatment depends on the cause of the <span class="qt0">psychosis</span>. It might involve drugs to control symptoms and talk therapy. Hospitalization is an option for serious cases where a person might be dangerous to himself or others.</p>

Hyperlipidemia.name: <span class="qt1">Cholesterol</span>
Hyperlipidemia.summary: What is <span class="qt1">cholesterol</span>?<p><span class="qt1">Cholesterol</span> is a waxy, fat-like substance that's found in all the cells in your body. Your body needs some <span class="qt1">cholesterol</span> to make hormones, vitamin D, and substances that help you digest foods. Your body makes all the <span class="qt1">cholesterol</span> it needs. <span class="qt1">Cholesterol</span> is also found in foods from animal sources, such as egg yolks, meat, and cheese.</p><p>If you have too much <span class="qt1">cholesterol</span> in your blood, it can combine with other substances in the blood to form plaque. Plaque sticks to the walls of your arteries. This buildup of plaque is known as atherosclerosis. It can lead to coronary artery disease, where your coronary arteries become narrow or even blocked.</p>What are HDL, LDL, and VLDL?<p>HDL, LDL, and VLDL are lipoproteins. They are a combination of fat (lipid) and protein. The lipids need to be attached to the proteins so they can move through the blood. Different types of lipoproteins have different purposes:</p><ul><li>HDL stands for high-density lipoprotein. It is sometimes called "good" <span class="qt1">cholesterol</span> because it carries <span class="qt1">cholesterol</span> from other parts of your body back to your liver. Your liver then removes the <span class="qt1">cholesterol</span> from your body.</li><li>LDL stands for low-density lipoprotein. It is sometimes called "bad" <span class="qt1">cholesterol</span> because a high LDL level leads to the buildup of plaque in your arteries.</li><li>VLDL stands for very low-density lipoprotein. Some people also call VLDL a "bad" <span class="qt1">cholesterol</span> because it too contributes to the buildup of plaque in your arteries. But VLDL and LDL are different; VLDL mainly carries triglycerides and LDL mainly carries <span class="qt1">cholesterol</span>.</li></ul>What causes high <span class="qt1">cholesterol</span>?<p>The most common cause of high <span class="qt1">cholesterol</span> is an unhealthy lifestyle. This can include:</p><ul><li>Unhealthy eating habits, such as eating lots of bad fats. One type, saturated fat, is found in some meats, dairy products, chocolate, baked goods, and deep-fried and processed foods. Another type, trans fat, is in some fried and processed foods. Eating these fats can raise your LDL (bad) <span class="qt1">cholesterol</span>.</li><li>Lack of physical activity, with lots of sitting and little exercise. This lowers your HDL (good) <span class="qt1">cholesterol</span>.</li><li>Smoking, which lowers HDL <span class="qt1">cholesterol</span>, especially in women. It also raises your LDL <span class="qt1">cholesterol</span>.</li></ul><p>Genetics may also cause people to have high <span class="qt1">cholesterol</span>. For example, familial hypercholesterolemia (FH) is an inherited form of high <span class="qt1">cholesterol</span>. Other medical conditions and certain medicines may also cause high <span class="qt1">cholesterol</span>.</p>What can raise my risk of high <span class="qt1">cholesterol</span>?<p>A variety of things can raise your risk for high <span class="qt1">cholesterol</span>:</p><ul><li>Age. Your <span class="qt1">cholesterol</span> levels tend to rise as you get older. Even though it is less common, younger people, including children and teens, can also have high <span class="qt1">cholesterol</span>.</li><li>Heredity. High blood <span class="qt1">cholesterol</span> can run in families.</li><li>Weight. Being overweight or having obesity raises your <span class="qt1">cholesterol</span> level.</li><li>Race. Certain races may have an increased risk of high <span class="qt1">cholesterol</span>. For example, African Americans typically have higher HDL and LDL <span class="qt1">cholesterol</span> levels than whites.</li></ul>What health problems can high <span class="qt1">cholesterol</span> cause?<p>If you have large deposits of plaque in your arteries, an area of plaque can rupture (break open). This can cause a blood clot to form on the surface of the plaque. If the clot becomes large enough, it can mostly or completely block blood flow in a coronary artery.</p><p>If the flow of oxygen-rich blood to your heart muscle is reduced or blocked, it can cause angina (chest pain) or a heart attack.</p><p>Plaque also can build up in other arteries in your body, including the arteries that bring oxygen-rich blood to your brain and limbs. This can lead to problems such as carotid artery disease, stroke, and peripheral arterial disease.</p>How is high <span class="qt1">cholesterol</span> diagnosed?<p>There are usually no signs or symptoms that you have high <span class="qt1">cholesterol</span>. There is a blood test to measure your <span class="qt1">cholesterol</span> level. When and how often you should get this test depends on your age, risk factors, and family history.  The general recommendations are:</p><p>For people who are age 19 or younger::</p><ul><li>The first test should be between ages 9 to 11</li><li>Children should have the test again every 5 years</li><li>Some children may have this test starting at age 2 if there is a family history of high blood <span class="qt1">cholesterol</span>, heart attack, or stroke</li></ul><p>For people who are age 20 or older::</p><ul><li>Younger adults should have the test every 5 years</li><li>Men ages 45 to 65 and women ages 55 to 65 should have it every 1 to 2 years</li></ul>How can I lower my <span class="qt1">cholesterol</span>?<p>You can lower your <span class="qt1">cholesterol</span> through heart-healthy lifestyle changes. They include a heart-healthy eating plan, weight management, and regular physical activity.</p><p>If the lifestyle changes alone do not lower your <span class="qt1">cholesterol</span> enough, you may also need to take medicines. There are several types of <span class="qt1">cholesterol</span>-lowering drugs available, including statins. If you take medicines to lower your <span class="qt1">cholesterol</span>, you still should continue with the lifestyle changes.</p><p>Some people with familial hypercholesterolemia (FH) may receive a treatment called lipoprotein apheresis. This treatment uses a filtering machine to remove LDL <span class="qt1">cholesterol</span> from the blood. Then the machine returns the rest of the blood back to the person.</p><p>NIH: National Heart, Lung, and Blood Institute</p>

Exanthema.name: Rashes
Exanthema.summary: <p>A rash is an area of irritated or swollen skin. Many rashes are itchy, red, painful, and irritated. Some rashes can also lead to blisters or patches of raw skin.  Rashes are a symptom of many different medical problems. Other causes include irritating substances and allergies. Certain genes can make people more likely to get rashes.</p><p>Contact dermatitis is a common type of rash. It causes redness, itching, and sometimes small bumps. You get the rash where you have touched an irritant, such as a chemical, or something you are allergic to, like poison ivy.</p><p>Some rashes develop right away. Others form over several days. Although most rashes clear up fairly quickly, others are long-lasting and need  long-term treatment.</p><p>Because rashes can be caused by many different things, it's important to figure out what kind you have before you treat it. If it is a bad rash, if it does not go away, or if you have other symptoms, you should see your health care provider. Treatments may include moisturizers, lotions, baths, cortisone creams that relieve swelling, and antihistamines, which relieve itching.</p>

Ischemia.name: Adhesions
Ischemia.summary: <p>Adhesions are bands of scar-like tissue. Normally, internal tissues and organs have slippery surfaces so they can shift easily as the body moves. Adhesions cause tissues and organs to stick together. They might connect the loops of the intestines to each other, to nearby organs, or to the wall of the abdomen. They can pull sections of the intestines out of place. This may block food from passing through the intestine.</p><p>Adhesions can occur anywhere in the body. But they often form after surgery on the abdomen. Almost everyone who has surgery on the abdomen gets adhesions. Some adhesions don't cause any problems. But when they partly or completely block the intestines, they cause symptoms such as:</p><ul><li>Severe abdominal pain or cramping</li><li>Vomiting</li><li>Bloating</li><li>An inability to pass gas</li><li>Constipation</li></ul><p>Adhesions can sometimes cause infertility in women by preventing fertilized eggs from reaching the uterus.</p><p>No tests are available to detect adhesions.  Doctors usually find them during surgery to diagnose other problems.</p><p>Some adhesions go away by themselves. If they partly block your intestines, a diet low in fiber can allow food to move easily through the affected area. If you have a complete intestinal obstruction, it is life-threatening. You should get immediate medical attention and may need surgery. </p><p>NIH: National Institute of Diabetes and Digestive and Kidney Diseases</p>

Benign prostatic hypertrophy.name: Enlarged <span class="qt1">Prostate</span> (BPH)

Kidney failure acute.name: <span class="qt0">Kidney</span> <span class="qt1">Failure</span>
Kidney failure acute.summary: <p>Healthy <span class="qt0">kidneys</span> clean your blood by removing excess fluid, minerals, and wastes. They also make hormones that keep your bones strong and your blood healthy. But if the <span class="qt0">kidneys</span> are damaged, they <span class="qt1">don't work</span> properly. Harmful wastes can build up in your body. Your blood pressure may rise. Your body may retain excess fluid and not make enough red blood cells. This is called <span class="qt0">kidney</span> <span class="qt1">failure</span>.</p><p>If your <span class="qt0">kidneys</span> <span class="qt1">fail</span>, you need treatment to replace the work they normally do. The treatment options are dialysis or a <span class="qt0">kidney</span> transplant. Each treatment has benefits and drawbacks. No matter which treatment you choose, you'll need to make some changes in your life, including how you eat and plan your activities. But with the help of health care providers, family, and friends, most people with <span class="qt0">kidney</span> <span class="qt1">failure</span> can lead full and active lives.</p><p>NIH: National Institute of Diabetes and Digestive and <span class="qt0">Kidney</span> Diseases</p>

Cirrhosis.name: <span class="qt0">Cirrhosis</span>
Cirrhosis.summary: <p><span class="qt0">Cirrhosis</span> is scarring of the liver. Scar tissue forms because of injury or long-term disease. Scar tissue cannot do what healthy liver tissue does - make protein, help fight infections, clean the blood, help digest food and store energy.   <span class="qt0">Cirrhosis</span> can lead to  :</p><ul><li>Easy bruising or bleeding, or nosebleeds</li><li>Swelling of the abdomen or legs </li><li>Extra sensitivity to medicines</li><li>High blood pressure in the vein entering the liver</li><li>Enlarged veins called varices in the esophagus and stomach. Varices can bleed suddenly.</li><li> Kidney failure</li><li>Jaundice</li><li>Severe itching</li><li>Gallstones</li></ul><p>A small number of people with <span class="qt0">cirrhosis</span> get liver cancer.</p><p>Your doctor will diagnose <span class="qt0">cirrhosis</span> with blood tests, imaging tests, or a biopsy.</p><p><span class="qt0">Cirrhosis</span> has many causes. In the United States, the most common causes are chronic alcoholism and hepatitis. Nothing will make the scar tissue disappear, but treating the cause can keep it from getting worse. If too much scar tissue forms, you may need to consider a liver transplant.  </p><p>NIH: National Institute of Diabetes and Digestive and Kidney Diseases</p>

Obesity.name: <span class="qt0">Obesity</span>
Obesity.summary: <p><span class="qt0">Obesity</span> means having too much body <span class="qt0">fat</span>. It is different from being <span class="qt0">overweight</span>, which means weighing too much.  The weight may come from muscle, bone, <span class="qt0">fat</span>, and/or body water.  Both terms mean that a person's weight is greater than what's considered healthy for his or her height. </p><p><span class="qt0">Obesity</span> happens over time when you eat more calories than you use. The balance between calories-in and calories-out differs for each person. Factors that might affect your weight include your genetic makeup, overeating, eating high-<span class="qt0">fat</span> foods, and not being physically active. </p><p><span class="qt0">Obesity</span> increases your risk of diabetes, heart disease, stroke, arthritis, and some cancers. If you have <span class="qt0">obesity</span>, losing even 5 to 10% of your weight can delay or prevent some of these diseases. For example, that means losing 10 to 20 pounds if you weigh 200 pounds.</p><p>NIH: National Institute of Diabetes and Digestive and Kidney Diseases</p>

Transient ischemic attack.name: <span class="qt0">Transient</span> <span class="qt2"><span class="qt3">Ischemic</span></span> <span class="qt4">Attack</span>
Transient ischemic attack.summary: <p>A <span class="qt0">transient</span> <span class="qt2"><span class="qt3">ischemic</span></span> <span class="qt4">attack</span> (TIA) is a stroke that lasts only a few minutes. It happens when the blood supply to part of the brain is briefly blocked. Symptoms of a TIA are like other stroke symptoms, but do not last as long. They happen suddenly, and include:</p><ul><li>Numbness or weakness, especially on one side of the body</li><li>Confusion or trouble speaking or understanding speech</li><li>Trouble seeing in one or both eyes</li><li>Difficulty walking</li><li>Dizziness</li><li>Loss of balance or coordination</li></ul><p>Most symptoms of a TIA disappear within an hour, although they may last for up to 24 hours. Because you cannot tell if these symptoms are from a TIA or a stroke, you should go to the hospital right away.</p><p>TIAs are often a warning sign for future strokes. Taking medicine, such as blood thinners, may reduce your risk of a stroke. Your doctor might also recommend surgery. You can also help lower your risk by having a healthy lifestyle. This includes not smoking, not drinking too much, eating a healthy diet, and exercising. It is also important to control other health problems, such as high blood pressure and cholesterol.</p><p>NIH: National Institute of Neurological Disorders and Stroke</p>

Bronchitis.name: Acute <span class="qt0">Bronchitis</span>
Bronchitis.summary: <p><span class="qt0">Bronchitis</span> is an inflammation of the bronchial tubes, the airways that carry air to your lungs. It causes a cough that often brings up mucus. It can also cause shortness of breath, wheezing, a low fever, and chest tightness. There are two main types of <span class="qt0">bronchitis</span>: acute and chronic.</p><p>Most cases of acute <span class="qt0">bronchitis</span> get better within several days. But your cough can last for several weeks after the infection is gone.</p><p>The same viruses that cause colds and the flu often cause acute <span class="qt0">bronchitis</span>. These viruses spread through the air when people cough, or though physical contact (for example, on unwashed hands). Being exposed to tobacco smoke, air pollution, dusts, vapors, and fumes can also cause acute <span class="qt0">bronchitis</span>. Less often, bacteria can also cause acute <span class="qt0">bronchitis</span>.</p><p>To diagnose acute <span class="qt0">bronchitis</span>, your health care provider will ask about your symptoms and listen to your breathing. You may also have other tests.</p><p>Treatments include rest, fluids, and aspirin (for adults) or acetaminophen to treat fever. A humidifier or steam can also help. You may need inhaled medicine to open your airways if you are wheezing. Antibiotics won't help if the cause is viral. You may get antibiotics if the cause is bacterial.</p><p>NIH: National Heart, Lung, and Blood Institute</p>

Arthritis.name: <span class="qt0">Arthritis</span>
Arthritis.summary: <p>If you feel pain and stiffness in your body or have trouble moving around, you might have <span class="qt0">arthritis</span>. Most kinds of <span class="qt0">arthritis</span> cause pain and swelling in your joints. Joints are places where two bones meet, such as your elbow or knee. Over time, a swollen joint can become severely damaged. Some kinds of <span class="qt0">arthritis</span> can also cause problems in your organs, such as your eyes or skin.</p><p>Types of <span class="qt0">arthritis</span> include:</p><ul><li><span class="qt0">Osteoarthritis</span> is the most common type of <span class="qt0">arthritis</span>. It's often related to aging or to an injury.</li><li>Autoimmune <span class="qt0">arthritis</span> happens when your body's immune system attacks healthy cells in your body by mistake. Rheumatoid <span class="qt0">arthritis</span> is the most common form of this kind of <span class="qt0">arthritis</span>.</li><li>Juvenile <span class="qt0">arthritis</span> is a type of <span class="qt0">arthritis</span> that happens in  children.</li><li>Infectious <span class="qt0">arthritis</span> is an infection that has spread from another part of the body to the joint.</li><li>Psoriatic <span class="qt0">arthritis</span> affects people with psoriasis.</li><li>Gout is a painful type of <span class="qt0">arthritis</span> that happens when too much uric acid builds up in the body. It often starts in the big toe.</li></ul><p>NIH: National Institute of <span class="qt0">Arthritis</span> and Musculoskeletal and Skin Diseases</p>

Adenocarcinoma.name: Intestinal Cancer
Adenocarcinoma.summary: <p>Your small intestine is part of your digestive system.  It is a long tube that connects your stomach to your large intestine. Intestinal cancer is rare, but eating a high-fat diet or having Crohn's disease, celiac disease, or a history of  colonic polyps can increase your risk.</p><p>Possible signs of small intestine cancer include:</p><ul><li>Abdominal pain</li><li>Weight loss for no reason</li><li>Blood in the stool</li><li>A lump in the abdomen</li></ul><p>Imaging tests that create pictures of the small intestine and the area around it can help diagnose intestinal cancer and show whether it has spread.</p><p>Surgery is the most common treatment. Additional options include chemotherapy, radiation therapy, or a combination.</p><p>NIH: National Cancer Institute</p>

Hemiparesis.name: Syphilis
Hemiparesis.summary: <p>Syphilis is a sexually transmitted disease caused by bacteria. It infects the genital area, lips, mouth, or anus of both men and women. You usually get syphilis from sexual contact with someone who has it. It can also pass from mother to baby during pregnancy.</p><p>The early stage of syphilis usually causes a single, small, painless sore. Sometimes it causes swelling in nearby lymph nodes. If you do not treat it, syphilis usually causes a non-itchy skin rash, often on your hands and feet. Many people do not notice symptoms for years. Symptoms can go away and come back.</p><p>The sores caused by syphilis make it easier to get or give someone HIV during sex. If you are pregnant, syphilis can cause complications, or you could lose your baby. In rare cases, syphilis causes serious health problems and even death.</p><p>Syphilis is easy to cure with antibiotics if you catch it early. Correct usage of latex condoms greatly reduces, but does not completely eliminate, the risk of catching or spreading syphilis. If your or your partner is allergic to latex, you can use polyurethane condoms. The most reliable way to avoid infection is to not have anal, vaginal, or oral sex.</p><p>Centers for Disease Control and Prevention</p>

Osteoporosis.name: <span class="qt0">Osteoporosis</span>
Osteoporosis.summary:
<p><span class="qt0">Osteoporosis</span> is a disease that thins and weakens the bones. Your bones become fragile and fracture (break) easily, especially the bones in the hip, spine, and wrist. In the United States, millions of people either already have <span class="qt0">osteoporosis</span> or are at high risk due to low bone mass.</p><p>Anyone can develop <span class="qt0">osteoporosis</span>, but it is more common in older women. Risk factors include:</p><ul><li>Getting older </li><li>Being small and thin </li><li>Having a family history of <span class="qt0">osteoporosis</span></li><li>Taking certain medicines</li><li>Being a white or Asian woman</li><li>Having low bone density</li></ul><p><span class="qt0">Osteoporosis</span> is a silent disease. You might not know you have it until you break a bone. A bone mineral density test is the best way to check your bone health.</p><p>To keep bones strong, eat a diet rich in calcium and vitamin D, exercise, and do not smoke. If needed, medicines can also help. It is also important to try to avoid falling down. Falls are the number one cause of fractures in older adults.</p><p>NIH: National Institute of Arthritis and Musculoskeletal and Skin 
Diseases</p>

Incontinence.name: Urinary <span class="qt0">Incontinence</span>

Pancreatitis.name: <span class="qt0">Pancreatitis</span>
Pancreatitis.summary: <p>The pancreas is a large gland behind the stomach and close to the first part of the small intestine. It secretes digestive juices into the small intestine through a tube called the pancreatic duct. The pancreas also releases the hormones insulin and glucagon into the bloodstream.</p><p><span class="qt0">Pancreatitis</span> is inflammation of the pancreas. It happens when digestive enzymes start digesting the pancreas itself. <span class="qt0">Pancreatitis</span> can be acute or chronic. Either form is serious and can lead to complications.</p><p>Acute <span class="qt0">pancreatitis</span> occurs suddenly and usually goes away in a few days with treatment. It is often caused by gallstones.  Common symptoms are severe pain in the upper abdomen, nausea, and vomiting.   Treatment is usually a few days in the hospital for intravenous (IV) fluids, antibiotics, and medicines to relieve pain.</p><p>Chronic <span class="qt0">pancreatitis</span> does not heal or improve. It gets worse over time and leads to permanent damage. The most common cause is heavy alcohol use. Other causes include cystic fibrosis and other inherited disorders, high levels of calcium or fats in the blood, some medicines, and autoimmune conditions. Symptoms include nausea, vomiting, weight loss, and oily stools. Treatment may also be a few days in the hospital for intravenous (IV) fluids, medicines to relieve pain, and nutritional support. After that, you may need to start taking enzymes and eat a special diet.  It is also important to not smoke or drink alcohol.</p><p>NIH: National Institute of Diabetes and Digestive and Kidney Diseases</p>

Paranoia.name: Personality Disorders
Paranoia.summary: What is personality?<p>Your personality is your own way of thinking, feeling, behaving, and relating to others. Once you become an adult, your personality usually doesn't change much.</p>What are personality disorders?<p>Personality disorders are a group of mental disorders. They involve long-term patterns of thoughts and behaviors that are different from what is considered normal in your culture. The thoughts and behaviors are unhealthy and inflexible. They cause serious problems with relationships, work, and social activities. They can make it hard to deal with everyday stresses and problems.</p>What are the types of personality disorders?<p>There are 10 types of personality disorders. They are grouped into three different categories called clusters. The types in each cluster have some similar symptoms and characteristics. The clusters and types are:</p><p>Cluster A personality disorders involve unusual and odd thoughts and behaviors. It includes:</p><ul><li><span class="qt0">Paranoid</span> personality disorder, in which a person has <span class="qt0">paranoia</span> (an extreme fear and distrust of others). They may think that someone is trying to harm them.</li><li>Schizoid personality disorder, in which a person prefers to be alone and is not interested in having relationships with others.</li><li>Schizotypal personality disorder, in which a person has unusual thoughts and ways of behaving and speaking. They are uncomfortable having close relationships with others.</li></ul><p>Cluster B personality disorders involve dramatic and emotional thoughts and behaviors that can keep changing. It includes:</p><ul><li>Antisocial personality disorder, in which a person has a long-term pattern of manipulating, exploiting, or violating the rights of others.</li><li>Borderline personality disorder, in which a person has lots of trouble managing their emotions. This makes them impulsive and uncertain about how they see themselves. It can cause a lot of trouble in their relationships.</li><li>Histrionic personality disorder, in which a person is dramatic, has strong emotions, and always wants attention from others.</li><li>Narcissistic personality disorder, in which a person lacks empathy and wants to be admired by others. They think that they are better than others and that they deserve special treatment.</li></ul><p>Cluster C personality disorders involve anxious and fearful thoughts and behaviors. It includes:</p><ul><li>Avoidant personality disorder, in which a person is very shy and feels that they are not as good as others. They often avoid people because they fear rejection.</li><li>Dependent personality disorder, in which a person depends too much on others and feels that they need to be taken care of. They may let others treat them badly because they are afraid of losing the relationship.</li><li>Obsessive-compulsive personality disorder, in which a person needs control and order. They are perfectionists and can be inflexible. Although some of the symptoms are similar, this is not the same thing as obsessive-compulsive disorder (OCD).</li></ul>What causes personality disorders?<p>Personality disorders usually begin when someone is in their teens or early adult years. The cause is unknown. However, genes and childhood experiences such as abuse and trauma likely play a role.</p>What are the symptoms of personality disorders?<p>The symptoms of each personality disorder are different. But each disorder involves problems and uncertainty with how people see themselves. The disorders also cause problems in relationships with other people.</p><p>People with personality disorders may have trouble realizing that they have a problem. To them, their thoughts are normal. They may see others as the problem. So they may not seek help when they need it. Or, if they seek help, it may be because of another reason. They may be looking for help because of other mental health symptoms or problems with relationships and work. Sometimes someone else, such as a family member or social agency, may ask them to get help.</p>How are personality disorders diagnosed?<p>A mental health care provider can diagnose personality disorders. A mental health provider is a health care professional who specializes in diagnosing and treating mental health problems. To make a diagnosis, the provider will consider the person's symptoms, experiences, and family medical history. A thorough medical exam may also be done to help rule out other possible causes of the symptoms.</p>How are personality disorders treated?<p>Talk therapy, also known as psychotherapy, is the main treatment for personality disorders. Medicines may help relieve certain symptoms, such as anxiety or mood swings.</p>

Malignant neoplasm of prostate.name: <span class="qt3"><span class="qt4">Prostate</span></span><span class="qt4"> </span><span class="qt1"><span class="qt4">Cancer</span></span>

Stenosis aortic valve.name: Heart <span class="qt3">Valve</span> Diseases

Hernia.name: <span class="qt0">Hernia</span>
Hernia.summary: <p>A <span class="qt0">hernia</span> happens when part of an internal organ or tissue bulges through a weak area of muscle. Most <span class="qt1">hernias</span> are in the abdomen.</p><p>There are several types of <span class="qt1">hernias</span>, including:</p><ul><li> Inguinal, in the groin. This is the the most common type.</li><li> Umbilical, around the belly button</li><li> Incisional, through a scar</li><li>Hiatal, a small opening in the diaphragm that allows the upper part of the stomach to move up into the chest.</li><li> Congenital diaphragmatic, a birth defect that needs surgery</li></ul><p><span class="qt1">Hernias</span> are common. They can affect men, women, and children.  A combination of muscle weakness and straining, such as with heavy lifting, might contribute. Some people are born with weak abdominal muscles and may be more likely to get a <span class="qt0">hernia</span>.</p><p>Treatment is usually surgery to repair the opening in the muscle wall. Untreated <span class="qt1">hernias</span> can cause pain and health problems.</p>

Carcinoma prostate.name: <span class="qt3">Prostate</span> <span class="qt0"><span class="qt1">Cancer</span></span>

Lymphatic diseases.name: <span class="qt0">Lymphatic</span> <span class="qt1"><span class="qt2">Diseases</span></span>
Lymphatic diseases.summary: <p>The <span class="qt0">lymphatic</span> system is a network of tissues and organs. It is made up of:</p><ul><li><span class="qt0">Lymph</span> - a fluid that contains white blood cells that defend against germs</li><li><span class="qt0">Lymph</span> vessels - vessels that carry <span class="qt0">lymph</span> throughout your body.  They are different from blood vessels.</li><li><span class="qt0">Lymph</span> nodes - glands found throughout the <span class="qt0">lymph</span> vessels. Along with your spleen, these nodes are where white blood cells fight infection.</li></ul><p>Your bone marrow and thymus produce the cells in <span class="qt0">lymph</span>. They are part of the system, too.</p><p>The <span class="qt0">lymphatic</span> system clears away infection and keeps your body fluids in balance. If it's not working properly, fluid builds in your tissues and causes swelling, called lymphedema. Other <span class="qt0">lymphatic</span> system problems can include infections, blockage, and cancer.</p>

Edema pulmonary.name: <span class="qt0">Edema</span>
Edema pulmonary.summary: <p><span class="qt0">Edema</span> means swelling caused by fluid in your body's tissues. It usually occurs in the feet, ankles and legs, but it can involve your entire body.</p><p>Causes of <span class="qt0">edema</span> include:</p><ul><li>Eating too much salt</li><li>Sunburn</li><li>Heart failure</li><li>Kidney disease</li><li>Liver problems from cirrhosis</li><li>Pregnancy</li><li>Problems with  lymph nodes, especially after mastectomy</li><li>Some medicines</li><li>Standing or walking a lot when the weather is warm</li></ul><p>To keep swelling down, your health care provider may recommend keeping your legs raised when sitting, wearing support stockings, limiting how much salt you eat, or taking a medicine called a diuretic - also called a water pill. </p>

Malignant neoplasm of breast.name: <span class="qt3"><span class="qt4">Breast</span></span><span class="qt4"> </span><span class="qt1"><span class="qt4">Cancer</span></span>

Schizophrenia.name: <span class="qt0">Schizophrenia</span>
Schizophrenia.summary: <p><span class="qt0">Schizophrenia</span> is a serious brain illness. People who have it may hear voices that aren't there. They may think other people are trying to hurt them. Sometimes they don't make sense when they talk. The disorder makes it hard for them to keep a job or take care of themselves.</p><p>Symptoms of <span class="qt0">schizophrenia</span> usually start between ages 16 and 30. Men often develop symptoms at a younger age than women. People usually do not get <span class="qt0">schizophrenia</span> after age 45. There are three types of symptoms:</p><ul><li>Psychotic symptoms distort a person's thinking.  These include hallucinations (hearing or seeing things that are not there), delusions (beliefs that are not true), trouble organizing thoughts, and strange movements.</li><li>"Negative" symptoms make it difficult to show emotions and to function normally. A person may seem depressed and withdrawn.</li><li>Cognitive symptoms affect the thought process.  These include trouble using information, making decisions, and paying attention.</li></ul><p>No one is sure what causes <span class="qt0">schizophrenia</span>.  Your genes, environment, and brain chemistry may play a role.</p><p>There is no cure. Medicine can help control many of the symptoms. You may need to try different medicines to see which works best. You should stay on your medicine for as long as your doctor recommends. Additional treatments can help you deal with your illness from day to day.  These include therapy, family education, rehabilitation, and skills training.</p><p>NIH: National Institute of Mental Health</p>

Diverticulitis.name: Diverticulosis and <span class="qt0">Diverticulitis</span>

Overload fluid.name: Heart Failure

Ulcer peptic.name: <span class="qt1">Peptic</span> <span class="qt0">Ulcer</span>
Ulcer peptic.summary: <p>A <span class="qt1">peptic</span> <span class="qt0">ulcer</span> is a sore in the lining of your stomach or your duodenum, the first part of your small intestine. A burning stomach pain is the most common symptom. The pain:</p><ul><li>Starts between meals or during the night</li><li>Briefly stops if you eat or take antacids</li><li>Lasts for minutes to hours</li><li>Comes and goes for several days or weeks</li></ul><p><span class="qt1">Peptic</span> <span class="qt0">ulcers</span> happen when the acids that help you digest food damage the walls of the stomach or duodenum. The most common cause is infection with a bacterium called Helicobacter pylori. Another cause is the long-term use of nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory medicines (NSAIDs) such as aspirin and ibuprofen. Stress and spicy foods do not cause <span class="qt0">ulcers</span>, but can make them worse. </p><p>To see if you have an H. pylori infection, your doctor will test your blood, breath, or stool. Your doctor also may look inside your stomach and duodenum by doing an endoscopy or x-ray.</p><p><span class="qt1">Peptic</span> <span class="qt0">ulcers</span> will get worse if not treated. Treatment may include medicines to reduce stomach acids or antibiotics to kill H. pylori. Antacids and milk can't heal <span class="qt1">peptic</span> <span class="qt0">ulcers</span>. Not smoking and avoiding alcohol can help. You may need surgery if your <span class="qt0">ulcers</span> don't heal.</p><p>NIH: National Institute of Diabetes and Digestive and Kidney Diseases</p>

Carcinoma breast.name: Male <span class="qt3">Breast</span> <span class="qt0"><span class="qt1">Cancer</span></span>
Carcinoma breast.summary: <p>Although <span class="qt3">breast</span> <span class="qt0"><span class="qt1">cancer</span></span> is much more common in women, men can get it too. It happens most often to men between the ages of 60 and 70.</p><p><span class="qt3">Breast</span> lumps usually aren't <span class="qt0"><span class="qt1">cancer</span></span>. However, most men with <span class="qt3">breast</span> <span class="qt0"><span class="qt1">cancer</span></span> have lumps. Other <span class="qt3">breast</span> symptoms can include:</p><ul><li>Dimpled or puckered skin</li><li>A red, scaly nipple or skin</li><li>Fluid discharge</li></ul><p>Risk factors for male <span class="qt3">breast</span> <span class="qt0"><span class="qt1">cancer</span></span> include exposure to radiation, a family history of <span class="qt3">breast</span> <span class="qt0"><span class="qt1">cancer</span></span>, and having high estrogen levels, which can happen with diseases like cirrhosis or Klinefelter syndrome.</p><p>Treatment for male <span class="qt3">breast</span> <span class="qt0"><span class="qt1">cancer</span></span> is usually a <span class="qt3">mastectomy</span>, which is surgery to remove the <span class="qt3">breast</span>. Other treatments include radiation, chemotherapy and/or hormone therapy. </p><p>NIH: National <span class="qt0"><span class="qt1">Cancer</span></span> Institute</p>

Deglutition disorder.name: Swallowing <span class="qt1">Disorders</span>
Deglutition disorder.summary: <p>If you have a swallowing <span class="qt1">disorder</span>, you may have difficulty or pain when swallowing. Some people cannot swallow at all. Others may have trouble swallowing liquids, foods, or saliva. This makes it hard to eat. Often, it can be difficult to take in enough calories and fluids to nourish your body.</p><p>Anyone can have a swallowing <span class="qt1">disorder</span>, but it is more common in older adults. It often happens because of other conditions, including:</p><ul><li>Nervous system <span class="qt1">disorders</span>, such as Parkinson's disease and cerebral palsy</li><li>	Problems with your esophagus, including GERD (gastroesophageal reflux disease)</li><li>Stroke</li><li>Head or spinal cord  injury</li><li>	Cancer of the head, neck, or esophagus</li></ul><p>Medicines can help some people, while others may need surgery.  Swallowing treatment with a speech-language pathologist can help.  You may find it helpful to change your diet or hold your head or neck in a certain way when you eat. In very serious cases, people may need feeding tubes.</p><p>NIH: National Institute on Deafness and Other Communication <span class="qt1">Disorders</span></p>

Thrombocytopaenia.name: Platelet Disorders
Thrombocytopaenia.summary: <p>Platelets, also known as thrombocytes, are blood cells. They form in your bone marrow, a sponge-like tissue in your bones. Platelets play a major role in blood clotting. Normally, when one of your blood vessels is injured, you start to bleed. Your platelets will clot (clump together) to plug the hole in the blood vessel and stop the bleeding. You can have different problems with your platelets:</p><ul><li>If your blood has a low number of platelets, it is called <span class="qt2">thrombocytopenia</span>. This can put you at risk for mild to serious bleeding. The bleeding could be external or internal. There can be various causes. If the problem is mild, you may not need treatment. For more serious cases, you may need medicines or blood or platelet transfusions.</li><li>If your blood has too many platelets, you may have a higher risk of blood clots.</li><ul><li>When the cause is unknown, this is called thrombocythemia. It is rare. You may not need treatment if there are no signs or symptoms. In other cases, people who have it may need treatment with medicines or procedures.</li><li>If another disease or condition is causing the high platelet count, it is thrombocytosis. The treatment and outlook for thrombocytosis depends on what is causing it.</li></ul><li>Another possible problem is that your platelets do not work as they should. For example, in von Willebrand Disease, your platelets cannot stick together or cannot attach to blood vessel walls. This can cause excessive bleeding. There are different types of in von Willebrand Disease; treatment depends on which type you have.</li></ul><p>NIH: National Heart, Lung, and Blood Institute</p>

Gout.name: <span class="qt0">Gout</span>
Gout.summary: <p><span class="qt0">Gout</span> is a common, painful form of arthritis. It causes swollen, red, hot and stiff joints.</p><p><span class="qt0">Gout</span> happens when uric acid builds up in your body.  Uric acid comes from the breakdown of substances called purines. Purines are in your body's tissues and in foods, such as liver, dried beans and peas, and anchovies. Normally, uric acid dissolves in the blood. It passes through the kidneys and out of the body in urine. But sometimes uric acid can build up and form needle-like crystals. When they form in your joints, it is very painful. The crystals can also cause kidney stones.</p><p>Often, <span class="qt0">gout</span> first attacks your big toe. It can also attack ankles, heels, knees, wrists, fingers, and elbows. At first, <span class="qt0">gout</span> attacks usually get better in days. Eventually, attacks last longer and happen more often.</p><p>You are more likely to get <span class="qt0">gout</span> if you:</p><ul><li>Are a man</li><li>Have family member with <span class="qt0">gout</span></li><li>Are overweight</li><li>Drink alcohol</li><li>Eat too many foods rich in purines</li></ul><p><span class="qt0">Gout</span> can be hard to diagnose. Your doctor may take a sample of fluid from an inflamed joint to look for crystals. You can treat <span class="qt0">gout</span> with medicines.</p><p>Pseudogout has similar symptoms and is sometimes confused with <span class="qt0">gout</span>.  However, it is caused by calcium phosphate, not uric acid.</p><p>NIH: National Institute of Arthritis and Musculoskeletal and Skin Diseases</p>

Upper respiratory infection.name: Common Cold

Hypertension pulmonary.name: <span class="qt2"><span class="qt3">Pulmonary</span></span> <span class="qt0"><span class="qt1">Hypertension</span></span>
Hypertension pulmonary.summary: <p><span class="qt2"><span class="qt3">Pulmonary</span></span> <span class="qt0"><span class="qt1">hypertension</span></span> (PH) is <span class="qt0"><span class="qt1">high blood pressure</span></span> in the arteries to your <span class="qt2"><span class="qt3">lungs</span></span>. It is a serious condition. If you have it, the blood vessels that carry blood from your heart to your <span class="qt2"><span class="qt3">lungs</span></span> become hard and narrow. Your heart has to work harder to pump the blood through. Over time, your heart weakens and cannot do its job and you can develop heart failure. </p><p>Symptoms of PH  include:</p><ul><li>Shortness of breath during routine activity, such as climbing two flights of stairs</li><li>Tiredness</li><li>Chest pain</li><li>A racing heartbeat</li><li>Pain on the upper right side of the abdomen</li><li>Decreased appetite</li></ul><p>As PH worsens, you may find it hard to do any physical activities.</p><p>There are two main kinds of PH. One runs in families or appears for no known reason. The other kind is related to another condition, usually heart or <span class="qt2"><span class="qt3">lung</span></span> disease. </p><p>There is no cure for PH. Treatments can control symptoms.  They involve treating the heart or <span class="qt2"><span class="qt3">lung</span></span> disease, medicines, oxygen, and sometimes <span class="qt2"><span class="qt3">lung</span></span> transplantation.</p><p>NIH: National Heart, <span class="qt2"><span class="qt3">Lung</span></span>, and Blood Institute</p>

Hepatitis.name: <span class="qt0">Hepatitis</span>
Hepatitis.summary: What is <span class="qt0">hepatitis</span>?<p><span class="qt0">Hepatitis is inflammation of the liver. Inflammation</span> is swelling that happens when tissues of the body are injured or infected. It can damage your liver. This swelling and damage can affect how well your liver functions.</p><p><span class="qt0">Hepatitis</span> can be an acute (short-term) infection or a chronic (long-term) infection. Some types of <span class="qt0">hepatitis</span> cause only acute infections. Other types can cause both acute and chronic infections.</p>What causes <span class="qt0">hepatitis</span>?<p>There are different types of <span class="qt0">hepatitis</span>, with different causes:</p><ul><li>Viral <span class="qt0">hepatitis</span> is the most common type. It is caused by one of several viruses -- <span class="qt0">hepatitis</span> viruses A, B, C, D, and E. In the United States, A, B, and C are the most common.</li><li>Alcoholic <span class="qt0">hepatitis</span> is caused by heavy alcohol use</li><li>Toxic <span class="qt0">hepatitis</span> can be caused by certain poisons, chemicals, medicines, or supplements</li><li>Autoimmune <span class="qt0">hepatitis</span> is a chronic type in which your body's immune system attacks your liver. The cause is not known, but genetics and your environment may play a role.</li></ul>How is viral <span class="qt0">hepatitis</span> spread?<p><span class="qt0">Hepatitis A and hepatitis</span> E usually spread through contact with food or water that was contaminated with an infected person's stool. You can also get <span class="qt0">hepatitis</span> E by eating undercooked pork, deer, or shellfish.</p><p><span class="qt0">Hepatitis</span> B, <span class="qt0">hepatitis</span> C, and <span class="qt0">hepatitis</span> D spread through contact with the blood of someone who has the disease. <span class="qt0">Hepatitis</span> B and D may also spread through contact with other body fluids. This can happen in many ways, such as sharing drug needles or having unprotected sex.</p>Who is at risk for <span class="qt0">hepatitis</span>?<p>The risks are different for the different types of <span class="qt0">hepatitis</span>. For example, with most of the viral types, your risk is higher if you have unprotected sex.  People who drink a lot over long periods of time are at risk for alcoholic <span class="qt0">hepatitis</span>.</p>What are the symptoms of <span class="qt0">hepatitis</span>?<p>Some people with <span class="qt0">hepatitis</span> do not have symptoms and do not know they are infected. If you do have symptoms, they may include:</p><ul><li>Fever</li><li>Fatigue</li><li>Loss of appetite</li><li>Nausea and/or vomiting</li><li>Abdominal pain</li><li>Dark urine</li><li>Clay-colored bowel movements</li><li>Joint pain</li><li>Jaundice, yellowing of your skin and eyes</li></ul><p>If you have an acute infection, your symptoms can start anywhere between 2 weeks to 6 months after you got infected. If you have a chronic infection, you may not have symptoms until many years later.</p>What other problems can <span class="qt0">hepatitis</span> cause?<p>Chronic <span class="qt0">hepatitis</span> can lead to complications such as cirrhosis (scarring of the liver), liver failure, and liver cancer. Early diagnosis and treatment of chronic <span class="qt0">hepatitis</span> may prevent these complications.</p>How is <span class="qt0">hepatitis</span> diagnosed?<p>To diagnose <span class="qt0">hepatitis</span>, your health care provider:</p><ul><li>Will ask about your symptoms and medical history</li><li>Will do a physical exam</li><li>Will likely do blood tests, including tests for viral <span class="qt0">hepatitis</span></li><li>Might do imaging tests, such as an ultrasound, CT scan, or MRI</li><li>May need to do a liver biopsy to get a clear diagnosis and check for liver damage</li></ul>What are the treatments for <span class="qt0">hepatitis</span>?<p>Treatment for <span class="qt0">hepatitis</span> depends on which type you have and whether it is acute or chronic. Acute viral <span class="qt0">hepatitis</span> often goes away on its own. To feel better, you may just need to rest and get enough fluids. But in some cases, it may be more serious. You might even need treatment in a hospital.</p><p>There are different medicines to treat the different chronic types of <span class="qt0">hepatitis</span>. Possible other treatments may include surgery and other medical procedures. People who have alcoholic <span class="qt0">hepatitis</span> need to stop drinking. If your chronic <span class="qt0">hepatitis</span> leads to liver failure or liver cancer, you may need a liver transplant.</p>Can <span class="qt0">hepatitis</span> be prevented?<p>There are different ways to prevent or lower your risk for <span class="qt0">hepatitis</span>, depending on the type of <span class="qt0">hepatitis</span>. For example, not drinking too much alcohol can prevent alcoholic <span class="qt0">hepatitis</span>. There are vaccines to prevent <span class="qt0">hepatitis</span> A and B. Autoimmune <span class="qt0">hepatitis</span> cannot be prevented.</p><p>NIH: National Institute of Diabetes and Digestive and Kidney Diseases</p>

Hypoglycemia.name: <span class="qt0">Hypoglycemia</span>
Hypoglycemia.summary: What is blood glucose?<p>Blood glucose, or blood sugar, is the main sugar found in your blood. It is your body's primary source of energy. It comes from the food you eat. Your body breaks down most of that food into glucose and releases it into your bloodstream. When your blood glucose goes up, it signals your pancreas to release insulin. Insulin is a hormone that helps the glucose get into your cells to be used for energy.</p><p>For people with diabetes, your body doesn't make enough insulin, can't use it as well as it should, or both. Too much glucose stays in your blood and doesn't reach your cells.</p>What is <span class="qt0">hypoglycemia</span>?<p><span class="qt0">Hypoglycemia</span> means low glucose. It happens when the level of glucose in your blood drops below what is healthy for you:</p><ul><li>For many people with diabetes, this means a blood glucose level lower than 70 mg/dL. Your number might be different, so check with your health care team to find out what blood glucose level is too low for you.</li><li>For people who don't have diabetes, <span class="qt0">hypoglycemia</span> is typically a blood glucose level lower than 55 mg/dL.</li></ul>What causes <span class="qt0">hypoglycemia</span>?<p><span class="qt0">Hypoglycemia</span> is common in people who have diabetes type 1 or who have diabetes type 2 and take insulin or other diabetes medicines. It can happen:</p><ul><li>As a side effect of insulin or some other medicines that help your pancreas release insulin into your blood. These medicines can lower your blood glucose level.</li><li>If you don't eat or drink enough carbohydrates (carbs). Carbs are the main source of glucose for your body.</li><li>If you get a lot more physical activity than usual.</li><li>If you drink too much alcohol without enough food.</li><li>When you are sick and can't eat enough food or keep food down.</li></ul><p>Although it's rare, you can still get low blood glucose without having diabetes. The causes can include conditions such as liver disease, kidney disease, and hormone deficiencies (lack of certain hormones). It can also happen in people who have had certain types of weight loss surgery. Some medicines, such as certain heart medicines and antibiotics, can also cause it. See your health care provider to find out the cause of your low blood glucose and how to treat it.</p>What are the symptoms of <span class="qt0">hypoglycemia</span>?<p>The symptoms of low blood glucose tend to come on quickly. The symptoms can be different for everyone, but they may include:</p><ul><li>Shaking</li><li>Sweating</li><li>Nervousness or anxiety</li><li>Irritability or confusion</li><li>Dizziness</li><li>Hunger</li></ul>How is <span class="qt0">hypoglycemia</span> diagnosed?<p>If you have diabetes, you'll most likely need to check your blood glucose every day and make sure that it's not too low. You can do this with a blood glucose meter or continuous glucose monitoring (CGM) system.</p><p>There are also blood tests that providers can use to check if your blood glucose is too low.</p><p>If you don't have diabetes and you have <span class="qt0">hypoglycemia</span>, your provider will likely order other tests to try to figure out the cause.</p>What are the treatments for <span class="qt0">hypoglycemia</span>?<p>If you have mild or moderate <span class="qt0">hypoglycemia</span>, eating or drinking something with carbohydrates can help. But severe <span class="qt0">hypoglycemia</span> can cause serious complications, including passing out, coma, or even death. Severe <span class="qt0">hypoglycemia</span> can be treated with glucagon, a hormone that raises blood glucose levels. It can be given as nasal spray or injection. If you have diabetes, your provider can prescribe you a glucagon kit for use in case of an emergency.</p><p>If you have diabetes and you often have mild or moderate low blood glucose, your health care team may make changes to your diabetes meal plan, physical activity plan, and/or diabetes medicines.</p><p>If you don't have diabetes and you keep having low blood glucose, the treatment will depend on what is causing it to happen.</p>Can <span class="qt0">hypoglycemia</span> be prevented?<p>If you have diabetes and you take insulin or other medicines that lower blood glucose, you can help prevent <span class="qt0">hypoglycemia</span> if you:</p><ul><li>Follow your diabetes meal plan. Eat and drink enough carbs to keep your blood glucose in your target range. Also carry a source of fast-acting carbohydrate, such as glucose tablets or a juice box, with you in case your blood glucose gets too low.</li><li>Be safe during physical activity. Check your blood glucose before and afterwards. You may need to eat a snack before your physical activity.</li><li>If you take diabetes medicines, make sure to take them correctly.</li></ul>

Colitis.name: Ulcerative <span class="qt0">Colitis</span>
Colitis.summary: <p>Ulcerative <span class="qt0">colitis</span> (UC) is a disease that causes inflammation and sores, called ulcers, in the lining of the rectum and colon. It is one of a group of diseases called inflammatory bowel disease.</p><p>UC can happen at any age, but it usually starts between the ages of 15 and 30. It tends to run in families. The most common symptoms are pain in the abdomen and blood or pus in diarrhea. Other symptoms may include:</p><ul><li>Anemia</li><li>Severe tiredness</li><li>Weight loss</li><li>Loss of appetite</li><li>Bleeding from the rectum</li><li>Sores on the skin</li><li>Joint pain</li><li>Growth failure in children</li></ul><p>About half of people with UC have mild symptoms.</p><p>Doctors use blood tests, stool tests, colonoscopy or sigmoidoscopy, and imaging tests to diagnose UC. Several types of drugs can help control it. Some people have long periods of remission, when they are free of symptoms. In severe cases, doctors must remove the colon.</p><p>NIH: National Institute of Diabetes and Digestive and Kidney Diseases</p>

Suicide attempt.name: <span class="qt0">Suicide</span>

Diverticulosis.name: <span class="qt0">Diverticulosis</span> and Diverticulitis

Pneumonia aspiration.name: <span class="qt0">Pneumonia</span>

Pneumocystis carinii pneumonia.name: HIV and Infections
Pneumocystis carinii pneumonia.summary: <p>Having HIV/AIDS weakens your body's immune system. It destroys the white blood cells that fight infection. This puts you at risk for opportunistic infections (OIs). OIs are serious infections that take advantage of your weak immune system. These infections are less common and less severe in healthy people.</p><p>There are many types of OIs:</p><ul><li>Bacterial infections, including tuberculosis and a serious related disease, Mycobacterium avium complex (MAC)</li><li>Viral infections, such as cytomegalovirus (CMV) and hepatitis C</li><li>Fungal infections, like yeast infections, cryptococcal meningitis, <span class="qt0">pneumocystis carinii pneumonia</span> (PCP) and histoplasmosis</li><li>Parasitic infections, such as crypto (cryptosporidiosis) and toxo (toxoplasmosis)</li></ul><p>Having HIV/AIDS can make infections harder to treat. People with HIV/AIDS are also more likely to have complications from common illnesses such as the flu.</p><p>You can help prevent infections by taking your HIV/AIDS medicines. Other things that can help include practicing safe sex, washing your hands well and often, and cooking your food thoroughly.</p>

Hepatitis b.name: <span class="qt0">Hepatitis</span> <span class="qt1">B</span>
Hepatitis b.summary: What is <span class="qt0">hepatitis</span>?<p><span class="qt0">Hepatitis is inflammation of the liver. Inflammation</span> is swelling that happens when tissues of the body are injured or infected. It can damage your liver. This swelling and damage can affect how well your liver functions.</p>What is <span class="qt0">hepatitis</span> <span class="qt1">B</span>?<p><span class="qt0">Hepatitis</span> <span class="qt1">B</span> is a type of viral <span class="qt0">hepatitis</span>. It can cause an acute (short-term) or chronic (long-term) infection. People with an acute infection usually get better on their own without treatment. Some people with chronic <span class="qt0">hepatitis</span> <span class="qt1">B</span> will need treatment.</p><p>Thanks to a vaccine, <span class="qt0">hepatitis</span> <span class="qt1">B</span> is not very common in the United States. It is more common in certain parts of the world, such as sub-Saharan Africa and parts of Asia.</p>What causes <span class="qt0">hepatitis</span> <span class="qt1">B</span>?<p><span class="qt0">Hepatitis</span> <span class="qt1">B</span> is caused by the <span class="qt0">hepatitis</span> <span class="qt1">B</span> virus. The virus spreads through contact with blood, semen, or other body fluids from a person who has the virus.</p>Who is at risk for <span class="qt0">hepatitis</span> <span class="qt1">B</span>?<p>Anyone can get <span class="qt0">hepatitis</span> <span class="qt1">B</span>, but the risk is higher in:</p><ul><li>Infants born to mothers who have <span class="qt0">hepatitis</span> <span class="qt1">B</span></li><li>People who inject drugs or share needles, syringes, and other types of drug equipment</li><li>Sex partners of people with <span class="qt0">hepatitis</span> <span class="qt1">B</span>, especially if they are not using latex or polyurethane condoms during sex</li><li>Men who have sex with men</li><li>People who live with someone who has <span class="qt0">hepatitis</span> <span class="qt1">B</span>, especially if they use the same razor, toothbrush, or nail clippers</li><li>Health care and public-safety workers who are exposed to blood on the job</li><li>Hemodialysis patients</li><li>People who have lived in or traveled often to parts of the world where <span class="qt0">hepatitis</span> <span class="qt1">B</span> is common</li><li>Have diabetes, <span class="qt0">hepatitis</span> C, or HIV</li></ul>What are the symptoms of <span class="qt0">hepatitis</span> <span class="qt1">B</span>?<p>Often, people with <span class="qt0">hepatitis</span> <span class="qt1">B</span> don't have symptoms. Adults and children over 5 are more likely to have symptoms than younger children.</p><p>Some people with acute <span class="qt0">hepatitis</span> <span class="qt1">B</span> have symptoms 2 to 5 months after infection. These symptoms can include:</p><ul><li>Dark yellow urine</li><li>Diarrhea</li><li>Fatigue</li><li>Fever</li><li>Gray- or clay-colored stools</li><li>Joint pain</li><li>Loss of appetite</li><li>Nausea and/or vomiting</li><li>Abdominal pain</li><li>Yellowish eyes and skin, called jaundice</li></ul><p>If you have chronic <span class="qt0">hepatitis</span> <span class="qt1">B</span>, you may not have symptoms until complications develop. This could be decades after you were infected. For this reason, <span class="qt0">hepatitis</span> <span class="qt1">B</span> screening is important, even if you have no symptoms. Screening means that you are tested for a disease even though you don't have symptoms. If you are at high risk, your health care provider may suggest  screening.</p>What other problems can <span class="qt0">hepatitis</span> <span class="qt1">B</span> cause?<p>In rare cases, acute <span class="qt0">hepatitis</span> <span class="qt1">B</span> can cause liver failure.</p><p>Chronic <span class="qt0">hepatitis</span> <span class="qt1">B</span> can develop into a serious disease that causes long-term health problems such as cirrhosis (scarring of the liver), liver cancer, and liver failure.</p><p>If you have ever had <span class="qt0">hepatitis</span> <span class="qt1">B</span>, the virus may become active again, or reactivated, later in life. This could start to damage the liver and cause symptoms.</p>How is <span class="qt0">hepatitis</span> <span class="qt1">B</span> diagnosed?<p>To diagnose <span class="qt0">hepatitis</span> <span class="qt1">B</span>, your health care provider may use many tools to make a diagnosis:</p><ul><li>A medical history, which includes asking about your symptoms</li><li>A physical exam</li><li>Blood tests, including tests for viral <span class="qt0">hepatitis</span></li></ul>What are the treatments for <span class="qt0">hepatitis</span> <span class="qt1">B</span>?<p>If you have acute <span class="qt0">hepatitis</span> <span class="qt1">B</span>, you probably don't need treatment. Some people with chronic <span class="qt0">hepatitis</span> <span class="qt1">B</span> don't need treatment. But if you have a chronic infection and blood tests show that <span class="qt0">hepatitis</span> <span class="qt1">B</span> could be damaging your liver, you may need to take antiviral medicines.</p>Can <span class="qt0">hepatitis</span> <span class="qt1">B</span> be prevented?<p>The best way to prevent <span class="qt0">hepatitis</span> <span class="qt1">B</span> is to get the <span class="qt0">hepatitis</span> <span class="qt1">B</span> vaccine.</p><p>You can also reduce your chance of <span class="qt0">hepatitis</span> <span class="qt1">B</span> infection by:</p><ul><li>Not sharing drug needles or other drug materials</li><li>Wearing gloves if you have to touch another person's blood or open sores</li><li>Making sure your tattoo artist or body piercer uses sterile tools</li><li>Not sharing personal items, such as toothbrushes, razors, or nail clippers</li><li>Using a latex condom during sex. If your or your partner is allergic to latex, you can use polyurethane condoms.</li></ul><p>If you think you have been in contact with the <span class="qt0">hepatitis</span> <span class="qt1">B</span> virus, see your health care provider right away. Your provider may give you a dose of the <span class="qt0">hepatitis</span> <span class="qt1">B</span> vaccine to prevent infection. In some cases, your provider may also give you a medicine called <span class="qt0">hepatitis</span> <span class="qt1">B</span> immune globulin (HBIG). You need to get the vaccine and the HBIG (if needed) as soon as possible after coming into contact with the virus. It is best if you can get them within 24 hours.</p><p>National Institute of Diabetes and Digestive and Kidney Diseases</p>

Lymphoma.name: <span class="qt0">Lymphoma</span>
Lymphoma.summary: <p><span class="qt0">Lymphoma</span> is a cancer of a part of the immune system called the lymph system.  There are many types of <span class="qt0">lymphoma</span>.  One type is Hodgkin disease.  The rest are called non-Hodgkin <span class="qt1">lymphomas</span>.</p><p>Non-Hodgkin <span class="qt1">lymphomas</span> begin when a type of white blood cell, called a T cell or B cell, becomes abnormal. The cell divides again and again, making more and more abnormal cells. These abnormal cells can spread to almost any other part of the body. Most of the time, doctors don't know why a person gets non-Hodgkin <span class="qt0">lymphoma</span>. You are at increased risk if you have a weakened immune system or have certain types of infections.</p><p>Non-Hodgkin <span class="qt0">lymphoma</span> can cause many symptoms, such as :</p><ul><li>Swollen, painless lymph nodes in the neck, armpits or groin</li><li>Unexplained weight loss </li><li>Fever </li><li>Soaking night sweats </li><li>Coughing, trouble breathing or chest pain </li><li>Weakness and tiredness that don't go away </li><li>Pain, swelling or a feeling of fullness in the abdomen </li></ul><p>Your doctor will diagnose <span class="qt0">lymphoma</span> with a physical exam, blood tests, a chest x-ray, and a biopsy.  Treatments include chemotherapy, radiation therapy, targeted therapy, biological therapy, or therapy to remove proteins from the blood. Targeted therapy uses drugs or other substances that attack specific cancer cells with less harm to normal cells. Biologic therapy boosts your body's own ability to fight cancer. If you don't have symptoms, you may not need treatment right away. This is called watchful waiting.</p><p>NIH: National Cancer Institute</p>

Encephalopathy.name: Creutzfeldt-Jakob Disease
Encephalopathy.summary: <p>Creutzfeldt-Jakob disease (CJD) is a rare, degenerative brain disorder. Symptoms usually start around age 60. Memory problems, behavior changes, vision problems, and poor muscle coordination progress quickly to dementia, coma, and death. Most patients die within a year.</p><p>The three main categories of CJD are  :</p><ul><li>Sporadic CJD, which occurs for no known reason </li><li>Hereditary CJD, which runs in families</li><li>Acquired CJD, which occurs from contact with infected tissue, usually during a medical procedure</li></ul><p>Cattle can get a disease related to CJD called bovine spongiform <span class="qt0">encephalopathy</span> (BSE) or "mad cow disease."  There is concern that people can get a variant of CJD from eating beef from an infected animal, but there is no direct proof to support this.</p><p>NIH: National Institute of Neurological Disorders and Stroke</p>

Parkinson disease.name: <span class="qt0">Parkinson</span>'s <span class="qt1">Disease</span>
Parkinson disease.summary: <p><span class="qt0">Parkinson</span>'s <span class="qt1">disease</span> (PD) is a type of movement disorder. It happens when nerve cells in the brain don't produce enough of a brain chemical called dopamine. Sometimes it is genetic, but most cases do not seem to run in families. Exposure to chemicals in the environment might play a role.</p><p>Symptoms begin gradually, often on one side of the body.  Later they affect both sides. They  include:</p><ul><li>Trembling of hands, arms, legs, jaw and face </li><li>Stiffness of the arms, legs and trunk </li><li>Slowness of movement </li><li>Poor balance and coordination </li></ul><p>As symptoms get worse, people with the <span class="qt1">disease</span> may have trouble walking, talking, or doing simple tasks. They may also have problems such as depression, sleep problems, or trouble chewing, swallowing, or speaking.</p><p>There is no specific test for PD, so it can be difficult to diagnose.  Doctors use a medical history and a neurological examination to diagnose it.</p><p>PD usually begins around age 60, but it can start earlier. It is more common in men than in women. There is no cure for PD. A variety of medicines sometimes help symptoms dramatically. Surgery and deep brain stimulation (DBS) can help severe cases. With DBS, electrodes are surgically implanted in the brain. They send electrical pulses to stimulate the parts of the brain that control movement.</p><p>NIH: National Institute of Neurological Disorders and Stroke</p>

Hyperglycemia.name: <span class="qt0">Hyperglycemia</span>
Hyperglycemia.summary: What is blood glucose?<p>Blood glucose, or blood sugar, is the main sugar found in your blood. It is your body's primary source of energy. It comes from the food you eat. Your body breaks down most of that food into glucose and releases it into your bloodstream. When your blood glucose goes up, it signals your pancreas to release insulin. Insulin is a hormone that helps the glucose get into your cells to be used for energy.</p><p>For people with diabetes, your body doesn't make enough insulin, can't use it as well as it should, or both. Too much glucose stays in your blood and doesn't reach your cells.</p>What is <span class="qt0">hyperglycemia</span>?<p><span class="qt0">Hyperglycemia</span> means high blood glucose. It most often affects people who have diabetes. When you have diabetes, your body doesn't make enough insulin or can't use it the right way.
