Too much glucose stays in your blood and doesn't reach your cells.  </p>What causes <span class="qt0">hyperglycemia</span>?<p>A key part of managing diabetes is controlling your blood glucose levels. To do this, you need to follow a diabetes meal plan and get regular physical activity. You might also need to take diabetes medicines. You have to balance all of these to keep your blood glucose at the right levels. But if you eat too much food or the wrong foods, don't take your medicines correctly, or don't get physical activity, you can get <span class="qt0">hyperglycemia</span>. It can also happen if you are stressed or sick.</p><p>Less commonly, people who don't have diabetes can also get <span class="qt0">hyperglycemia</span>. It can be caused by conditions that can affect insulin or glucose levels in your blood. They include problems with your pancreas or adrenal glands, certain medicines, and severe illnesses.</p>What are the symptoms of <span class="qt0">hyperglycemia</span>?<p>The symptoms of <span class="qt0">hyperglycemia</span> include:</p><ul><li>Feeling thirsty</li><li>Feeling tired or weak</li><li>Headaches</li><li>Urinating (peeing) often</li><li>Blurred vision</li></ul><p>If you are diabetic and you often have high blood glucose levels or the symptoms of <span class="qt0">hyperglycemia</span>, talk with your health care team. You may need a change in your diabetes meal plan, physical activity plan, or diabetes medicines.</p><p>If you don't have diabetes and you are having these symptoms, see your provider to find out the cause and how to treat it.</p>What other problems can <span class="qt0">hyperglycemia</span> cause?<p>If <span class="qt0">hyperglycemia</span> is not treated, it can cause other problems. In people with diabetes, long-term <span class="qt0">hyperglycemia</span> can lead to serious health problems (diabetes complications).</p><p>If your blood glucose levels get very high, you can develop diabetes-related ketoacidosis (DKA). It happens when your body doesn't have enough insulin to allow blood glucose into your cells for use as energy. Instead, your liver breaks down fat for fuel. This process produces acids called ketones. When too many ketones are produced too fast, they can build up to dangerous levels in your body. This can be life-threatening.</p><p>The symptoms of DKA may include:</p><ul><li>Trouble breathing</li><li>Nausea or vomiting</li><li>Pain in your abdomen (belly)</li><li>Confusion</li><li>Feeling very tired or sleepy</li></ul><p>If you have an an at-home test for ketones, check your ketone level every 4 to 6 hours when your blood glucose is very high or when you are having these symptoms. If the test shows that your ketones are moderate or high, or if you don't have a ketones test, contact your health care provider right away or get emergency medical help.</p>How is <span class="qt0">hyperglycemia</span> diagnosed?<p>If you have diabetes, you'll most likely need to check your blood glucose every day and make sure that it's not too high. You can do this with a blood glucose meter or continuous glucose monitoring (CGM) system.</p><p>There are also blood tests that providers can use to check if your blood glucose is too high.</p><p></p>What are the treatments for <span class="qt0">hyperglycemia</span>?<p>If you have diabetes and often have high blood glucose, your health care team may make changes to your diabetes meal plan, physical activity plan, and/or diabetes medicines.</p><p>If you have severe <span class="qt0">hyperglycemia</span> and are having symptoms of DKA, you will need treatment at the hospital. The treatment often includes I.V. (intravenous) fluids and insulin.</p>Can <span class="qt0">hyperglycemia</span> be prevented?<p>If you have diabetes, managing your diabetes can help prevent <span class="qt0">hyperglycemia</span>. To manage your diabetes, it's important to:</p><ul><li>Follow your diabetes meal plan</li><li>Get regular physical activity</li><li>If you need diabetes medicines, take them correctly</li><li>Regularly check your blood glucose level</li><li>Get regular checkups with your health care team</li></ul>

Alzheimer's disease.name: <span class="qt0">Alzheimer</span>'s Caregivers
Alzheimer's disease.summary:
<p>A caregiver gives care to someone who needs help taking care of themselves. It can be rewarding. It may help to strengthen connections to a loved one. You may feel fulfillment from helping someone else. But sometimes caregiving can be stressful and even overwhelming. This can be especially true when caring for someone with <span class="qt0"><span class="qt2">Alzheimer</span></span><span class="qt2">'s </span><span class="qt1"><span class="qt2">disease</span></span> (AD).</p><p>AD is an <span class="qt1">illness</span> that changes the brain. It causes people to lose the ability to remember, think, and use good judgment. They also have trouble taking care of themselves. Over time, as the <span class="qt1">disease</span> gets worse, they will need more and more help. As a caregiver, it is important for you to learn about AD. You will want to know what happens to the person during the different stages of the <span class="qt1">disease</span>. This can help you plan for the future, so that you will have all of the resources you will need to be able to take care of your loved one.</p><p>As a caregiver for someone with AD, your responsibilities can include:</p><ul><li>Getting your loved one's health, legal, and financial affairs in order. If possible, include them in the planning while they can still make decisions. Later you will need to take over managing their finances and paying their bills.
</li><li>Evaluating their house and making sure it's safe for their needs</li><li>Monitoring their ability to drive. You may want to hire a driving specialist who can test their driving skills. When it is no longer safe for your loved one to drive, you need to make sure that they stop.</li><li>Encouraging your loved one to get some physical activity. Exercising together may make it more fun for them.</li><li>Making sure that your loved one has a healthy diet</li><li>Helping with daily tasks like bathing, eating, or taking medicine</li><li>Doing housework and cooking</li><li>Running errands such as shopping for food and clothes</li><li>Driving them to appointments</li><li>Providing company and emotional support</li><li>Arranging medical care and making health decisions</li></ul><p>As you care for your loved one with AD, don't ignore your own needs. Caregiving can be stressful, and you need to take care of your own physical and mental health.</p><p>At some point, you will not be able to do everything on your own. Make sure that you get help when you need it. There are many different services available, including:</p><ul><li>Home care services</li><li>Adult day care services</li><li>Respite services, which provide short-term care for the person with AD</li><li>Federal and state government programs that can provide financial support and services</li><li>Assisted living facilities</li><li>Nursing homes, some of which have special memory care units for people with AD</li><li>Palliative and hospice care</li></ul><p>You might consider hiring a geriatric care manager. They are specially trained professionals who can help you to find the right services for your needs.</p><p>NIH: National Institute on Aging</p>

Candidiasis.name: <span class="qt1">Yeast Infections</span>
Candidiasis.summary: <p>Candida is the scientific name for yeast. It is a fungus that lives almost everywhere, including in your body. Usually, your immune system keeps yeast under control. If you are sick or taking antibiotics, it can multiply and cause an infection. </p><p><span class="qt1">Yeast infections</span> affect different parts of the body in different ways:</p><ul><li>Thrush is a <span class="qt1">yeast infection</span> that causes white patches in your mouth </li><li>Candida esophagitis is thrush that spreads to your esophagus, the tube that takes food from your mouth to your stomach. It can make it hard or painful to swallow. </li><li>Women can get vaginal <span class="qt1">yeast infections</span>, causing vaginitis</li><li><span class="qt1">Yeast infections</span> of the skin cause itching and rashes </li><li><span class="qt1">Yeast infections</span> in your bloodstream can be life-threatening </li></ul><p>Antifungal medicines get rid of <span class="qt1">yeast infections</span> in most people. If you have a weak immune system, treatment might be more difficult.</p>

Fibroid tumor.name: Uterine <span class="qt0">Fibroids</span>
Fibroid tumor.summary: <p>Uterine <span class="qt0">fibroids</span> are the most common benign <span class="qt1">tumors</span> in women of childbearing age. <span class="qt0">Fibroids</span> are made of muscle cells and other tissues that grow in and around the wall of the uterus, or womb. The cause of <span class="qt0">fibroids</span> is unknown. Risk factors include being African American or being overweight.</p><p>Many women with <span class="qt0">fibroids</span> have no symptoms. If you do have symptoms, they may include:</p><ul><li>Heavy or painful periods or bleeding between periods </li><li>Feeling "full" in the lower abdomen </li><li>Urinating often </li><li>Pain during sex </li><li>Lower back pain </li><li>Reproductive problems, such as infertility, multiple miscarriages or early labor</li></ul><p>Your health care provider may find <span class="qt0">fibroids</span> during a gynecological exam or by using imaging tests.  Treatment includes drugs that can slow or stop their growth, or surgery.  If you have no symptoms, you may not even need treatment. Many women with <span class="qt0">fibroids</span> can get pregnant naturally. For those who cannot, infertility treatments may help.</p><p>NIH: National Institute of Child Health and Human Development</p>

Glaucoma.name: <span class="qt0">Glaucoma</span>
Glaucoma.summary: <p><span class="qt0">Glaucoma</span> is a group of diseases that can damage the eye's optic nerve. It is a leading cause of blindness in the United States. It usually happens when the fluid pressure inside the eyes slowly rises, damaging the optic nerve. Often there are no symptoms at first. Without treatment, people with <span class="qt0">glaucoma</span> will slowly lose their peripheral, or side vision. They seem to be looking through a tunnel. Over time, straight-ahead vision may decrease until no vision remains.</p><p>A comprehensive eye exam can tell if you have <span class="qt0">glaucoma</span>.  People at risk should get eye exams at least every two years.  They include:</p><ul><li>African Americans over age 40</li><li>People over age 60, especially Mexican Americans</li><li>People with a family history of <span class="qt0">glaucoma</span></li></ul><p>There is no cure, but <span class="qt0">glaucoma</span> can usually be controlled. Early treatment can help protect your eyes against vision loss. Treatments usually include prescription eyedrops and/or surgery.</p><p>NIH: National Eye Institute</p>

Neuropathy.name: Diabetic Nerve Problems
Neuropathy.summary: <p>If you have diabetes, your blood glucose, or blood sugar, levels are too high.  Over time, this can damage the covering on your nerves or the blood vessels that bring oxygen to your nerves. Damaged nerves may stop sending messages, or may send messages slowly or at the wrong times.  </p><p>This damage is called diabetic <span class="qt0">neuropathy</span>.  Over half of people with diabetes get it.  Symptoms may include:</p><ul><li>Numbness in your hands, legs, or feet</li><li>Shooting pains, burning, or tingling</li><li>Nausea, vomiting, constipation, or diarrhea</li><li>Problems with sexual function</li><li>Urinary problems</li><li>Dizziness when you change positions quickly</li></ul><p>Your doctor will diagnose diabetic <span class="qt0">neuropathy</span> with a physical exam and nerve tests. Controlling your blood sugar can help prevent nerve problems, or keep them from getting worse. Treatment may include pain relief and other medicines.</p><p>NIH: National Institute of Diabetes and Digestive and Kidney Diseases</p>

Neoplasm metastasis.name: Bone <span class="qt0"><span class="qt1">Cancer</span></span>
Neoplasm metastasis.summary: <p><span class="qt0"><span class="qt1">Cancer</span></span> that starts in a bone is uncommon.  <span class="qt0"><span class="qt1">Cancer</span></span> that has spread to the bone from another part of the body is more common. </p><p>There are three types of bone <span class="qt0"><span class="qt1">cancer</span></span>:</p><ul><li>Osteosarcoma - occurs most often between ages 10 and 19. It is more common in the knee and upper arm.</li><li>Chondrosarcoma - starts in cartilage, usually after age 40</li><li>Ewing's <span class="qt0"><span class="qt1">sarcoma</span></span> - occurs most often in children and teens under 19. It is more common in boys than girls.</li></ul><p>The most common symptom of bone <span class="qt0"><span class="qt1">cancer</span></span> is pain. Other symptoms vary, depending on the location and size of the <span class="qt0"><span class="qt1">cancer</span></span>. Surgery is often the main treatment for bone <span class="qt0"><span class="qt1">cancer</span></span>. Other treatments may include amputation, chemotherapy, and radiation therapy. Because bone <span class="qt0"><span class="qt1">cancer</span></span> can come back after treatment, regular follow-up visits are important.</p><p>NIH: National <span class="qt0"><span class="qt1">Cancer</span></span> Institute</p>

Tonic-clonic epilepsy.name: Seizures
Tonic-clonic epilepsy.summary:
<p>Seizures are symptoms of a brain problem. They happen because of sudden, abnormal 
electrical activity in the brain. When people think of seizures, they often think of convulsions in which a person's body 
shakes rapidly and uncontrollably. Not all seizures cause convulsions. There are many types 
of seizures and some have mild symptoms. Seizures fall into two main groups. Focal 
seizures, also called partial seizures, happen in just one part of the brain. Generalized 
seizures are a result of abnormal activity on both sides of the brain. </p><p>Most seizures last from 30 seconds to 2 minutes and do not cause lasting harm. However, 
it is a medical emergency if seizures last longer than 5 minutes or if a person has many 
seizures and does not wake up between them. Seizures can have many causes, including 
medicines, high fevers, head injuries and certain diseases.  People who have recurring 
seizures due to a brain disorder have <span class="qt1">epilepsy</span>. </p><p>NIH: National Institute of Neurological Disorders and Stroke</p>

Malignant tumor of colon.name: <span class="qt3">Colorectal</span> <span class="qt1">Cancer</span>

Kidney disease.name: <span class="qt0">Kidney</span> Cysts
Kidney disease.summary: <p> A cyst is a fluid-filled sac. You may get simple <span class="qt0">kidney</span> cysts as you age; they are usually harmless. There are also some <span class="qt1">diseases</span> which cause <span class="qt0">kidney</span> cysts. One type is polycystic <span class="qt0"><span class="qt2">kidney</span></span><span class="qt2"> </span><span class="qt1"><span class="qt2">disease</span></span> (PKD). It runs in families. In PKD, many cysts grow in the <span class="qt0">kidneys</span>. This can enlarge the <span class="qt0">kidneys</span> and make them work poorly. About half of people with the most common type of PKD end up with <span class="qt0">kidney</span> failure. PKD also causes cysts in other parts of the body, such as the liver. </p><p>Often, there are no symptoms at first. Later, symptoms include:</p><ul><li>Pain in the back and lower sides</li><li>Headaches</li><li>Blood in the urine</li></ul><p>Doctors diagnose PKD with imaging tests and family history. There is no cure. Treatments can help with symptoms and complications. They include medicines and lifestyle changes, and if there is <span class="qt0">kidney</span> failure, dialysis or <span class="qt0">kidney</span> transplants.</p><p>Acquired cystic <span class="qt0"><span class="qt2">kidney</span></span><span class="qt2"> </span><span class="qt1"><span class="qt2">disease</span></span> (ACKD) happens in people who have chronic <span class="qt0"><span class="qt2">kidney</span></span><span class="qt2"> </span><span class="qt1"><span class="qt2">disease</span></span>, especially if they are on dialysis. Unlike PKD, the <span class="qt0">kidneys</span> are normal sized, and cysts do not form in other parts of the body. ACKD often has no symptoms. Usually, the cysts are harmless and do not need treatment. If they do cause complications, treatments include medicines, draining the cysts, or surgery.</p><p>NIH: National Institute of Diabetes and Digestive and <span class="qt0"><span class="qt2">Kidney</span></span><span class="qt2"> </span><span class="qt1"><span class="qt2">Diseases</span></span></p>

Ketoacidosis diabetic.name: Hyperglycemia
Ketoacidosis diabetic.summary: What is blood glucose?<p>Blood glucose, or blood sugar, is the main sugar found in your blood. It is your body's primary source of energy. It comes from the food you eat. Your body breaks down most of that food into glucose and releases it into your bloodstream. When your blood glucose goes up, it signals your pancreas to release insulin. Insulin is a hormone that helps the glucose get into your cells to be used for energy.</p><p>For people with diabetes, your body doesn't make enough insulin, can't use it as well as it should, or both. Too much glucose stays in your blood and doesn't reach your cells.</p>What is hyperglycemia?<p>Hyperglycemia means high blood glucose. It most often affects people who have diabetes. When you have diabetes, your body doesn't make enough insulin or can't use it the right way. Too much glucose stays in your blood and doesn't reach your cells.  </p>What causes hyperglycemia?<p>A key part of managing diabetes is controlling your blood glucose levels. To do this, you need to follow a diabetes meal plan and get regular physical activity. You might also need to take diabetes medicines. You have to balance all of these to keep your blood glucose at the right levels. But if you eat too much food or the wrong foods, don't take your medicines correctly, or don't get physical activity, you can get hyperglycemia. It can also happen if you are stressed or sick.</p><p>Less commonly, people who don't have diabetes can also get hyperglycemia. It can be caused by conditions that can affect insulin or glucose levels in your blood. They include problems with your pancreas or adrenal glands, certain medicines, and severe illnesses.</p>What are the symptoms of hyperglycemia?<p>The symptoms of hyperglycemia include:</p><ul><li>Feeling thirsty</li><li>Feeling tired or weak</li><li>Headaches</li><li>Urinating (peeing) often</li><li>Blurred vision</li></ul><p>If you are <span class="qt2">diabetic</span> and you often have high blood glucose levels or the symptoms of hyperglycemia, talk with your health care team. You may need a change in your diabetes meal plan, physical activity plan, or diabetes medicines.</p><p>If you don't have diabetes and you are having these symptoms, see your provider to find out the cause and how to treat it.</p>What other problems can hyperglycemia cause?<p>If hyperglycemia is not treated, it can cause other problems. In people with diabetes, long-term hyperglycemia can lead to serious health problems (diabetes complications).</p><p>If your blood glucose levels get very high, you can develop diabetes-related <span class="qt0">ketoacidosis</span> (DKA). It happens when your body doesn't have enough insulin to allow blood glucose into your cells for use as energy. Instead, your liver breaks down fat for fuel. This process produces acids called ketones. When too many ketones are produced too fast, they can build up to dangerous levels in your body. This can be life-threatening.</p><p>The symptoms of DKA may include:</p><ul><li>Trouble breathing</li><li>Nausea or vomiting</li><li>Pain in your abdomen (belly)</li><li>Confusion</li><li>Feeling very tired or sleepy</li></ul><p>If you have an an at-home test for ketones, check your ketone level every 4 to 6 hours when your blood glucose is very high or when you are having these symptoms. If the test shows that your ketones are moderate or high, or if you don't have a ketones test, contact your health care provider right away or get emergency medical help.</p>How is hyperglycemia diagnosed?<p>If you have diabetes, you'll most likely need to check your blood glucose every day and make sure that it's not too high. You can do this with a blood glucose meter or continuous glucose monitoring (CGM) system.</p><p>There are also blood tests that providers can use to check if your blood glucose is too high.</p><p></p>What are the treatments for hyperglycemia?<p>If you have diabetes and often have high blood glucose, your health care team may make changes to your diabetes meal plan, physical activity plan, and/or diabetes medicines.</p><p>If you have severe hyperglycemia and are having symptoms of DKA, you will need treatment at the hospital. The treatment often includes I.V. (intravenous) fluids and insulin.</p>Can hyperglycemia be prevented?<p>If you have diabetes, managing your diabetes can help prevent hyperglycemia. To manage your diabetes, it's important to:</p><ul><li>Follow your diabetes meal plan</li><li>Get regular physical activity</li><li>If you need diabetes medicines, take them correctly</li><li>Regularly check your blood glucose level</li><li>Get regular checkups with your health care team</li></ul>

Respiratory failure.name: <span class="qt0">Respiratory</span> <span class="qt1">Failure</span>
Respiratory failure.summary:
What is <span class="qt0">respiratory</span> <span class="qt1">failure</span>?<p><span class="qt0">Respiratory</span> <span class="qt1">failure</span> is a condition in which your blood doesn't have enough oxygen or has too much carbon dioxide. Sometimes you can have both problems.</p><p>When you breathe, your lungs take in oxygen. The oxygen passes into your blood, which carries it to your organs. Your organs, such as your heart and brain, need this oxygen-rich blood to work well.</p><p>Another part of breathing is removing the carbon dioxide from the blood and breathing it out. Having too much carbon dioxide in your blood can harm your organs.</p>What causes <span class="qt0">respiratory</span> <span class="qt1">failure</span>?<p>Conditions that affect your breathing can cause <span class="qt0">respiratory</span> <span class="qt1">failure</span>. These conditions may affect the muscles, nerves, bones, or tissues that support breathing. Or they may affect the lungs directly. These conditions include:</p><ul><li>Diseases that affect the lungs, such as COPD (chronic obstructive pulmonary disease), cystic fibrosis, pneumonia, pulmonary embolism, and COVID-19</li><li>Conditions that affect the nerves and muscles that control breathing, such as amyotrophic lateral sclerosis (ALS), muscular dystrophy, spinal cord injuries, and stroke
</li><li>Problems with the spine, such as scoliosis (a curve in the spine). They can affect the bones and muscles used for breathing.</li><li>Damage to the tissues and ribs around the lungs. An injury to the chest can cause this damage.</li><li>Drug or alcohol overdose</li><li>Inhalation injuries, such as from inhaling smoke (from fires) or harmful fumes</li></ul>What are the symptoms of <span class="qt0">respiratory</span> <span class="qt1">failure</span>?<p>The symptoms of <span class="qt0">respiratory</span> <span class="qt1">failure</span> depend on the cause and the levels of oxygen and carbon dioxide in your blood.</p><p>A low oxygen level in the blood can cause shortness of breath and air hunger (the feeling that you can't breathe in enough air). Your skin, lips, and fingernails may also have a bluish color. A high carbon dioxide level can cause rapid breathing and confusion.</p><p>Some people who have <span class="qt0">respiratory</span> <span class="qt1">failure</span> may become very sleepy or lose consciousness. They also may have arrhythmia (irregular heartbeat). You may have these symptoms if your brain and heart are not getting enough oxygen.</p>How is <span class="qt0">respiratory</span> <span class="qt1">failure</span> diagnosed?<p>Your health care provider will diagnose <span class="qt0">respiratory</span> <span class="qt1">failure</span> based on:</p><ul><li>Your medical history</li><li>A physical exam, which often includes</li><ul><li>Listening to your lungs to check for abnormal sounds</li><li>Listening to your heart to check for arrhythmia</li><li>Looking for a bluish color on your skin, lips, and fingernails</li></ul><li>Diagnostic tests, such as</li><ul><li>Pulse oximetry, a small sensor that uses a light to measure how much oxygen is in your blood. The sensor goes on the end of your finger or on your ear.</li><li>Arterial blood gas test, a test that measures the oxygen and carbon dioxide levels in your blood. The blood sample is taken from an artery, usually in your wrist.</li></ul></ul><p>Once you are diagnosed with <span class="qt0">respiratory</span> <span class="qt1">failure</span>, your provider will look for what is causing it. Tests for this often include a chest x-ray. If your provider thinks you may have arrhythmia because of the <span class="qt0">respiratory</span> <span class="qt1">failure</span>, you may have an EKG (electrocardiogram). This is simple, painless test that detects and records your heart's electrical activity.</p>What are the treatments for <span class="qt0">respiratory</span> <span class="qt1">failure</span>?<p>Treatment for <span class="qt0">respiratory</span> <span class="qt1">failure</span> depends on:</p><ul><li>Whether it is acute (short-term) or chronic (ongoing)</li><li>How severe it is</li><li>What is causing it</li></ul><p>Acute <span class="qt0">respiratory</span> <span class="qt1">failure</span> can be a medical emergency. You may need treatment in intensive care unit at a hospital. Chronic <span class="qt0">respiratory</span> <span class="qt1">failure</span> can often be treated at home. But if your chronic <span class="qt0">respiratory</span> <span class="qt1">failure</span> is severe, you might need treatment in a long-term care center.</p><p>One of the main goals of treatment is to get oxygen to your lungs and other organs and remove carbon dioxide from your body. Another goal is to treat the cause of the condition. Treatments may include:</p><ul><li>Oxygen therapy, through a nasal cannula (two small plastic tubes that go in your nostrils) or through a mask that fits over your nose and mouth</li><li>Tracheostomy, a surgically-made hole that goes through the front of your neck and into your windpipe. A breathing tube, also called a tracheostomy, or trach tube, is placed in the hole to help you breathe.</li><li>Ventilator, a breathing machine that blows air into your lungs. It also carries carbon dioxide out of your lungs.</li><li>Other breathing treatments, such as noninvasive positive pressure ventilation (NPPV), which uses mild air pressure to keep your airways open while you sleep. Another treatment is a special bed that rocks back and forth, to help you breathe in and out.</li><li>Fluids, often through an intravenous (IV), to improve blood flow throughout your body. They also provide nutrition.</li><li>Medicines for discomfort</li><li>Treatments for the cause of the <span class="qt0">respiratory</span> <span class="qt1">failure</span>. These treatments may include medicines and procedures.</li></ul><p>If you have <span class="qt0">respiratory</span> <span class="qt1">failure</span>, see your health care provider for ongoing medical care. Your provider may suggest pulmonary rehabilitation.</p><p>If your <span class="qt0">respiratory</span> <span class="qt1">failure</span> is chronic, make sure that you know when and where to get help for your symptoms. You need emergency care if you have severe symptoms, such as trouble catching your breath or talking. You should call your provider if you notice that your symptoms are worsening or if you have new signs and symptoms.</p><p>Living with <span class="qt0">respiratory</span> <span class="qt1">failure</span> may cause fear, anxiety, depression, and stress. Talk therapy, medicines, and support groups can help you feel better.</p><p>NIH: National Heart, Lung, and Blood Institute</p>

Tonic-clonic seizures.name: <span class="qt1"><span class="qt2">Seizures</span></span>
Tonic-clonic seizures.summary:
<p><span class="qt1"><span class="qt2">Seizures</span></span> are symptoms of a brain problem. They happen because of sudden, abnormal 
electrical activity in the brain. When people think of <span class="qt1"><span class="qt2">seizures</span></span>, they often think of convulsions in which a person's body 
shakes rapidly and uncontrollably. Not all <span class="qt1"><span class="qt2">seizures</span></span> cause convulsions. There are many types 
of <span class="qt1"><span class="qt2">seizures</span></span> and some have mild symptoms. <span class="qt1"><span class="qt2">Seizures</span></span> fall into two main groups. Focal 
<span class="qt1"><span class="qt2">seizures</span></span>, also called partial <span class="qt1"><span class="qt2">seizures</span></span>, happen in just one part of the brain. Generalized 
<span class="qt1"><span class="qt2">seizures</span></span> are a result of abnormal activity on both sides of the brain. </p><p>Most <span class="qt1"><span class="qt2">seizures</span></span> last from 30 seconds to 2 minutes and do not cause lasting harm. However, 
it is a medical emergency if <span class="qt1"><span class="qt2">seizures</span></span> last longer than 5 minutes or if a person has many 
<span class="qt1"><span class="qt2">seizures</span></span> and does not wake up between them. <span class="qt1"><span class="qt2">Seizures</span></span> can have many causes, including 
medicines, high fevers, head injuries and certain diseases.  People who have recurring 
<span class="qt1"><span class="qt2">seizures</span></span> due to a brain disorder have epilepsy. </p><p>NIH: National Institute of Neurological Disorders and Stroke</p>

Carcinoma of lung.name: <span class="qt4">Lung</span> <span class="qt0"><span class="qt1">Cancer</span></span>

Melanoma.name: <span class="qt0">Melanoma</span>
Melanoma.summary: <p><span class="qt0">Melanoma</span> is the most serious type of <span class="qt0">skin cancer</span>.  Often the first sign of <span class="qt0">melanoma</span> is a change in the size, shape, color, or feel of a mole. Most <span class="qt1">melanomas</span> have a black or black-blue area. <span class="qt0">Melanoma</span> may also appear as a new mole. It may be black, abnormal, or "ugly looking."</p><p>Thinking of "ABCDE" can help you remember what to watch for:</p><ul><li> Asymmetry - the shape of one half does not match the other</li><li> Border - the edges are ragged, blurred or irregular</li><li> Color - the color is uneven and may include shades of black, brown and tan</li><li> Diameter - there is a change in size, usually an increase</li><li>Evolving - the mole has changed over the past few weeks or months</li></ul><p>Surgery is the first treatment of all stages of <span class="qt0">melanoma</span>. Other treatments include chemotherapy and radiation, biologic, and targeted therapies.  Biologic therapy boosts your body's own ability to fight cancer. Targeted therapy uses substances that attack cancer cells without harming normal cells.</p><p>NIH: National Cancer Institute</p>

Malignant neoplasms.name: <span class="qt1">Cancer</span>
Malignant neoplasms.summary: <p><span class="qt1">Cancer</span> begins in your cells, which are the building blocks of your body.   Normally, your body forms new cells as you need them, replacing old cells that die. Sometimes this process goes wrong. New cells grow even when you don't need them, and old cells don't die when they should. These extra cells can form a mass called a <span class="qt1">tumor. Tumors</span> can be benign or malignant. Benign <span class="qt1">tumors</span> aren't <span class="qt1">cancer</span> while malignant ones are. Cells from <span class="qt0">malignant <span class="qt1">tumors</span></span> can invade nearby tissues. They can also break away and spread to other parts of the body. </p><p><span class="qt1">Cancer</span> is not just one disease but many diseases. There are more than 100 different types of <span class="qt1">cancer</span>. Most <span class="qt1">cancers</span> are named for where they start. For example, lung <span class="qt1">cancer</span> starts in the lung, and breast <span class="qt1">cancer</span> starts in the breast. The spread of <span class="qt1">cancer</span> from one part of the body to another is called metastasis. Symptoms and treatment depend on the <span class="qt1">cancer</span> type and how advanced it is. Most treatment plans may include surgery, radiation and/or chemotherapy. Some may involve hormone therapy, immunotherapy or other types of biologic therapy, or stem cell transplantation. </p><p>NIH: National <span class="qt1">Cancer</span> Institute</p>

Gastroenteritis.name: <span class="qt0">Gastroenteritis</span>

Personality disorder.name: <span class="qt0"><span class="qt2">Personality</span></span><span class="qt2"> </span><span class="qt1"><span class="qt2">Disorders</span></span>
Personality disorder.summary: What is <span class="qt0">personality</span>?<p>Your <span class="qt0">personality</span> is your own way of thinking, feeling, behaving, and relating to others. Once you become an adult, your <span class="qt0">personality</span> usually doesn't change much.</p>What are <span class="qt0"><span class="qt2">personality</span></span><span class="qt2"> </span><span class="qt1"><span class="qt2">disorders</span></span>?<p><span class="qt0"><span class="qt2">Personality</span></span><span class="qt2"> </span><span class="qt1"><span class="qt2">disorders</span></span> are a group of mental <span class="qt1">disorders</span>. They involve long-term patterns of thoughts and behaviors that are different from what is considered normal in your culture. The thoughts and behaviors are unhealthy and inflexible. They cause serious problems with relationships, work, and social activities. They can make it hard to deal with everyday stresses and problems.</p>What are the types of <span class="qt0"><span class="qt2">personality</span></span><span class="qt2"> </span><span class="qt1"><span class="qt2">disorders</span></span>?<p>There are 10 types of <span class="qt0"><span class="qt2">personality</span></span><span class="qt2"> </span><span class="qt1"><span class="qt2">disorders</span></span>. They are grouped into three different categories called clusters. The types in each cluster have some similar symptoms and characteristics. The clusters and types are:</p><p>Cluster A <span class="qt0"><span class="qt2">personality</span></span><span class="qt2"> </span><span class="qt1"><span class="qt2">disorders</span></span> involve unusual and odd thoughts and behaviors. It includes:</p><ul><li>Paranoid <span class="qt0"><span class="qt2">personality</span></span><span class="qt2"> </span><span class="qt1"><span class="qt2">disorder</span></span>, in which a person has paranoia (an extreme fear and distrust of others). They may think that someone is trying to harm them.</li><li>Schizoid <span class="qt0"><span class="qt2">personality</span></span><span class="qt2"> </span><span class="qt1"><span class="qt2">disorder</span></span>, in which a person prefers to be alone and is not interested in having relationships with others.</li><li>Schizotypal <span class="qt0"><span class="qt2">personality</span></span><span class="qt2"> </span><span class="qt1"><span class="qt2">disorder</span></span>, in which a person has unusual thoughts and ways of behaving and speaking. They are uncomfortable having close relationships with others.</li></ul><p>Cluster B <span class="qt0"><span class="qt2">personality</span></span><span class="qt2"> </span><span class="qt1"><span class="qt2">disorders</span></span> involve dramatic and emotional thoughts and behaviors that can keep changing. It includes:</p><ul><li>Antisocial <span class="qt0"><span class="qt2">personality</span></span><span class="qt2"> </span><span class="qt1"><span class="qt2">disorder</span></span>, in which a person has a long-term pattern of manipulating, exploiting, or violating the rights of others.</li><li>Borderline <span class="qt0"><span class="qt2">personality</span></span><span class="qt2"> </span><span class="qt1"><span class="qt2">disorder</span></span>, in which a person has lots of trouble managing their emotions. This makes them impulsive and uncertain about how they see themselves. It can cause a lot of trouble in their relationships.</li><li>Histrionic <span class="qt0"><span class="qt2">personality</span></span><span class="qt2"> </span><span class="qt1"><span class="qt2">disorder</span></span>, in which a person is dramatic, has strong emotions, and always wants attention from others.</li><li>Narcissistic <span class="qt0"><span class="qt2">personality</span></span><span class="qt2"> </span><span class="qt1"><span class="qt2">disorder</span></span>, in which a person lacks empathy and wants to be admired by others. They think that they are better than others and that they deserve special treatment.</li></ul><p>Cluster C <span class="qt0"><span class="qt2">personality</span></span><span class="qt2"> </span><span class="qt1"><span class="qt2">disorders</span></span> involve anxious and fearful thoughts and behaviors. It includes:</p><ul><li>Avoidant <span class="qt0"><span class="qt2">personality</span></span><span class="qt2"> </span><span class="qt1"><span class="qt2">disorder</span></span>, in which a person is very shy and feels that they are not as good as others. They often avoid people because they fear rejection.</li><li>Dependent <span class="qt0"><span class="qt2">personality</span></span><span class="qt2"> </span><span class="qt1"><span class="qt2">disorder</span></span>, in which a person depends too much on others and feels that they need to be taken care of. They may let others treat them badly because they are afraid of losing the relationship.</li><li>Obsessive-compulsive <span class="qt0"><span class="qt2">personality</span></span><span class="qt2"> </span><span class="qt1"><span class="qt2">disorder</span></span>, in which a person needs control and order. They are perfectionists and can be inflexible. Although some of the symptoms are similar, this is not the same thing as obsessive-compulsive <span class="qt1">disorder</span> (OCD).</li></ul>What causes <span class="qt0"><span class="qt2">personality</span></span><span class="qt2"> </span><span class="qt1"><span class="qt2">disorders</span></span>?<p><span class="qt0"><span class="qt2">Personality</span></span><span class="qt2"> </span><span class="qt1"><span class="qt2">disorders</span></span> usually begin when someone is in their teens or early adult years. The cause is unknown. However, genes and childhood experiences such as abuse and trauma likely play a role.</p>What are the symptoms of <span class="qt0"><span class="qt2">personality</span></span><span class="qt2"> </span><span class="qt1"><span class="qt2">disorders</span></span>?<p>The symptoms of each <span class="qt0"><span class="qt2">personality</span></span><span class="qt2"> </span><span class="qt1"><span class="qt2">disorder</span></span> are different. But each <span class="qt1">disorder</span> involves problems and uncertainty with how people see themselves. The <span class="qt1">disorders</span> also cause problems in relationships with other people.</p><p>People with <span class="qt0"><span class="qt2">personality</span></span><span class="qt2"> </span><span class="qt1"><span class="qt2">disorders</span></span> may have trouble realizing that they have a problem. To them, their thoughts are normal. They may see others as the problem. So they may not seek help when they need it. Or, if they seek help, it may be because of another reason. They may be looking for help because of other mental health symptoms or problems with relationships and work. Sometimes someone else, such as a family member or social agency, may ask them to get help.</p>How are <span class="qt0"><span class="qt2">personality</span></span><span class="qt2"> </span><span class="qt1"><span class="qt2">disorders</span></span> diagnosed?<p>A mental health care provider can diagnose <span class="qt0"><span class="qt2">personality</span></span><span class="qt2"> </span><span class="qt1"><span class="qt2">disorders</span></span>. A mental health provider is a health care professional who specializes in diagnosing and treating mental health problems. To make a diagnosis, the provider will consider the person's symptoms, experiences, and family medical history. A thorough medical exam may also be done to help rule out other possible causes of the symptoms.</p>How are <span class="qt0"><span class="qt2">personality</span></span><span class="qt2"> </span><span class="qt1"><span class="qt2">disorders</span></span> treated?<p>Talk therapy, also known as psychotherapy, is the main treatment for <span class="qt0"><span class="qt2">personality</span></span><span class="qt2"> </span><span class="qt1"><span class="qt2">disorders</span></span>. Medicines may help relieve certain symptoms, such as anxiety or mood swings.</p>

Malignant neoplasm of lung.name: <span class="qt3"><span class="qt4">Lung</span></span><span class="qt4"> </span><span class="qt1"><span class="qt4">Cancer</span></span>

Manic disorder.name: <span class="qt2">Bipolar </span><span class="qt1"><span class="qt2">Disorder</span></span>

Hemorrhoids.name: <span class="qt0">Hemorrhoids</span>
Hemorrhoids.summary: What are <span class="qt0">hemorrhoids</span>?<p><span class="qt0">Hemorrhoids</span> are swollen, inflamed veins around your anus or the lower part of your rectum. There are two types:</p><ul><li>External <span class="qt0">hemorrhoids</span>, which form under the skin around your anus</li><li>Internal <span class="qt0">hemorrhoids</span>, which form in the lining of your anus and lower rectum</li></ul>What causes <span class="qt0">hemorrhoids</span>?<p><span class="qt0">Hemorrhoids</span> happen when there is too much pressure on the veins around the anus. This can be caused by:</p><ul><li>Straining during bowel movements</li><li>Sitting on the toilet for long periods of time</li><li>Chronic constipation or diarrhea</li><li>A low-fiber diet</li><li>Weakening of the supporting tissues in your anus and rectum. This can happen with aging and pregnancy.</li><li>Frequently lifting heavy objects</li></ul>What are the symptoms of <span class="qt0">hemorrhoids</span>?<p>The symptoms of <span class="qt0">hemorrhoids</span> depend on which type you have:</p><p>With external <span class="qt0">hemorrhoids</span>, you may have:</p><ul><li>Anal itching</li><li>One or more hard, tender lumps near your anus</li><li>Anal pain, especially when sitting</li></ul><p>Too much straining, rubbing, or cleaning around your anus may make your symptoms worse. For many people, the symptoms of external <span class="qt0">hemorrhoids</span> go away within a few days.</p><p>With internal <span class="qt0">hemorrhoids</span>, you may have:</p><ul><li>Bleeding from your rectum - you would see bright red blood in your stool, on toilet paper, or in the toilet bowl after a bowel movement</li><li>Prolapse, which is a <span class="qt0">hemorrhoid</span> that has fallen through your anal opening</li></ul><p>Internal <span class="qt0">hemorrhoids</span> are usually not painful unless they are prolapsed. Prolapsed internal <span class="qt0">hemorrhoids</span> may cause pain and discomfort.</p>How can I treat <span class="qt0">hemorrhoids</span> at home?<p>You can most often treat your <span class="qt0">hemorrhoids</span> at home by:</p><ul><li>Eating foods that are high in fiber</li><li>Taking a stool softener or a fiber supplement</li><li>Drinking enough fluids every day</li><li>Not straining during bowel movements</li><li>Not sitting on the toilet for long periods of time</li><li>Taking over-the-counter pain relievers</li><li>Taking warm baths several times a day to help relieve pain. This could be a regular bath or a sitz bath. With a sitz bath, you use a special plastic tub that allows you to sit in a few inches of warm water.</li><li>Using over-the-counter <span class="qt0">hemorrhoid</span> creams, ointments, or suppositories to relieve mild pain, swelling, and itching of external <span class="qt0">hemorrhoids</span></li></ul>When do I need to see a health care provider for <span class="qt0">hemorrhoids</span>?<p>You should see your health care provider if you:</p><ul><li>Still have symptoms after 1 week of at-home treatment</li><li>Have bleeding from your rectum. <span class="qt0">Hemorrhoids</span> are a common cause of bleeding, but other conditions can also cause bleeding. They include Crohn's disease, ulcerative colitis, colorectal cancer, and anal cancer. So it's important to see your provider to find the cause of the bleeding.</li></ul>How are <span class="qt0">hemorrhoids</span> diagnosed?<p>To make a diagnosis, your health care provider:</p><ul><li>Will ask about your medical history</li><li>Will do a physical exam. Often providers can diagnose external <span class="qt0">hemorrhoids</span> by looking at the area around your anus.</li><li>Will do a digital rectal exam to check for internal <span class="qt0">hemorrhoids</span>. For this, the provider will insert a lubricated, gloved finger into the rectum to feel for anything that is abnormal.</li><li>May do procedures such as an anoscopy to check for internal <span class="qt0">hemorrhoids</span></li></ul>What are the treatments for <span class="qt0">hemorrhoids</span>?<p>If at-home treatments for <span class="qt0">hemorrhoids</span> don't help you, you may need a medical procedure. There are several different procedures that your provider can do in the office. These procedures use different techniques to cause scar tissue to form in the <span class="qt0">hemorrhoids</span>. This cuts off the blood supply, which usually shrinks the <span class="qt0">hemorrhoids</span>. In severe cases, you may need surgery.</p>Can <span class="qt0">hemorrhoids</span> be prevented?<p>You can help prevent <span class="qt0">hemorrhoids</span> by:</p><ul><li>Eating foods that are high in fiber</li><li>Taking a stool softener or a fiber supplement</li><li>Drinking enough fluids every day</li><li>Not straining during bowel movements</li><li>Not sitting on the toilet for long periods of time</li></ul><p>NIH: National Institute of Diabetes and Digestive and Kidney Diseases</p>

Emphysema pulmonary.name: <span class="qt0">Emphysema</span>
Emphysema pulmonary.summary:
What is <span class="qt0">emphysema</span>?<p><span class="qt0">Emphysema</span> is a type of <span class="qt2"><span class="qt3">COPD</span></span> (chronic obstructive <span class="qt2"><span class="qt3">pulmonary</span></span> disease). <span class="qt2"><span class="qt3">COPD</span></span> is a group of <span class="qt2"><span class="qt3">lung</span></span> diseases that make it hard to breathe and get worse over time. The other main type of <span class="qt2"><span class="qt3">COPD</span></span> is chronic bronchitis. Most people with <span class="qt2"><span class="qt3">COPD</span></span> have both <span class="qt0">emphysema</span> and chronic bronchitis, but how severe each type is can be different from person to person.</p><p><span class="qt0">Emphysema</span> affects the air sacs in your <span class="qt2"><span class="qt3">lungs</span></span>. Normally, these sacs are elastic or stretchy. When you breathe in, each air sac fills up with air, like a small balloon. When you breathe out, the air sacs deflate, and the air goes out.</p><p>In <span class="qt0">emphysema</span>, the walls between many of the air sacs in the <span class="qt2"><span class="qt3">lungs</span></span> are damaged. This causes the air sacs to lose their shape and become floppy. The damage also can destroy the walls of the air sacs, leading to fewer and larger air sacs instead of many tiny ones. This makes it harder for your <span class="qt2"><span class="qt3">lungs</span></span> to move oxygen in and carbon dioxide out of your body.</p>What causes <span class="qt0">emphysema</span>?<p>The cause of <span class="qt0">emphysema</span> is usually long-term exposure to irritants that damage your <span class="qt2"><span class="qt3">lungs</span></span> and the airways. In the United States, cigarette smoke is the main cause. Pipe, cigar, and other types of tobacco smoke can also cause <span class="qt0">emphysema</span>, especially if you inhale them.</p><p>Exposure to other inhaled irritants can contribute to <span class="qt0">emphysema</span>. These include secondhand smoke, air pollution, and chemical fumes or dusts from the environment or workplace.</p><p>Rarely, a genetic condition called alpha-1 antitrypsin deficiency can play a role in causing <span class="qt0">emphysema</span>.</p>Who is at risk for <span class="qt0">emphysema</span>?<p>The risk factors for <span class="qt0">emphysema</span> include:</p><ul><li>Smoking. This the main risk factor. Up to 75% of people who have <span class="qt0">emphysema</span> smoke or used to smoke.</li><li>Long-term exposure to other <span class="qt2"><span class="qt3">lung</span></span> irritants, such as secondhand smoke, air pollution, and chemical fumes and dusts from the environment or workplace.</li><li>Age. Most people who have <span class="qt0">emphysema</span> are at least 40 years old when their symptoms begin.</li><li>Genetics. This includes alpha-1 antitrypsin deficiency, which is a genetic condition. Also, smokers who get <span class="qt0">emphysema</span> are more likely to get it if they have a family history of <span class="qt2"><span class="qt3">COPD</span></span>.</li></ul>What are the symptoms of <span class="qt0">emphysema</span>?<p>At first, you may have no symptoms or only mild symptoms. As the disease gets worse, your symptoms usually become more severe. They can include:</p><ul><li>Frequent coughing or wheezing</li><li>A cough that produces a lot mucus</li><li>Shortness of breath, especially with physical activity</li><li>A whistling or squeaky sound when you breathe</li><li>Tightness in your chest</li></ul><p>Some people with <span class="qt0">emphysema</span> get frequent respiratory infections such as colds and the flu. In severe cases, <span class="qt0">emphysema</span> can cause weight loss, weakness in your lower muscles, and swelling in your ankles, feet, or legs.</p>How is <span class="qt0">emphysema</span> diagnosed?<p>Your health care provider may use many tools to make a diagnosis:</p><ul><li>A medical history, which includes asking about your symptoms</li><li>A family history</li><li>Other tests tests, such as <span class="qt2"><span class="qt3">lung</span></span> function tests, a chest x-ray or CT scan, and blood tests</li></ul>What are the treatments for <span class="qt0">emphysema</span>?<p>There is no cure for <span class="qt0">emphysema</span>. However, treatments can help with symptoms, slow the progress of the disease, and improve your ability to stay active. There are also treatments to prevent or treat complications of the disease. Treatments include:</p><ul><li>Lifestyle changes, such as
	<ul><li>Quitting smoking if you are a smoker. This is the most important step you can take to treat <span class="qt0">emphysema</span>.</li><li>Avoiding secondhand smoke and places where you might breathe in other <span class="qt2"><span class="qt3">lung</span></span> irritants</li><li>Ask your health care provider for an eating plan that will meet your nutritional needs. Also ask about how much physical activity you can do. Physical activity can strengthen the muscles that help you breathe and improve your overall wellness.</li></ul></li><li>Medicines, such as
	<ul><li>Bronchodilators, which relax the muscles around your airways. This helps open your airways and makes breathing easier. Most bronchodilators are taken through an inhaler. In more severe cases, the inhaler may also contain steroids to reduce inflammation.</li><li>Vaccines for the flu and pneumococcal pneumonia, since people with <span class="qt0">emphysema</span> are at higher risk for serious problems from these diseases</li><li>Antibiotics if you get a bacterial or viral <span class="qt2"><span class="qt3">lung</span></span> infection</li></ul></li><li>Oxygen therapy, if you have severe <span class="qt0">emphysema</span> and low levels of oxygen in your blood. Oxygen therapy can help you breathe better. You may need extra oxygen all the time or only at certain times.</li><li><span class="qt2"><span class="qt3">Pulmonary</span></span> rehabilitation, which is a program that helps improve the well-being of people who have chronic breathing problems. It may include
	<ul><li>An exercise program</li><li>Disease management training</li><li>Nutritional counseling</li><li>Psychological counseling</li></ul></li><li>Surgery, usually as a last resort for people who have severe symptoms that have not gotten better with medicines. There are surgeries to 
	<ul><li>Remove damaged <span class="qt2"><span class="qt3">lung</span></span> tissue</li><li>Remove large air spaces (bullae) that can form when air sacs are destroyed. The bullae can interfere with breathing.</li><li>Do a <span class="qt2"><span class="qt3">lung</span></span> transplant. This is might be an option if you have very severe <span class="qt0">emphysema</span>.</li></ul></li></ul><p>If you have <span class="qt0">emphysema</span>, it's important to know when and where to get help for your symptoms. You should get emergency care if you have severe symptoms, such as trouble catching your breath or talking. Call your health care provider if your symptoms are getting worse or if you have signs of an infection, such as a fever.</p>Can <span class="qt0">emphysema</span> be prevented?<p>Since smoking causes most cases of <span class="qt0">emphysema</span>, the best way to prevent it is to not smoke. It's also important to try to avoid <span class="qt2"><span class="qt3">lung</span></span> irritants such as secondhand smoke, air pollution, chemical fumes, and dusts.</p><p>NIH: National Heart, <span class="qt2"><span class="qt3">Lung</span></span>, and Blood Institute</p>

Aphasia.name: <span class="qt0">Aphasia</span>

Pyelonephritis.name: Urinary Tract Infections
Pyelonephritis.summary: <p>The urinary system is the body's drainage system for removing wastes and extra water. It includes two kidneys, two ureters, a bladder, and a urethra. Urinary tract infections (UTIs) are the second most common type of infection in the body.</p><p>You may have a UTI if you notice:</p><ul><li>Pain or burning when you urinate</li><li>Fever, tiredness, or shakiness</li><li>An urge to urinate often</li><li>Pressure in your lower belly </li><li>Urine that smells bad or looks cloudy or reddish</li><li>Pain in your back or side below the ribs</li></ul><p>People of any age or sex can get UTIs. But about four times as many women get UTIs as men. You're also at higher risk if you have diabetes, need a tube to drain your bladder, or have a spinal cord injury.</p><p>If you think you have a UTI it is important to see your doctor. Your doctor can tell if you have a UTI with a urine test.  Treatment is with antibiotics. </p><p>NIH: National Institute of Diabetes and Digestive and Kidney Diseases</p>

Effusion pericardial.name: <span class="qt1">Pericardial</span> Disorders
Effusion pericardial.summary: <p>The <span class="qt2">pericardium</span> is a membrane, or sac, that surrounds your heart. It holds the heart in place and helps it work properly.  Problems with the <span class="qt2">pericardium</span> include:</p><ul><li>Pericarditis - an inflammation of the sac. It can be from a virus or other infection, a heart attack, heart surgery, other medical conditions, injuries, and certain medicines.</li><li><span class="qt1">Pericardial</span> <span class="qt0">effusion</span> - the  buildup of fluid in the sac</li><li>Cardiac tamponade - a serious problem in which buildup of fluid in the sac causes problems with the function of the heart</li></ul><p>Symptoms of <span class="qt1">pericardial</span> problems include chest pain, rapid heartbeat, and difficulty breathing. Fever is a common symptom of acute pericarditis. Your doctor may use a physical exam, imaging tests, and heart tests to make a diagnosis. Treatment depends on the cause.</p><p>NIH: National Heart, Lung, and Blood Institute</p>

Obesity morbid.name: Obesity
Obesity morbid.summary: <p><span class="qt0">Obesity</span> means having too much body <span class="qt0">fat</span>. It is different from being <span class="qt0">overweight</span>, which means weighing too much.  The weight may come from muscle, bone, <span class="qt0">fat</span>, and/or body water.  Both terms mean that a person's weight is greater than what's considered healthy for his or her height. </p><p><span class="qt0">Obesity</span> happens over time when you eat more calories than you use. The balance between calories-in and calories-out differs for each person. Factors that might affect your weight include your genetic makeup, overeating, eating high-<span class="qt0">fat</span> foods, and not being physically active. </p><p><span class="qt0">Obesity</span> increases your risk of diabetes, heart disease, stroke, arthritis, and some cancers. If you have <span class="qt0">obesity</span>, losing even 5 to 10% of your weight can delay or prevent some of these diseases. For example, that means losing 10 to 20 pounds if you weigh 200 pounds.</p><p>NIH: National Institute of Diabetes and Digestive and Kidney Diseases</p>

Endocarditis.name: <span class="qt0">Endocarditis</span>

Delirium.name: <span class="qt0">Delirium</span>
Delirium.summary: What is <span class="qt0">delirium</span>?<p><span class="qt0">Delirium</span> is a mental state in which you are confused, disoriented, and not able to think or remember clearly. It usually starts suddenly. It is often temporary and treatable.</p><p>There are three types of <span class="qt0">delirium</span>:</p><ul><li>Hypoactive, where you are not active and seem sleepy, tired, or depressed</li><li>Hyperactive, where you are restless or agitated</li><li>Mixed, where you change back and forth between being hypoactive and hyperactive</li></ul>What causes <span class="qt0">delirium</span>?<p>There are many different problems that can cause <span class="qt0">delirium</span>. Some of the more common causes include:</p><ul><li>Alcohol or drugs, either from intoxication or withdrawal. This includes a serious type of alcohol withdrawal syndrome called <span class="qt0">delirium</span> tremens. It usually happens to people who stop drinking after years of alcohol abuse.</li><li>Dehydration and electrolyte imbalances</li><li>Dementia</li><li>Hospitalization, especially in intensive care</li><li>Infections, such as urinary tract infections, pneumonia, and the flu</li><li>Medicines. This could be a side effect of a medicine, such as sedatives or opioids. Or it could be withdrawal after stopping a medicine.</li><li>Metabolic disorders</li><li>Organ failure, such as kidney or liver failure</li><li>Poisoning</li><li>Serious illnesses</li><li>Severe pain</li><li>Sleep deprivation</li><li>Surgeries, including reactions to anesthesia</li></ul>Who is at risk for <span class="qt0">delirium</span>?<p>Certain factors put you at risk for <span class="qt0">delirium</span>, including:</p><ul><li>Being in a hospital or nursing home</li><li>Dementia</li><li>Having a serious illness or more than one illness</li><li>Having an infection</li><li>Older age</li><li>Surgery</li><li>Taking medicines that affect the mind or behavior</li><li>Taking high doses of pain medicines, such as opioids</li></ul>What are the symptoms of <span class="qt0">delirium</span>?<p>The symptoms of <span class="qt0">delirium</span> usually start suddenly, over a few hours or a few days. They often come and go. The most common symptoms include:</p><ul><li>Changes in alertness (usually more alert in the morning, less at night)</li><li>Changing levels of consciousness</li><li>Confusion</li><li>Disorganized thinking, talking in a way that doesn't make sense</li><li>Disrupted sleep patterns, sleepiness</li><li>Emotional changes: anger, agitation, depression, irritability, overexcitement</li><li>Hallucinations and delusions</li><li>Incontinence</li><li>Memory problems, especially with short-term memory</li><li>Trouble concentrating</li></ul>How is <span class="qt0">delirium</span> diagnosed?<p>Your health care provider may use many tools to make a diagnosis:</p><ul><li>A medical history, which includes asking about your symptoms</li><li>Physical and neurological exams</li><li>Mental status testing</li><li>Lab and  diagnostic imaging tests</li></ul><p><span class="qt0">Delirium</span> and dementia have similar symptoms, so it can be hard to tell them apart. They can also occur together. <span class="qt0">Delirium</span> starts suddenly and can cause hallucinations. The symptoms may get better or worse and can last for hours or weeks.  On the other hand, dementia develops slowly and does not cause hallucinations. The symptoms are stable and may last for months or years.</p>What are the treatments for <span class="qt0">delirium</span>?<p>Treatment of <span class="qt0">delirium</span> focuses on the causes and symptoms of <span class="qt0">delirium</span>. The first step is to identify the cause. Often, treating the cause will lead to a full recovery. The recovery may take some time - weeks or sometimes even months. In the meantime, there may be treatments to manage the symptoms, such as:</p><ul><li>Controlling the environment, which includes making sure that the room is quiet and well-lit, having clocks or calendars in view, and having family members around</li><li>Medicines, including those that control aggression or agitation and pain relievers if there is pain</li><li>If needed, making sure that the person has a hearing aid, glasses, or other devices for communication</li></ul>Can <span class="qt0">delirium</span> be prevented?<p>Treating the conditions that can cause <span class="qt0">delirium</span> may reduce the risk of getting it. Hospitals can help lower the risk of <span class="qt0">delirium</span> by avoiding sedatives and making sure that the room is kept quiet, calm, and well-lit. It can also help to have family members around and to have the same staff members treat the person.</p>

Pneumothorax.name: Pleural Disorders
Pneumothorax.summary: <p>Your pleura is a large, thin sheet of tissue that wraps around the outside of your lungs and lines the inside of your chest cavity. Between the layers of the pleura is a very thin space. Normally it's filled with a small amount of fluid. The fluid helps the two layers of the pleura glide smoothly past each other as your lungs breathe air in and out.</p><p>Disorders of the pleura include:</p><ul><li>Pleurisy - inflammation of the pleura that causes sharp pain with breathing</li><li>Pleural effusion - excess fluid in the pleural space</li><li><span class="qt0">Pneumothorax</span> - buildup of air or gas in the pleural space</li><li>Hemothorax - buildup of blood in the pleural space</li></ul><p>Many different conditions can cause pleural problems. Viral infection is the most common cause of pleurisy. The most common cause of pleural effusion is congestive heart failure. Lung diseases, like COPD, tuberculosis, and acute lung injury, cause <span class="qt0">pneumothorax</span>. Injury to the chest is the most common cause of hemothorax. Treatment focuses on removing fluid, air, or blood from the pleural space, relieving symptoms, and treating the underlying condition.</p><p>NIH: National Heart, Lung, and Blood Institute</p>

Neutropenia.name: Blood Disorders
Neutropenia.summary: <p>Your blood is living tissue made up of liquid and solids. The liquid part, called plasma, is made of water, salts and protein. Over half of your blood is plasma. The solid part of your blood contains red blood cells, white blood cells and platelets.</p><p>Blood disorders affect one or more parts of the blood and prevent your blood from doing its job.  They can be acute or chronic. Many blood disorders are inherited. Other causes include other diseases, side effects of medicines, and a lack of certain nutrients in your diet.</p><p>Types of blood disorders include:</p><ul><li>Platelet disorders, excessive clotting, and bleeding problems, which affect how your blood clots</li><li>Anemia, which happens when your blood does not carry enough oxygen to the rest of your body</li><li>Cancers of the blood, such as leukemia and myeloma</li><li>Eosinophilic disorders, which are problems with one type of white blood cell.</li></ul>

Hyperbilirubinemia.name: Jaundice
Hyperbilirubinemia.summary: <p>Jaundice causes your skin and the whites of your eyes to turn yellow. Too much bilirubin causes jaundice.  Bilirubin is a yellow chemical in hemoglobin, the substance that carries oxygen in your red blood cells. As red blood cells break down, your body builds new cells to replace them. The old ones are processed by the liver. If the liver cannot handle the blood cells as they break down, bilirubin builds up in the body and your skin may look yellow. </p><p>Many healthy babies have some jaundice during the first week of life.  It usually goes away.   However, jaundice can happen at any age and may be a sign of a problem.  Jaundice can happen for many reasons, such as:</p><ul><li>	Blood diseases</li><li>	Genetic syndromes</li><li>	Liver diseases, such as hepatitis or cirrhosis</li><li>	Blockage of bile ducts </li><li>	Infections </li><li>	Medicines </li></ul>

Cholecystitis.name: Gallbladder Diseases
Cholecystitis.summary: <p>Your gallbladder is a pear-shaped organ under your liver. It stores bile, a fluid made by your liver to digest fat. As your stomach and intestines digest food, your gallbladder releases bile through a tube called the common bile duct. The duct connects your gallbladder and liver to your small intestine.</p><p>Your gallbladder is most likely to give you trouble if something blocks the flow of bile through the bile ducts. That is usually a gallstone. Gallstones form when substances in bile harden. Rarely, you can also get cancer in your gallbladder.</p><p>Many gallbladder problems get better with removal of the gallbladder. Fortunately, you can live without a gallbladder. Bile has other ways of reaching your small intestine.</p>

Chronic alcoholic intoxication.name: Alcohol Use Disorder (AUD)
Chronic alcoholic intoxication.summary: What is alcohol use disorder (AUD)?<p>For most adults, moderate alcohol use is probably not harmful. However, about 18 million adult Americans have an alcohol use disorder (AUD).  This means that their drinking causes distress and harm. AUD can range from mild to severe, depending on the symptoms. Severe AUD is sometimes called <span class="qt3">alcoholism</span> or alcohol dependence.</p><p>AUD is a disease that causes:</p><ul><li>Craving - a strong need to drink</li><li>Loss of control - not being able to stop drinking once you've started</li><li>Negative emotional state - feeling anxious and irritable when you are not drinking</li></ul>What is binge drinking?<p>Binge drinking is drinking so much at once that your blood alcohol concentration (BAC) level is 0.08% or more. For a man, this usually happens after having 5 or more drinks within a few hours. For a woman, it is after about 4 or more drinks within a few hours. Not everyone who binge drinks has an AUD, but they are at higher risk for getting one.</p>What are the dangers of too much alcohol?<p>Too much alcohol is dangerous. Heavy drinking can increase the risk of certain cancers. It may lead to liver diseases, such as fatty liver disease and cirrhosis. It can also cause damage to the brain and other organs. Drinking during pregnancy can harm your baby. Alcohol also increases the risk of death from car crashes, injuries, homicide, and suicide.</p>How do I know if I have an alcohol use disorder (AUD)?<p>You may have an AUD if you can answer yes to two or more of these questions:</p><p>In the past year, have you:</p><ul><li>Ended up drinking more or for a longer time than you had planned to?</li><li>Wanted to cut down or stop drinking, or tried to, but couldn't?</li><li>Spent a lot of your time drinking or recovering from drinking?</li><li>Felt a strong need to drink?</li><li>Found that drinking - or being sick from drinking - often interfered with your family life, job, or school?</li><li>Kept drinking even though it was causing trouble with your family or friends?</li><li>Given up or cut back on activities that you enjoyed just so you could drink?</li><li>Gotten into dangerous situations while drinking or after drinking? Some examples are driving drunk and having unsafe sex.</li><li>Kept drinking even though it was making you feel depressed or anxious? Or when it was adding to another health problem?</li><li>Had to drink more and more to feel the effects of the alcohol?</li><li>Had withdrawal symptoms when the alcohol was wearing off? They include trouble sleeping, shakiness, irritability, anxiety, depression, restlessness, nausea, and sweating. In severe cases, you could have a fever, seizures, or hallucinations.</li></ul><p>If you have any of these symptoms, your drinking may already be a cause for concern. The more symptoms you have, the more serious the problem is.</p>What should I do if I think that I might have an alcohol use disorder (AUD)?<p>If you think you might have an AUD, see your health care provider for an evaluation. Your provider can help make a treatment plan, prescribe medicines, and if needed, give you treatment referrals.</p><p>NIH: National Institute on <span class="qt1">Alcohol Abuse</span> and <span class="qt3">Alcoholism</span></p>

Thrombus.name: Deep Vein <span class="qt1">Thrombosis</span>
Thrombus.summary: <p>Deep vein <span class="qt1">thrombosis</span>, or DVT, is a <span class="qt0">blood clot</span> that forms in a vein deep in the body. Most deep vein clots occur in the lower leg or thigh. If the vein swells, the condition is called thrombophlebitis. A deep vein <span class="qt1">thrombosis</span> can break loose and cause a serious problem in the lung,  called a pulmonary embolism.</p><p>Sitting still for a long time can make you more likely to get a DVT. Some medicines and disorders that increase your risk for <span class="qt0">blood clots</span> can also lead to DVTs. Common symptoms are :</p><ul><li> Warmth and tenderness over the vein </li><li> Pain or swelling in the part of the body affected </li><li> Skin redness </li></ul><p>Treatment includes medicines to ease pain and inflammation, break up clots and keep new clots from forming. Keeping the affected area raised and applying moist heat can also help. If you are taking a long car or plane trip, take a break, walk or stretch your legs and drink plenty of liquids.</p>

Pancytopenia.name: Bone Marrow Diseases
Pancytopenia.summary: <p>Bone marrow is the spongy tissue inside some of your bones, such as your hip and thigh bones. It contains stem cells. The stem cells can develop into the red blood cells that carry oxygen through your body, the white blood cells that fight infections, and the platelets that help with blood clotting.</p><p>With bone marrow disease, there are problems with the stem cells or how they develop:</p><ul><li>In leukemia, a cancer of the blood, the bone marrow makes abnormal white blood cells</li><li>In aplastic anemia, the bone marrow doesn't make red blood cells</li><li>In myeloproliferative disorders, the bone marrow makes too many white blood cells</li><li>Other diseases, such as lymphoma, can spread into the bone marrow and affect the production of blood cells</li></ul><p>Causes of bone marrow diseases include genetics and environmental factors. Tests for bone marrow diseases include blood and bone marrow tests. Treatments depend on the disorder and how severe it is. They might involve medicines, blood transfusions or a bone marrow transplant.</p>

Dependence.name: Alcohol Use Disorder (AUD)
Dependence.summary: What is alcohol use disorder (AUD)?<p>For most adults, moderate alcohol use is probably not harmful. However, about 18 million adult Americans have an alcohol use disorder (AUD).  This means that their drinking causes distress and harm. AUD can range from mild to severe, depending on the symptoms. Severe AUD is sometimes called alcoholism or alcohol <span class="qt0">dependence</span>.</p><p>AUD is a disease that causes:</p><ul><li>Craving - a strong need to drink</li><li>Loss of control - not being able to stop drinking once you've started</li><li>Negative emotional state - feeling anxious and irritable when you are not drinking</li></ul>What is binge drinking?<p>Binge drinking is drinking so much at once that your blood alcohol concentration (BAC) level is 0.08% or more. For a man, this usually happens after having 5 or more drinks within a few hours. For a woman, it is after about 4 or more drinks within a few hours. Not everyone who binge drinks has an AUD, but they are at higher risk for getting one.</p>What are the dangers of too much alcohol?<p>Too much alcohol is dangerous. Heavy drinking can increase the risk of certain cancers. It may lead to liver diseases, such as fatty liver disease and cirrhosis. It can also cause damage to the brain and other organs. Drinking during pregnancy can harm your baby. Alcohol also increases the risk of death from car crashes, injuries, homicide, and suicide.</p>How do I know if I have an alcohol use disorder (AUD)?<p>You may have an AUD if you can answer yes to two or more of these questions:</p><p>In the past year, have you:</p><ul><li>Ended up drinking more or for a longer time than you had planned to?</li><li>Wanted to cut down or stop drinking, or tried to, but couldn't?</li><li>Spent a lot of your time drinking or recovering from drinking?</li><li>Felt a strong need to drink?</li><li>Found that drinking - or being sick from drinking - often interfered with your family life, job, or school?</li><li>Kept drinking even though it was causing trouble with your family or friends?</li><li>Given up or cut back on activities that you enjoyed just so you could drink?</li><li>Gotten into dangerous situations while drinking or after drinking? Some examples are driving drunk and having unsafe sex.</li><li>Kept drinking even though it was making you feel depressed or anxious? Or when it was adding to another health problem?</li><li>Had to drink more and more to feel the effects of the alcohol?</li><li>Had withdrawal symptoms when the alcohol was wearing off? They include trouble sleeping, shakiness, irritability, anxiety, depression, restlessness, nausea, and sweating. In severe cases, you could have a fever, seizures, or hallucinations.</li></ul><p>If you have any of these symptoms, your drinking may already be a cause for concern. The more symptoms you have, the more serious the problem is.</p>What should I do if I think that I might have an alcohol use disorder (AUD)?<p>If you think you might have an AUD, see your health care provider for an evaluation. Your provider can help make a treatment plan, prescribe medicines, and if needed, give you treatment referrals.</p><p>NIH: National Institute on Alcohol Abuse and Alcoholism</p>

Hernia hiatal.name: <span class="qt0">Hiatal Hernia</span>
Hernia hiatal.summary: <p>A <span class="qt0">hiatal hernia</span> is a condition in which the upper part of your stomach bulges through an opening in your diaphragm. Your diaphragm is the thin muscle that separates your chest from your abdomen. Your diaphragm helps keep acid from coming up into your esophagus. When you have a <span class="qt0">hiatal hernia</span>, it's easier for the acid to come up. This leaking of acid from your stomach into your esophagus is called GERD (gastroesophageal reflux disease). GERD may cause symptoms such as :</p><ul><li>Heartburn</li><li>Problems swallowing</li><li>A dry cough</li><li>Bad breath</li><li>Nausea and/or vomiting</li><li>Breathing problems</li><li>The wearing away of your teeth</li></ul><p>Often, the cause of a <span class="qt0">hiatal hernia</span> is unknown. It may have to do with weakness in the surrounding muscles. Sometimes the cause is an injury or a birth defect. Your risk of getting a <span class="qt0">hiatal hernia</span> goes up as you age; they are common in people over age 50. You are also at higher risk if you have obesity or smoke.</p><p>People usually find out that they have a <span class="qt0">hiatal hernia</span> when they are getting tests for GERD, heartburn, chest pain, or abdominal pain. The tests may be a chest x-ray, an x-ray with a barium swallow, or an upper endoscopy.</p><p>You don't need treatment if your <span class="qt0">hiatal hernia</span> does not cause any symptoms or problems. If you do have symptoms, some lifestyle changes may help. They include eating small meals, avoiding certain foods, not smoking or drinking alcohol, and losing weight. Your health care provider may recommend antacids or other medicines. If these don't help, you may need surgery.</p><p>NIH: National Institute of Diabetes and Digestive and Kidney Diseases</p>

Tachycardia sinus.name: Arrhythmia
Tachycardia sinus.summary: <p>An arrhythmia is a problem with the rate or rhythm of your heartbeat. It means that your heart beats too quickly, too slowly, or with an irregular pattern. When the heart beats faster than normal, it is called <span class="qt0">tachycardia</span>. When the heart beats too slowly, it is called bradycardia. The most common type of arrhythmia is atrial fibrillation, which causes an irregular and fast heart beat.</p><p>Many factors can affect your heart's rhythm, such as having had a heart attack, smoking, congenital heart defects, and stress. Some substances or medicines may also cause arrhythmias. </p><p>Symptoms of arrhythmias include:</p><ul><li>Fast or slow heart beat</li><li>Skipping beats</li><li>Lightheadedness or dizziness</li><li>Chest pain</li><li>Shortness of breath </li><li>Sweating </li></ul><p>Your doctor can run tests to find out if you have an arrhythmia. Treatment to restore a normal heart rhythm may include medicines, an implantable cardioverter-defibrillator (ICD) or pacemaker, or sometimes surgery. </p><p>NIH: National Heart, Lung, and Blood Institute</p>

Influenza.name: <span class="qt0"><span class="qt1">Flu</span></span>
Influenza.summary: What is the <span class="qt0"><span class="qt1">flu</span></span>?<p>The <span class="qt0"><span class="qt1">flu</span></span>, also called <span class="qt0"><span class="qt1">influenza</span></span>, is a respiratory infection caused by viruses. Each year, millions of Americans get sick with the <span class="qt0"><span class="qt1">flu</span></span>. Sometimes it causes mild illness. But it can also be serious or even deadly, especially for people over 65, newborn babies, and people with certain chronic illnesses.</p>What causes the <span class="qt0"><span class="qt1">flu</span></span>?<p>The <span class="qt0"><span class="qt1">flu</span></span> is caused by <span class="qt0"><span class="qt1">flu</span></span> viruses that spread from person to person.
