When someone with the <span class="qt0"><span class="qt1">flu</span></span> coughs, sneezes, or talks, they spray tiny droplets. These droplets can land in the mouths or noses of people who are nearby. Less often, a person may get <span class="qt0"><span class="qt1">flu</span></span> by touching a surface or object that has <span class="qt0"><span class="qt1">flu</span></span> virus on it and then touching their own mouth, nose, or possibly their eyes.</p>What are the symptoms of the <span class="qt0"><span class="qt1">flu</span></span>?<p>Symptoms of the <span class="qt0"><span class="qt1">flu</span></span> come on suddenly and may include:</p><ul><li>Fever or feeling feverish/chills</li><li>Cough</li><li>Sore throat</li><li>Runny or stuffy nose</li><li>Muscle or body aches</li><li>Headaches</li><li>Fatigue (tiredness)</li></ul><p>Some people may also have vomiting and diarrhea. This is more common in children.</p><p>Sometimes people have trouble figuring out whether they have a cold or the <span class="qt0"><span class="qt1">flu</span></span>. There are differences between them:</p>Signs and SymptomsColdFluStart of symptomsSlowlySuddenlyFeverRarelyUsuallyAchesSometimes (slight)UsuallyFatigue, weaknessSometimesUsuallyHeadacheRarelyCommonStuffy nose, sneezing, or sore throatCommonSometimes<p>Sometimes people say that they have a <span class="qt0"><span class="qt1">"flu"</span></span> when they really have something else. For example, <span class="qt0"><span class="qt1">"stomach flu"</span></span> isn't the <span class="qt0"><span class="qt1">flu</span></span>; it's gastroenteritis.</p>What other problems can the <span class="qt0"><span class="qt1">flu</span></span> cause?<p>Some people who get the <span class="qt0"><span class="qt1">flu</span></span> will develop complications. Some of these complications can be serious or even life-threatening. They include:</p><ul><li>Bronchitis</li><li>Ear infection</li><li>Sinus infection</li><li>Pneumonia</li><li>Inflammation of the heart (myocarditis), brain (encephalitis), or muscle tissues (myositis, rhabdomyolysis)</li></ul><p>The <span class="qt0"><span class="qt1">flu</span></span> also can make chronic health problems worse. For example, people with asthma may have asthma attacks while they have <span class="qt0"><span class="qt1">flu</span></span>.</p><p>Certain people are more likely to have complications from the <span class="qt0"><span class="qt1">flu</span></span>, including:</p><ul><li>Adults 65 and older</li><li>Pregnant women</li><li>Children younger than 5</li><li>People with certain chronic health conditions, such as asthma, diabetes, and heart disease</li></ul>How is the <span class="qt0"><span class="qt1">flu</span></span> diagnosed?<p>To diagnose the <span class="qt0"><span class="qt1">flu</span></span>, health care providers will first do a medical history and ask about your symptoms. There are several tests for the <span class="qt0"><span class="qt1">flu</span></span>. For the tests, your provider will swipe the inside of your nose or the back of your throat with a swab. Then the swab will be tested for the <span class="qt0"><span class="qt1">flu</span></span> virus.</p><p>Some tests are quick and give results in 15-20 minutes. But these tests are not as accurate as other <span class="qt0"><span class="qt1">flu</span></span> tests. These other tests can give you the results in one hour or several hours.</p>What are the treatments for the <span class="qt0"><span class="qt1">flu</span></span>?<p>Most people with the <span class="qt0"><span class="qt1">flu</span></span> recover on their own without medical care. People with mild cases of the <span class="qt0"><span class="qt1">flu</span></span> should stay home and avoid contact with others, except to get medical care.</p><p>But if you have symptoms of <span class="qt0"><span class="qt1">flu</span></span> and are in a high risk group or are very sick or worried about your illness, contact your health care provider. You might need antiviral medicines to treat your <span class="qt0"><span class="qt1">flu</span></span>. Antiviral medicines can make the illness milder and shorten the time you are sick. They also can prevent serious <span class="qt0"><span class="qt1">flu</span></span> complications. They usually work best when you start taking them within 2 days of getting sick.</p>Can the <span class="qt0"><span class="qt1">flu</span></span> be prevented?<p>The best way to prevent the <span class="qt0"><span class="qt1">flu is to get flu</span></span> vaccine every year. But it's also important to have good health habits like covering your cough and washing your hands often. This can help stop the spread of germs and prevent the <span class="qt0"><span class="qt1">flu</span></span>.</p><p>Centers for Disease Control and Prevention</p>

Cholelithiasis.name: <span class="qt1">Gallstones</span>
Cholelithiasis.summary: <p>Your gallbladder is a pear-shaped organ under your liver. It stores bile, a fluid made by your liver to digest fat. As your stomach and intestines digest food, your gallbladder releases bile through a tube called the common bile duct. The duct connects your gallbladder and liver to your small intestine.</p><p>Your gallbladder is most likely to give you trouble if something blocks the flow of bile through the bile ducts. That is usually a  <span class="qt1">gallstone. Gallstones</span> form when substances in bile harden. <span class="qt1">Gallstone</span> attacks usually happen after you eat. Signs of a <span class="qt1">gallstone</span> attack may include nausea, vomiting, or pain in the abdomen, back, or just under the right arm.</p><p><span class="qt1">Gallstones</span> are most common among older adults, women, overweight people, Native Americans and Mexican Americans.</p><p><span class="qt1">Gallstones</span> are often found during imaging tests for other health conditions. If you do not have symptoms, you usually do not need treatment. The most common treatment is removal of the gallbladder. Fortunately, you can live without a gallbladder.  Bile has other ways to reach your small intestine.</p><p>NIH: National Institute of Diabetes and Digestive and Kidney Diseases</p>

Migraine disorders.name: <span class="qt0">Migraine</span>
Migraine disorders.summary: What are <span class="qt0">migraines</span>?<p><span class="qt0">Migraines</span> are a recurring type of headache. They cause moderate to severe pain that is throbbing or pulsing. The pain is often on one side of your head. You may also have other symptoms, such as nausea and weakness. You may be sensitive to light and sound.</p>What causes <span class="qt0">migraines</span>?<p>Researchers believe that <span class="qt0">migraine</span> has a genetic cause. There are also a number of factors that can trigger a <span class="qt0">migraine</span>. These factors vary from person to person, and they include:</p><ul><li>Stress</li><li>Anxiety</li><li>Hormonal changes in women</li><li>Bright or flashing lights</li><li>Loud noises</li><li>Strong smells</li><li>Medicines</li><li>Too much or not enough sleep</li><li>Sudden changes in weather or environment</li><li>Overexertion (too much physical activity)</li><li>Tobacco</li><li>Caffeine or caffeine withdrawal</li><li>Skipped meals</li><li>Medication overuse (taking medicine for <span class="qt0">migraines</span> too often)</li></ul><p>Some people have found that certain foods or ingredients can trigger headaches, especially when they are combined with other triggers. These foods and ingredients include:</p><ul><li>Alcohol</li><li>Chocolate</li><li>Aged cheeses</li><li>Monosodium glutamate (MSG)</li><li>Some fruits and nuts</li><li>Fermented or pickled goods</li><li>Yeast</li><li>Cured or processed meats</li></ul>Who is at risk for <span class="qt0">migraines</span>?<p>About 12% of Americans get <span class="qt0">migraines</span>. They can affect anyone, but you are more likely to have them if you:</p><ul><li>Are a woman. Women are three times more likely than men to get <span class="qt0">migraines</span>.</li><li>Have a family history of <span class="qt0">migraines</span>. Most people with <span class="qt0">migraines</span> have family members who have <span class="qt0">migraines</span>.</li><li>Have other medical conditions, such as depression, anxiety, bipolar <span class="qt1">disorder</span>, sleep <span class="qt1">disorders</span>, and epilepsy.</li></ul>What are the symptoms of <span class="qt0">migraines</span>?<p>There are four different phases of <span class="qt0">migraines</span>. You may not always go through every phase each time you have a <span class="qt0">migraine</span>.:</p><ul><li>Prodome. This phase starts up to 24 hours before you get the <span class="qt0">migraine</span>. You have early signs and symptoms, such as food cravings, unexplained mood changes, uncontrollable yawning, fluid retention, and increased urination.</li><li>Aura. If you have this phase, you might see flashing or bright lights or zig-zag lines. You may have muscle weakness or feel like you are being touched or grabbed. An aura can happen just before or during a <span class="qt0">migraine</span>.</li><li>Headache. A <span class="qt0">migraine</span> usually starts gradually and then becomes more severe. It typically causes throbbing or pulsing pain, which is often on one side of your head. But sometimes you can have a <span class="qt0">migraine</span> without a headache. Other <span class="qt0">migraine</span> symptoms may include</li><ul><li>Increased sensitivity to light, noise, and odors</li><li>Nausea and vomiting</li><li>Worsened pain when you move, cough, or sneeze</li></ul><li>Postdrome (following the headache). You may feel exhausted, weak, and confused after a <span class="qt0">migraine</span>. This can last up to a day.</li></ul><p><span class="qt0">Migraines</span> are more common in the morning; people often wake up with them. Some people have <span class="qt0">migraines</span> at predictable times, such as before menstruation or on weekends following a stressful week of work.</p>How are <span class="qt0">migraines</span> diagnosed?<p>To make a diagnosis, your health care provider will:</p><ul><li>Take your medical history</li><li>Ask about your symptoms</li><li>Do a physical and neurological exam</li></ul><p>An important part of diagnosing <span class="qt0">migraines</span> is to rule out other medical conditions which could be causing the symptoms. So you may also have blood tests, an MRI or CT scan, or other tests.</p>How are <span class="qt0">migraines</span> treated?<p>There is no cure for <span class="qt0">migraines</span>. Treatment focuses on relieving symptoms and preventing additional attacks.</p><p>There are different types of medicines to relieve symptoms. They include triptan drugs, ergotamine drugs, and pain relievers. The sooner you take the medicine, the more effective it is.</p><p>There are also other things you can do to feel better:</p><ul><li>Resting with your eyes closed in a quiet, darkened room</li><li>Placing a cool cloth or ice pack on your forehead</li><li>Drinking fluids</li></ul><p>There are some lifestyle changes you can make to prevent <span class="qt0">migraines</span>:</p><ul><li>Stress management strategies, such as exercise, relaxation techniques, and biofeedback, may reduce the number and severity of <span class="qt0">migraines</span>. Biofeedback uses electronic devices to teach you to control certain body functions, such as your heartbeat, blood pressure, and muscle tension.</li><li>Make a log of what seems to trigger your <span class="qt0">migraines</span>. You can learn what you need to avoid, such as certain foods and medicines. It also help you figure out what you should do, such as establishing a consistent sleep schedule and eating regular meals.</li><li>Hormone therapy may help some women whose <span class="qt0">migraines</span> seem to be linked to their menstrual cycle</li><li>If you have obesity, losing weight may also be helpful</li></ul><p>If you have frequent or severe <span class="qt0">migraines</span>, you may need to take medicines to prevent further attacks. Talk with your health care provider about which drug would be right for you.</p><p>Certain natural treatments, such as riboflavin (vitamin B2) and coenzyme Q10, may help prevent <span class="qt0">migraines</span>. If your magnesium level is low, you can try taking magnesium. There is also an herb, butterbur, which some people take to prevent <span class="qt0">migraines</span>. But butterbur may not be safe for long-term use. Always check with your health care provider before taking any supplements.</p><p>NIH: National Institute of Neurological <span class="qt1">Disorders</span> and Stroke</p>

Biliary calculus.name: <span class="qt2">Gallstones</span>
Biliary calculus.summary: <p>Your gallbladder is a pear-shaped organ under your liver. It stores bile, a fluid made by your liver to digest fat. As your stomach and intestines digest food, your gallbladder releases bile through a tube called the common bile duct. The duct connects your gallbladder and liver to your small intestine.</p><p>Your gallbladder is most likely to give you trouble if something blocks the flow of bile through the bile ducts. That is usually a  <span class="qt2">gallstone. Gallstones</span> form when substances in bile harden. <span class="qt2">Gallstone</span> attacks usually happen after you eat. Signs of a <span class="qt2">gallstone</span> attack may include nausea, vomiting, or pain in the abdomen, back, or just under the right arm.</p><p><span class="qt2">Gallstones</span> are most common among older adults, women, overweight people, Native Americans and Mexican Americans.</p><p><span class="qt2">Gallstones</span> are often found during imaging tests for other health conditions. If you do not have symptoms, you usually do not need treatment. The most common treatment is removal of the gallbladder. Fortunately, you can live without a gallbladder.  Bile has other ways to reach your small intestine.</p><p>NIH: National Institute of Diabetes and Digestive and Kidney Diseases</p>

Adhesion.name: <span class="qt0">Adhesions</span>
Adhesion.summary: <p><span class="qt0">Adhesions</span> are bands of scar-like tissue. Normally, internal tissues and organs have slippery surfaces so they can shift easily as the body moves. <span class="qt0">Adhesions</span> cause tissues and organs to stick together. They might connect the loops of the intestines to each other, to nearby organs, or to the wall of the abdomen. They can pull sections of the intestines out of place. This may block food from passing through the intestine.</p><p><span class="qt0">Adhesions</span> can occur anywhere in the body. But they often form after surgery on the abdomen. Almost everyone who has surgery on the abdomen gets <span class="qt0">adhesions. Some adhesions</span> don't cause any problems. But when they partly or completely block the intestines, they cause symptoms such as:</p><ul><li>Severe abdominal pain or cramping</li><li>Vomiting</li><li>Bloating</li><li>An inability to pass gas</li><li>Constipation</li></ul><p><span class="qt0">Adhesions</span> can sometimes cause infertility in women by preventing fertilized eggs from reaching the uterus.</p><p>No tests are available to detect <span class="qt0">adhesions</span>.  Doctors usually find them during surgery to diagnose other problems.</p><p>Some <span class="qt0">adhesions</span> go away by themselves. If they partly block your intestines, a diet low in fiber can allow food to move easily through the affected area. If you have a complete intestinal obstruction, it is life-threatening. You should get immediate medical attention and may need surgery. </p><p>NIH: National Institute of Diabetes and Digestive and Kidney Diseases</p>

Delusion.name: Psychotic Disorders
Delusion.summary: <p>Psychotic disorders are severe mental disorders that cause abnormal thinking and perceptions. People with psychoses lose touch with reality. Two of the main symptoms are <span class="qt0"><span class="qt1">delusions and hallucinations. Delusions</span></span> are false beliefs, such as thinking that someone is plotting against you or that the TV is sending you secret messages. <span class="qt0"><span class="qt1">Hallucinations</span></span> are false perceptions, such as hearing, seeing, or feeling something that is not there.</p><p>Schizophrenia is one type of psychotic disorder. People with bipolar disorder may also have psychotic symptoms. Other problems that can cause psychosis include alcohol and some drugs, brain tumors, brain infections, and stroke.</p><p>Treatment depends on the cause of the psychosis. It might involve drugs to control symptoms and talk therapy. Hospitalization is an option for serious cases where a person might be dangerous to himself or others.</p>

Ileus.name: Intestinal Obstruction
Ileus.summary: <p>An intestinal obstruction occurs when food or stool cannot move through the intestines. The obstruction can be complete or partial. There are many causes. The most common are adhesions, hernias, cancers, and certain medicines. </p><p>Symptoms include:</p><ul><li>Severe abdominal pain or cramping </li><li>Vomiting </li><li>Bloating </li><li>Loud bowel sounds </li><li>Swelling of the abdomen </li><li>Inability to pass gas </li><li>Constipation</li></ul><p>A complete intestinal obstruction is a medical emergency.  It often requires surgery.</p><p>NIH: National Institute of Diabetes and Digestive and Kidney Diseases</p>

Decubitus ulcer.name: Pressure Sores
Decubitus ulcer.summary: <p>Pressure sores are areas of damaged skin caused by staying in one position for too long. They commonly form where your bones are close to your skin, such as your ankles, back, elbows, heels and hips. You are at risk if you are bedridden, use a wheelchair, or are unable to change your position. Pressure sores can cause serious infections, some of which are life-threatening. They can be a problem for people in nursing homes.</p><p>You can prevent the sores by :</p><ul><li>	Keeping skin clean and dry</li><li>Changing position every two hours</li><li>	Using pillows and products that relieve pressure</li></ul><p>Pressure sores have a variety of treatments. Advanced sores are slow to heal, so early treatment is best.</p>

Osteomyelitis.name: Bone Infections
Osteomyelitis.summary: <p>Like other parts of the body, bones can get infected. The infections are usually bacterial, but can also be fungal. They may spread to the bone from nearby skin or muscles, or from another part of the body through the bloodstream. People who are at risk for bone infections include those with diabetes, poor circulation, or recent injury to the bone. You may also be at risk if you are having hemodialysis. </p><p>Symptoms of bone infections include:</p><ul><li>Pain in the infected area</li><li>Chills and fever</li><li>Swelling, warmth, and redness</li></ul><p>A blood test or imaging test such as an x-ray can tell if you have a bone infection. Treatment includes antibiotics and often surgery.</p>

Gastritis.name: Stomach Disorders
Gastritis.summary: <p>Your stomach is an organ between your esophagus and small intestine. It is where digestion of protein begins. The stomach has three tasks. It stores swallowed food. It mixes the food with stomach acids. Then it sends the mixture on to the small intestine.</p><p>Most people have a problem with their stomach at one time or another. Indigestion and heartburn are common problems. You can relieve some stomach problems with over-the-counter medicines and lifestyle changes, such as avoiding fatty foods or eating more slowly. Other problems like peptic ulcers or GERD require medical attention. </p><p>You should see a doctor if you have any of the following:</p><ul><li>Blood when you have a bowel movement</li><li>Severe abdominal pain</li><li>Heartburn not relieved by antacids </li><li>Unintended weight loss </li><li>Ongoing vomiting or diarrhea</li></ul><p>NIH: National Institute of Diabetes and Digestive and Kidney Diseases</p>

Sickle cell anemia.name: <span class="qt0"><span class="qt3">Sickle</span></span><span class="qt3"> </span><span class="qt1"><span class="qt3">Cell</span></span><span class="qt3"> Disease</span>
Sickle cell anemia.summary: What is <span class="qt0"><span class="qt3">sickle</span></span><span class="qt3"> </span><span class="qt1"><span class="qt3">cell</span></span><span class="qt3"> disease</span> (SCD)?<p><span class="qt0"><span class="qt3">Sickle</span></span><span class="qt3"> </span><span class="qt1"><span class="qt3">cell</span></span><span class="qt3"> disease</span> (SCD) is a group of inherited red blood <span class="qt1">cell</span> disorders. If you have SCD, there is a problem with your hemoglobin. Hemoglobin is a protein in red blood <span class="qt1">cells</span> that carries oxygen throughout the body. With SCD, the hemoglobin forms into stiff rods within the red blood <span class="qt1">cells</span>. This changes the shape of the red blood <span class="qt1">cells. The cells</span> are supposed to be disc-shaped, but this changes them into a crescent, or <span class="qt0">sickle</span>, shape.</p><p>The <span class="qt0">sickle</span>-shaped <span class="qt1">cells</span> are not flexible and cannot change shape easily. Many of them burst apart as they move through your blood vessels. The <span class="qt0">sickle</span> <span class="qt1">cells</span> usually only last 10 to 20 days, instead of the normal 90 to 120 days. Your body may have trouble making enough new <span class="qt1">cells</span> to replace the ones that you lost. Because of this, you may not have enough red blood <span class="qt1">cells</span>. This is a condition called <span class="qt2">anemia</span>, and it can make you feel tired.</p><p>The <span class="qt0">sickle</span>-shaped <span class="qt1">cells</span> can also stick to vessel walls, causing a blockage that slows or stops the flow of blood. When this happens, oxygen can't reach nearby tissues. The lack of oxygen can cause attacks of sudden, severe pain, called pain crises. These attacks can occur without warning. If you get one, you might need to go to the hospital for treatment.</p>What causes <span class="qt0"><span class="qt3">sickle</span></span><span class="qt3"> </span><span class="qt1"><span class="qt3">cell</span></span><span class="qt3"> disease</span> (SCD)?<p>The cause of SCD is a defective gene, called a <span class="qt0">sickle</span> <span class="qt1">cell</span> gene. People with the disease are born with two <span class="qt0">sickle</span> <span class="qt1">cell</span> genes, one from each parent.</p><p>If you are born with one <span class="qt0">sickle</span> <span class="qt1">cell</span> gene, it's called <span class="qt0">sickle</span> <span class="qt1">cell</span> trait. People with <span class="qt0">sickle</span> <span class="qt1">cell</span> trait are generally healthy, but they can pass the defective gene on to their children.</p>Who is at risk for <span class="qt0"><span class="qt3">sickle</span></span><span class="qt3"> </span><span class="qt1"><span class="qt3">cell</span></span><span class="qt3"> disease</span> (SCD)?<p>In the United States, most of the people with SCD are African Americans:</p><ul><li>About 1 in 13 African American babies is born with <span class="qt0">sickle</span> <span class="qt1">cell</span> trait</li><li>About 1 in every 365 black children is born with <span class="qt0"><span class="qt3">sickle</span></span><span class="qt3"> </span><span class="qt1"><span class="qt3">cell</span></span><span class="qt3"> disease</span></li></ul><p>SCD also affects some people who come from Hispanic, southern European, Middle Eastern, or Asian Indian backgrounds.</p>What are the symptoms of <span class="qt0"><span class="qt3">sickle</span></span><span class="qt3"> </span><span class="qt1"><span class="qt3">cell</span></span><span class="qt3"> disease</span> (SCD)?<p>People with SCD start to have signs of the disease during the first year of life, usually around 5 months of age. Early symptoms of SCD may include:</p><ul><li>Painful swelling of the hands and feet</li><li>Fatigue or fussiness from <span class="qt2">anemia</span></li><li>A yellowish color of the skin (jaundice) or the whites of the eyes (icterus)</li></ul><p>The effects of SCD vary from person to person and can change over time. Most of the signs and symptoms of SCD are related to complications of the disease. They may include severe pain, <span class="qt2">anemia</span>, organ damage, and infections.</p>How is <span class="qt0"><span class="qt3">sickle</span></span><span class="qt3"> </span><span class="qt1"><span class="qt3">cell</span></span><span class="qt3"> disease</span> (SCD) diagnosed?<p>A blood test can show if you have SCD or <span class="qt0">sickle</span> <span class="qt1">cell</span> trait. All states now test newborns as part of their screening programs, so treatment can begin early.</p><p>People who are thinking about having children can have the test to find out how likely it is that their children will have SCD.</p><p>Doctors can also diagnose SCD before a baby is born. That test uses a sample of amniotic fluid (the liquid in the sac surrounding the baby) or tissue taken from the placenta (the organ that brings oxygen and nutrients to the baby).</p>What are the treatments for <span class="qt0"><span class="qt3">sickle</span></span><span class="qt3"> </span><span class="qt1"><span class="qt3">cell</span></span><span class="qt3"> disease</span> (SCD)?<p>The only cure for SCD is bone marrow or stem <span class="qt1">cell</span> transplantation. Because these transplants are risky and can have serious side effects, they are usually only used in children with severe SCD. For the transplant to work, the bone marrow must be a close match. Usually, the best donor is a brother or sister.</p><p>There are treatments that can help relieve symptoms, lessen complications, and prolong life:</p><ul><li>Antibiotics to try to prevent infections in younger children</li><li>Pain relievers for acute or chronic pain</li><li>Hydroxyurea, a medicine that has been shown to reduce or prevent several SCD complications. It increases the amount of fetal hemoglobin in the blood. This medicine is not right for everyone; talk to your health care provider about whether you should take it. This medicine is not safe during pregnancy.</li><li>Childhood vaccinations to prevent infections</li><li>Blood transfusions for severe <span class="qt2">anemia</span>. If you have had some serious complications, such as a stroke, you may have transfusions to prevent more complications.</li></ul><p>There are other treatments for specific complications.</p><p>To stay as healthy as possible, make sure that you get regular medical care, live a healthy lifestyle, and avoid situations that may set off a pain crisis.</p><p>NIH: National Heart, Lung, and Blood Institute</p>

Bacteremia.name: Sepsis
Bacteremia.summary: What is sepsis?<p>Sepsis is your body's overactive and extreme response to an infection. Sepsis is a life-threatening medical emergency. Without quick treatment, it can lead to tissue damage, organ failure, and even death.</p>What causes sepsis?<p>Sepsis happens when an infection you already have triggers a chain reaction throughout your body. Bacterial infections are the most common cause, but other types of infections can also cause it.</p><p>The infections are often in the lungs, stomach, kidneys, or bladder. It's possible for sepsis to begin with a small cut that gets infected or with an infection that develops after surgery. Sometimes, sepsis can occur in people who didn't even know that they had an infection.</p>Who is at risk for sepsis?<p>Anyone with an infection could get sepsis. But certain people are at higher risk:</p><ul><li>Adults 65 or older</li><li>People with chronic conditions, such as diabetes, lung disease, cancer, and kidney disease</li><li>People with weakened immune systems</li><li>Pregnant women</li><li>Children younger than one</li></ul>What are the symptoms of sepsis?<p>Sepsis can cause one or more of these symptoms:</p><ul><li>Rapid breathing and heart rate</li><li>Shortness of breath</li><li>Confusion or disorientation</li><li>Extreme pain or discomfort</li><li>Fever, shivering, or feeling very cold</li><li>Clammy or sweaty skin</li></ul><p>It's important to get medical care right away if you think you might have sepsis or if your infection is not getting better or is getting worse.</p>What other problems can sepsis cause?<p>Severe cases of sepsis can lead to septic shock, where your blood pressure drops to a dangerous level and multiple organs can fail.</p>How is sepsis diagnosed?<p>Your health care provider may use many tools to make a diagnosis:</p><ul><li>A medical history, which includes asking about your symptoms </li><li>A physical exam, including checking vital signs (your temperature, blood pressure, heart rate, and breathing)</li><li>Lab tests that check for signs of infection or organ damage</li><li>Imaging tests such as an x-ray or a CT scan to find the location of the infection</li></ul><p>Many of the signs and symptoms of sepsis can also be caused by other medical conditions. This may make sepsis hard to diagnose in its early stages.</p>What are the treatments for sepsis?<p>It is very important to get treatment right away. Treatment usually includes:</p><ul><li>Antibiotics</li><li>Maintaining blood flow to organs. This may involve getting oxygen and intravenous (IV) fluids.</li><li>Treating the source of the infection</li><li>If needed, medicines to increase blood pressure</li></ul><p>In serious cases, you might need kidney dialysis or a breathing tube. Some people need surgery to remove tissue damaged by the infection.</p>Can sepsis be prevented?<p>To prevent sepsis, you should try to prevent getting an infection:</p><ul><li>Take good care of any chronic health conditions that you have</li><li>Get recommended vaccines</li><li>Practice good hygiene, such as handwashing</li><li>Keep cuts clean and covered until healed</li></ul><p>NIH: National Institute of General Medical SciencesCenters for Disease Control and Prevention</p>

Failure kidney.name: <span class="qt1">Kidney</span> <span class="qt0">Failure</span>
Failure kidney.summary: <p>Healthy <span class="qt1">kidneys</span> clean your blood by removing excess fluid, minerals, and wastes. They also make hormones that keep your bones strong and your blood healthy. But if the <span class="qt1">kidneys</span> are damaged, they <span class="qt0">don't work</span> properly. Harmful wastes can build up in your body. Your blood pressure may rise. Your body may retain excess fluid and not make enough red blood cells. This is called <span class="qt1">kidney</span> <span class="qt0">failure</span>.</p><p>If your <span class="qt1">kidneys</span> <span class="qt0">fail</span>, you need treatment to replace the work they normally do. The treatment options are dialysis or a <span class="qt1">kidney</span> transplant. Each treatment has benefits and drawbacks. No matter which treatment you choose, you'll need to make some changes in your life, including how you eat and plan your activities. But with the help of health care providers, family, and friends, most people with <span class="qt1">kidney</span> <span class="qt0">failure</span> can lead full and active lives.</p><p>NIH: National Institute of Diabetes and Digestive and <span class="qt1">Kidney</span> Diseases</p>
